reviews.review: Great Day Trip and Seafood. We went out to Sai Kung for the seafood. The seafood was so fresh. The restaurants have all the fish tanks out front. You can pick and choose what you want and how you want it to be cooked. We watched fishermen sell their catch at the docks.

Little gem!. Just a 45 minutes taxi drive, you can get away from the hustle from Hong Kong. Here you may experience the locals and the seafood markets/restaurants and /or take a boat ride to one of the several islands. We took a short boat ride to Hap Mun Beach Bay. Very few people there but a very nice, clean, white sand beach. Very clean changing and bathroom areas. You may want to bring your own food/snacks, although you can purchase some drinks at a slightly higher prices. The water was extremely clear and fresh.The same boat ride company will pick you up at an agreed time.Once in town, you may want to eat or drink some tea overlooking the beautiful fishing boats!

Beautiful place to visit, wonderful to live in. Lived in said king for 2 years. It's an escape from busy hong Kong, but you can easily get to the city. Great place for trips to the islands. Wonderful seafood restaurants and a great expat community

Hard to be clear on this-. Sai Kung, been there twice, the first time we enjoyed walking around the shops. We thought it would be great to go back and take a boat trip. We paid $300HK (for two) for one hour Sampan ride. the two hour ride would have taken us to some caves, but as we have some great caves in Scotland, wasn't sure it was worth the ride/cost. the one hour ride was around the bay, without any other passengers. However, it was as if the driver just wanted us to sit in the water. Paddling would have been quicker. so we have learnt a lesson- go to Sai Kung, walk around the shops, and take a very cheap ferry ride to the local islands, you will see more than you would with a one hour sampan ride. If you want to go on a sampan go to Aberdeen and negotiate there (about $100-$150HK or less). You'll see slightly more, but still not a lot in half an hour. We took the long road back by bus to Sha Tin and then train to Hung Hom (near our hotel) Sha Tin's bus station is very close to railway station. Sai Kung is a place to go once you've been to HK a few times and looking for somewhere different.

Great day!. We caught the MRT to Mong Kok and then to Choi Hung where we got off and caught the Green Minibus (1A) to Sai Kung. We took a boat ride around the islands off Sai Kung which was a little hairy at times once we got out into the open sea. The coastline of these islands is fascinating. Lots of interesting rock formations, many caves and holes through rocks. Back on land we watched people selling fish directly from their boats at the dock. We then went to a restaurant (Hung Kee Seafood Restaurant). The food was amazing! After lunch we went for a wander through the old part of Sai Kung and checked out a small Temple (Tin Hau Temple & Hip Tin Temple – called The Temple). It was a very enjoyable day.

Unexpected in Hong Kong!. Sai Kung is an unexpected refuge from the hustle and bustle of high rise Hong Kong. However the weekends do get quite crowded so it is best to visit during the week. Stroll along the harbour front and eat dim sum or go to 'the square' and enjoy a coffee or lunch at one of the western style restaurants there. You can even hire a sampan for a trip around the small islands.

FANTASTIC !!. After much studying of TA Reviews, decided on a day trip to Sai Kung, took MTR from TST to Diamond Hill, then spent time at the attached shopping Mall, very nice with a great UniQlo store on the ground level, (great store with really great prices), then took the # 92 bus to Sai Kung. The bus terminal is attached to the MTR station, but be carefull, you have to cross several marked roadways with ped. crossings marked, but the bus and mini-bus drivers scream around at a great rate of knots, so keep a good lookout, we were almost skittled twice. The bus ride was great, we managed to get the front seats on the top deck and had a 45 minute panoramic ride all the way to Sai Kung. The route winds it way through small rural villiages and into a yacht club area / marina before reaching the end of the road, quite a scenic little trip through some of the more isolated areas of Hong Kong. Sai Kung was an amazing place, built on the edge of the sea, watched fisher people selling their live fish and seafood from the waterfront from small dories filled with live fish, quite entertaining. The seafront is lined with seafood restaurants, we chose one and had a full 5 course meal and beer for just under $500 HK, quite reasonable, and the quality of the food was very good, steamed fish, scallops fried rice. It may be a bit of a mission to get to but the bus trip was part of the fun, a really nice days outing away from the hustle and bustle of central Hong Kong. Highly recommended.

Gorgeous Hiking and a great little town to visit!. Sai Kung Country Park is a beautiful place to hike. There are beaches, islands, peaks and lingering trails. It is easy to search the internet for a hike to your liking Look into taking a speed boat out to one of the islands too. You will see the gorgeous GeoPark formations. Spectacular. The most eastern island is Tung Ping Chau. You can arrange a boat there. Snorkelling is pretty good here and there is a lovely, easy stroll of 7 kilometres around the island. There is one restaurant and it is inexpensive and okay as long as you like the Cantonese cuisine. Save your gourmet expectations for another trip! The town of Sai Kung is charming and the seafood restaurants are numerous. There is also some nice, unexpected shopping. To get to Sai Kung from Central, take the red line to North Point, switch to the purple line and head to Hang Hau. Take exit B and turn left to the bus terminus. The Green Mini Bus number 101M will take you there. The GMBs take Octopus card or correct change. The ride can be wild depending on the driver. It takes around 25 minutes depending on traffic. I suggest going in the morning to enjoy a whole day. If you love good ole American ribs or pulled pork and beer served in chilled glasses, head to Anthony's Ranch!

Seaside town. Sai Kung is a fast becoming a hot spot for weekend seaside fun and a great place to find a restaurant that would suite any taste. There are many western restaurants and local ones too, to choose from. You will also find boats here that will take you to various island beaches for the day, some as beautiful as Thailands gorgeous beaches.

the last back garden in HK. this is my favorite place in hong kong, u can find out many many of beach here, the sand are write the sea is blue and green, many hiking route and Geo park. Sai Kung Center (town) have many of restaurant and small shop, u can spend 1 day there.if u want to find out all of the place at Sai Kung, u have to stay at lase 1 month in Hong Kong, very recommend the place of relax~
Sai Kung. A very beautiful place! You an play along the beaches, enjoy a walk at the harbour, and even go golfing (take ferry). You also can view dragon boat events at the harbour.

We live here!. A great small community amongst the mega city. Friendly place with a few western bars/restaurants. No trains run here - its either bus or taxi. We have secluded beaches at hand for a minimum price starting @ $20hkd via sampan. Public pool is great! The whole place is pretty cool :)

an escape from the city!!. Love the place! The beach is almost deserted! Just a few people here and there! The place is an escape from the city! I went there for hiking and I enjoyed it, even though it was so tough!! Endless steps and the weather was so hot!! During my hike, there's this lady who had a heat stroke!! Please bring 1.5litre water to drink while hiking. There's also an area where you can do cliff jumping but to reach there is challenging. The rocks are slippery so be careful yea :)

Suburban Visit. By taking a public bus under Diamond Hill MTR station, you may reach Sai Kung Town. The entire bus trip takes around 30 - 45 mins, but it is relaxing and impressive. Sai Kung Town is famous for its seafood. Visitors can stroll around the local markets, visit the Tin Hau Temple or enjoy cuisine at both eastern and western-style restaurants. If you have time, you may join some of the local boat tours to islands nearby Sai Kung Town. It is fun and allows you to experience different lifestyles in Hong Kong.

Not far from the city by bus. Sai Kung is a small fishing village that is growing. Many ex-pats live in the area that is a short distance fromt entrance to the Country Park. Boat rentals are availalable and there are many outdoor cafes. On Sundays the Philapina singing groups fill the air with wonderful songs of worship! Highly recommend spending an afternoon and evening here on a Sunday.

So cool to visit!. A family member drove us around in his car so that we could see the New Territories. We stopped by Sai Kung. It was amazing.There are beautiful views. I wish we had more time to take a boat tour. It was impressive to see the tanks of seafood - lots of different seafood. It was interesting to see the dried seafood being sold and the little boats selling fresh seafood. Definitely recommended!

Very FUN Beach Excursion. I felt like a local, because this is what locals do. The drive on the public bus was a great way to see Hong Kong, and then the boat ride to Sai Kung was fun as well. The kids really enjoyed being at the beach, though they said the water was a bit dirty (EG saw potato chip packet in the ocean etc.).

The good surprise.... This Beach behind Hong Kong Island was à very nice expérience...Few people in the week...clean water, réal pleasure to stay on the sand...If you stay couple of days around HK, take team to visit the beachs...
A Hidden Gem. A wonderful destination away from Hong Kong but well worth a visit with a great waterfront and excellent fish restaurants. Sunday's are a must with the market etc.
Sinfully Delicious Seafood. After a walk along the harbour, we hand picked our own scallops, razor clams, clams, crab and crayfish. Finished the meal with Portuguese Egg Tarts.

Really beautifull - worth a visit!. We enjoyed our trip to Sai Kung a lot! It was not so crowded and we really liked the nice landscape and the beautifull view. I would definatelly recommend a visit in Sai Kung.

Great for Seafood Cuisine!. It's probably the most western place in Hong Kong, where there are a lot of locals who are foreigners and they know how to speak Cantonese.My mum and dad used to live here and they think it's heaven.It's great for seafood cuisine because it is freshly caught and fried straight away. be careful for scams though, they may see you as tourists and try to make you guys pay higher prices.

Great escape from the city. Great place to escape from the city crowds. Good variety of outdoor activities. Long Ke Wan and Tai Long Wan are both fantastic beaches (although in both cases you need to hike in). If you don't want to walk, Trio Beach and Sharp Island are both accessible by Sampan and offer good beaches and swimming.

Take the bus!. The double decker bus to Sai Kung is like a roller coaster ride over the island especially if you're lucky to get the front seats on the top level. Its a picturesque trip and you're rewarded at the end with a pretty sandy beach, restaurants and souvenir shops

Smells, beaches and islands. Took sampan trip out to an eating experience on Kau Sai Fishermen Village (standalone island), stopovers for swim close to other small islands. Great day sea, sun and friends.

Everyone should go..... The other side to the city life.... I hear a lot of people say that it's just a big city and people swing through for 2/3 days or so and leave. Go to the beach, enjoy the islands and everything else this wonderful country have to offer.
Nice fishing villages within unique charm. A small fishing village with unique charm. Very unique and different from rest of Hong Kong as a chill ax and relax fishing village.

Busier than before but still a nice escape from HK. I still like the place although it is much busier than few years ago. It is better to go in weekdays to avoid the very busy weekend times. Be aware of the traffic during the weekends.

a different kind of crowd. Sai Kung is a bustling fishing village in the New Territories and its charm lies in its authenticity. Fishing boats, fisherman selling their catch freshly killed for you, vendors selling all kinds of dried fish etc.Lots of expats live in this area and you can understand why. Where I was staying ( in a private home) we saw 50-60 cows meandering alongside the road every day. There is the beautiful view along the coastline and the oxygen rich vegetation which attracts a lot of hikers and walkers to the area.Overall, a little piece of Asia which still moves at its own gentle pace.

Beautiful beaches that can rival any other beach resort in Asia. Simply stunning and totally worth the trek to reach this beach. We hiked to the beach using route 2 (which is actually quite a work out) and took a boat ride out, such a great experience and I'm shocked that I'm only discovering this side of Hong Kong after having been here more than a dozen times.

A variety of activities. The only problem with Sai Kung is have to take a bus there. So far in my opinion, the fastest and most efficient way of coming from town is to take MTR to Choi Hung Stop, then change to the mini green bus. The ride on the mini green bus is an experience. Really fast in my opinion. Strolling by the waters is quite an experience. Can see the locals selling their catches from their boats. Had the chance to explore the area a little bit more. Interesting to observe how they locals go about their daily lives. There are also shops where you can do some shopping. There are also some pretty hip cafes and shops in the area.We booked a boat to tour the islands for an hour in the evening. Cost us about HKD300. I believe with some further bargaining, can go a bit cheaper. Nevertheless, was a nice relaxing ride.To end off the day, we went to the Hung Seafood. For HKD488, menu for 2, we shared the food among 2 adults and 1 child. Can choose up to 4 seafood dishes and will get a complimentary fried vegetables. We only chose 3 seafood dishes including steam abalone, bamboo clams and steamed scallops. We had char Siew with BBQ pork as our fourth dish. With the vegetables and we ordered rice, we had a fulfilling dinner. Had enjoyed Sai Kung. Will go back again.
Island hopping.... Love to hike????joined me in this lamma adventures with a great experienced...mountains,trees,rare species u can seen too...and a quiet clean beach a far...

OK if you have not been to Lantau, Cheung Chau, Lamma or Peng Chau Islands. OK but might be overrated. .... Better off going to Stanley Village Beach and Hairpin Beach then Shek O beach.Lamma, Lantau, Peng Chau , Chung Chau Islands are better boat ride alternatives and cheaper and faster to get to

Fun place after a hike. We visited Saikung after getting a speedboat from Sai Wan beach after our hike. It is just a beautiful place to stroll around and grab a beer or glass of wine before heading home. Getting there is easy, get the green line to Choi Hung and then the 1A mini bus or if you are coming from Central it is faster to go to Hang Hau (Island line and change at North point). Then the 101M mini bus. It can be crowded with visitors at weekends so our advice is to go mid week and head to the beaches and mountains. Lovely!

This is the suburb of HK. I specifically like the British Ex-pats who live here as they try to create a little bit of the London they may miss.We were far from crowds and close to nature. I really enjoyed the time here and found it refreshing. If you like nature then I recommend visiting here.
What a location. Sai Kung is fishing village, Seafood restaurants right on the water.Fresh seafood to eat in or you can purchase to take away. Good sandy are for walk in a nice day.

Good Day Trip Out. It's easy to get to Sai Kung by MTR and bus. Take the Green Line East to Choi Hung. From there, take green bus A11 all the way to the last stop which is Sai Kung. The journey from TST to Sai Kung was a very pleasant one hour on a sunny Friday morning. Our aim was to try the fresh seafood from Loaf On, a 1 Michelin Star restaurant. Unfortunately we had a really hard time locating the restaurant as we were looking for a huge place with lots of tables and chairs by the seafront.We walked the length of the seafront and still could not find it despite asking 3 different people. In the end, we settled for lunch at Chuen Kee Seafood Restaurant which had two very visible restaurant fronts. It was not a bad choice and we enjoyed our meal very much. Our stomachs filled, we continued our search for Loaf On and in the process stumbled upon a very interesting arts shop selling wooden carvings of animals.The shop owner gave us clear instructions on how to find Loaf On and we finally found it ! At the Sai Kung arch, turn right then left into the first alley. It is a discreet little air-conditioned place on the right. There are NO tables or chairs in the front. We made a mental note to try their food the next time. Take the A11 bus back to Choi Hung station. Facing the road, turn right of the bus stop and take a short walk to the underpass leading back to Choi Hung station. There are no signs, so do ask the locals if you are lost.

A Good Day Out. Sai Kung offers quite a lot of attractions for visitors. In summer it is busy with beach goers. There's a mariner and has great opportunites for boat trips to nearby islands and it also houses a public golf course with great views. Relatively easy to reach, it can serve as a welcome relief from the hectic city lifestyle of urban Hong Kong.
Fantastic dinner. We took a taxi out to Sai Kung for dinner. We enjoyed the freshest seafood. You get to pick the seafood you want to eat; crab, prawns, scallops, and so much more!
One of the best beaches in HongKong. I think, you are in HongKong you should plan a visit to that beach esoecially during moon night at night

An Exortic Lovely Check Point . Had a night boat trip for the squid fishing at Sai Kung.That is one of the best place to experience the ancient Hong Kong style crossing the East and West culture!Suggested to go at late afternoon in Summer Time and better in weekdays (to avoid overloading of tourists in weekend)The streets at Sai Kung are relatively narrower so be patients if the dog carrier share the same road with you :) but the animals are generally happy in Sai Kung :)There are loads of sea food restaurants along the side of the ferry pier.And plenty of multinational pubs/bars/restaurants at the side roads.Plus the local Hong Kong foodie around the mini buses/taxi stations (just next to the ferry pier),so your stomach won’t be loney!:)There are plenty ways to access to Sai Kung and here are 2 suggestions: A) Take underground to CHOI HUNG MTR STATION (Kwun Tong Line,green line) and head to exit C go up to the first slope of youe right hand side,there are minibus (green colour) towards Sai Kung Ferry Pier (City Centre).But bear in mind that most of the drivers not able to speaks English plus always long queue thereB) Take underground to DIAMOND HILL MTR STATION (Kwun Tong Line,green color) and head to exit C,turn left and there is a central bus station there.Pick the route 92 and its final destination is Sai Kung Ferry Pier.Estimated bus journey is one hour.Do have fun and stop over at Sai Kung!

Great access to fantastic beaches!. We only if a day trip to Sai Kung. I found getting there a little confusing, but thankfully we were with locals who made it easy for us. Once there, there are some nice cheap and expensive shops (if that's what you are into), delicious restaurants and places to eat, as well as the sea front, where you can take a boat out to surrounding islands.Remember to haggle! Never accept the first offer. We wanted to do a junk boat trip, and the weather was ideal for this! It's too bad we didn't pack swimmers, otherwise we'd have headed to an island and made a day of it. A great destination for your visit to HK.

Fishing town. One of my favorite places in Hong Kong. A fishing town with a nice harbor, where fishermen sell their fish right from the boat, nice walks along the bay, some good restaurants and a more "local" and relaxed feel than the expat dominated areas.

Best beach in hong kong. I've been to many of the beaches in hong kong and Sai Wan is by far the cleanest. The view is unlike any you can find on these islands. There was quite a hike leading to this beach. About a two hour walk was required due to multiple landslides that have caused the road to be blocked to all vehicles. Be sure to bring plenty of water and possibly gear to spend the night on the beach. There are a few small shops that rent over night gear, however I didn't spend the night. The beach is secluded which meant there weren't many people on the beach. We took the boat back to Sai Kung at 7pm which was ideal for the sunset. It was the most beautiful sunset cruise I have ever been on. I will upload more pictures once I get them off of my camera. This was one of my favorite experiences in hong kong!

Boy it is nice over there!. Greattt beaches, doesn't look it belongs to HK at all. You will need a hole day to be there- it is worth it! Chose a sunny day!You can get there by any kind of transportation, also boats and terrestrial.

Charming and wonderful. Sai Kung offers a different face to the perception of HK. It is rural, quaint and extremely peaceful. Surrounded by many islands the landscape is beautiful and the sunsets are memorable. The pace is slower and offers a respite from the hustle bustle of the city. The surrounding areas have a verdant display of lush foliage and hills and supply candy for the eyes and food for the soul. I LOVE Sai Kung.

Seafood, beaches, fishing village. There are several buses that take you to Sai Kung. Diamond hill MTR station ( bus 92) or bus 99 from the Ma On Shan station. The promenade has several seafood restaurants, most with a set menu dependent on the number of guests. Set menus are fine and they contain some choice but you are better off choosing what you would like from the tanks then selecting which way you want it cooked. Be sure to always confirm the price ahead of time as fish, crab, lobster are all by weight and the price can be extreme if you are not careful. Sai Kung also has a place for beer and wine, named the bottle shop which has an excellent selection. You'll see many expats at numerous English/Irish pubs in town. There are two bars named 'Casa' which have reasonably priced beer and wine and have nice Tapa dishes as well. Along the peer you can negotiate a price for hiring a boat for either taking a cruise around the islands, snorkelling/diving or taking you some of the island seafood restaurants. Boat trips are surprisingly reasonable. Stroll along the piers as well to see the fishermen selling their catch and be amazed at how many photographers are there trying to photograph the birds that hover above the harbour.

Lovely resort. Lovely beach resort. Plenty of seafood restaurants to choose from and a nice promenade to walk along the beach. You can do boat trips to other local islands or buy freshly caught fish/seafood from the pier. Further inland, the local town is full of little shops and eateries at very cheap prices. There is also a good pub (the Duke of York) that serves good beers and has a wide selection of alcoholic breakages, a pool table and darts.It's a good place to spend a day.

Out of the way, the best seafood,and well worth the trip. Tired of the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong? Want great seafood. Go to Sai Kung. The town is located in the New Territories and getting there can be a combined with 2 small but very good attractions, The Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Gardens. Take the MTR Red line from central to Mong Kok and change to the Green line getting off at Diamond Hill. At Diamond Hill you can visit the Nunnery and Garden which are across the street and easily accessible. From Diamond Hill terminal board the 92 bus for the trip to Sai Kung. In Sai Kung walk along the waterfront walk and enjoy one of the restaurants there... you won't regret it. The sea Food is as fresh as it gets, you choose it from the tanks yourself!! then take a boat ride around the islands , swim in the sea.

Best beach in HK but be careful swimming end may to july re potential tigersharks in the area. Nice to go here by Chinese junk and eat on the boat then jump into the sea and swim to the beach but beware of tiger sharks

Nice waterfront walk. One way to enjoy Hong Kong in a relaxing way -whether you are planning to try local seafood cuisine (they cook whatever you picked from the seafood stall), strolling along the waterfront, shopping from some speciality stores or looking for yummy desserts, Sai Kung is great place to explore for the whole family.

A great place to visit. Is a very different side of Hong Kong. The place is nice to visit, I was very surprised as I had not expected Hong Kong to have this side also. Nice. I took the public bus and the ride is nice too. When you arrive you almost feel you have left Hong Kong. Nice promenade, live fish boats selling fish. Seafood restaurants? more than enough, not all with english menu.

Floating seafood market. Took a mini bus from choi hong mtr, about half an hours ride. There were a lot of people during the public holiday, try to go in the morning. Nice place to stroll and looking at the floating market. Saw a boat that has a mountain of sea urchin and Bought some sea urchin to taste. Great! Had lunch at one of the restaurant. The bamboo clams were so fresh! Thumbs up for the seafood.

Great day in real HK!. Sai Kung is a village of its own. If you only go here for the seafood restaurants that's fine, but there is a also a really nice village to stroll and a nice beach front promenade as well as watching the local fishermans selling their catch by the piers. Well worth a visit.Getting there: take the MTR to Hang Hau. In the shopping center there is a public buss transport hub. Take 101 or 101M to Sai Kung end station, and you arrive in the midst of this village.

Sai Kung is a fishing district with piers to walk along and see the boats etc.. We visited Sai Kung several times to take the boat ride to Yim Tin Tsai - YTT is a Catholic village with St Joseph's Church set on the hillside. The village was owned by the CHAN families for over 300 years and has been awarded a UNESCO award for the salt field now being rejuvenated. There is a museum and the old Ching Po School to look around.
Our digs. We stayed at Sai Kung for our week in Hong Kong, lots of wonderful shops and waterfront wet market. Very busy place.

Sai Kung. Getting out of Hong Kong and visiting a place like Sai Kung separates one from the multitude of visitors who are stuck in the traditional tourist venues. NO! Hong Kong is not bad. I love Hong Kong. But to go places like Sai Kung just expands your horizons.

good day out. Sai Kung is worth the trip. MTR to Hang Hau and then Green Minibus 101. Less than an hour from Central.Early is better if you go on a weekend as it gets very busy, especially on a Sunday.Walk along the harbourfront and check out the live seafood. We ate at one of the big restaurants. We ordered a la carte but it may have been better to order the set menu. It was challenging ordering the seafood as you have to go to a different place and choose and you aren't clear on what it's going to cost.There's an interesting street behind the waterfront with coffee shops etc and there is a large market as well, with seafood downstairs and fresh food upstairs.If you walk along the waterfront away from the restaurants, you come to a nice beach. Nice scenery.

My favourite place in HK. What more do you need?!! Beaches, seafood, hikes in the hills and rivers. There is something for everyone here and it has a great relaxed vibe. There is some quaint little ale shops where you can just sit outside and watch the world go by and you can easily hop on a water taxi and relax at Tai Long Wan! Go!

Nice scenery and seafood. Sai Kung is another place that one can go to for a respite from the hustle and bustle of the city. Take bus 92 from Diamond Hill station and you will get very close to the house of Brigitte Lin Ching Hsia on the way. At Sai Kung Promenade you can watch housewives buying seafood from fishmongers plying their wares from boats docked right beside the Promenade.

Buy from boat only. You will get ripped off for sure if you buy else where. the cheapest is the from the boat. You save 40 to 50% off. Geoduck boat is 300. Store 500 to 800hkd. Cuttle fish boat 320. Store 600 to 900. Rock cod 2 kg. 280 boat. Store 600. But there are some items in store that boat wont jave. Crabs. Spotted prawns. Dont buy the set menu they offer you. You get smaller and frozen seafood. Buy fresh and for yourself.

It's nice to go to Sai Kung once in a while. It's nice to go to Sai Kung once in a while. Because, as a local, Sai Kung has some shops which you can't find easily in the city (e.g. there is a bakery selling European bread and smoke ham.)

Spend a relaxing afternoon at Sai Kung . A lot of seafood and Thai foods coffee shops around the place. You can walk along with good friends and your pets. Very relaxing place, view is good. Also many kind of seafood to choose from. Some new and unique shops around that location. Worth the visit.
Lovely seaside resort. Great day at Sai Kung, wandering the town and coastline. Lots of seafood dining options. Interesting vintage shops.

Kayak Open Sea. We were supposed to kayak to Geo Park but as the wind was strong and weather extremely cold and only 4 of us hence the plan was change to island hopping instead.It was still great experience kayaking in an open sea with the rush to beat against oncoming fast boats! It was relaxing and calming kayaking in open sea and enjoying nature with my family!
Beautiful fishing village. We came here one night for an all sea food dinner and a couple of days later for the Sai Kung peninsula hike, which was a really great experience!

Fishing Village.. We caught the ferry to Sai Kung,not amazing but an interesting look back in time,seafood is good here and the locals helped us choose Dim Sum ,we probably enjoyed this interaction more than the trip itself.

A different side to Hong Kong. Stayed with friends and in all honesty would have been unlikely to have gone. It is a bit of a trek from central HK. A combination of MTR and bus or taxi. A decent selection of restaurants and pubs - lots are geared to expats. Its a good place to grab a boat to one of the many beaches and fun to people watch the locals taking a break at the weekend. Beyond that nothing special for tourists. That said good to see another side to Hong Kong.

The place for seafood in HongKong. Great district for amazing seafood. Our local friend drove us up and introduced 2 great restaurants here. There were many large restaurants lined up along the way. He also said that both these places are one star restaurants. Looking at the location being beside the coast, the breeze were also nice after our meal. Overall had a nice relaxing dinner.

Old Fishing Village being spoiled by Development. Sai Kung used to be one of the hidden gems of Hong Kong but sadly not any more. The recent developments in the vicinity and the incessant tour buses have made it uncomfortably crowded - especially at weekends. There are only two roads in and out of the town and the traffic congestion is often horrendous.There are still charming walks in the Old Town and along the seafront and the seafood restaurants are famous, if expensive. Too many of the small shops have had to close because of unreasonable rent increases however.If you visit midweek it is still possible to experience some of Sai Kung's charms but if you go at the weekend or on a public holiday, be prepared for long queues for public transport and restaurants.

Worth the trek. Gorgeous beach. DO NOT GO in the summer months. Spring / Autumn is best. Otherwise it's just stifling there. A few little shops / restaurant dot the beaches so even though it feels remote there are facilities. Including bathrooms.

Good family break from urban Hong Kong. Was taken to this place by local friend. It is located near Clearwater Bay. It is fishing village with a few piers. Lots of boats and fisherman. Lots of restaurants and shops along the beachfront. Nice place for a walk as during weekends see the locals and expatriates walk their dogs and buy seafood directly from fisherman.

A nice to stroll around but seafood is expensive here!. This is a little estate some distance from the 'city' hustle and bustle in Central and Tsim Sha Tsui, sporting a coastal village vibe. There are several ferry connections here to various smaller offshore islands (I did not check the destinations these ferries served), and of course, tonnes of seafood restaurants hawking fresh seafood, though with a relatively hefty price tag. My companion and I did have a meal there - I thought it was only barely value for money.After lunch, it was nice to stroll around the pier and the little shops to walk off the lunch. If you have an afternoon to spare in your itinerary, this could be a place to go, but if you are stretched for time, give this place a miss.

Sai kung pier is the best to get fresh seafood and snacks. This place is where u go to for boat trips around the island. You can have fresh seafood straight from the fishermen. It is a place where local hongkong people go to. The cuttlefish snack is simply too awesome. 3 packets for hkd$25. Everytime when i visit hongkong, i will go to this place for the seafood. Very reasonable price. Highly recommend.

Beautiful place!. Easily accessible by MTR then minibus (9HKD) then taxi (100HKD). Going back, it's a rough boat ride (150HKD, only cash) for about 30 minutes, then minibus, then MTR. It's a nice, quite easy hike and the beaches are beautiful. I'd definitely go back!

A place to relax. Our friend took us for a day trip, from the city concrete jungle to some place more relax; Sai Kung was one of the places. This was a former a fishing village, but if you want sea food, this is still the place to be. You can buy dried seafood or live fish from the fishermen at the pier. I bought some dried shrimp and it was a reasonable price. There was a nice stroll at the Waterfront Promenade and they have boat tour to take you out to National Geopark. Too bad on the afternoon we visited it was cloudy and hazy; otherwise I will hop on a boat to take a tour myself. My friend took us to a street that has lots of restaurants, lots of choices for a good lunch.Happy Travelling!

Something completely different. We loved Sai Kung but have only ever been with a local (it might be a little tricker to negotiate your way around on your own). The fish restaurants are incredible to see (and the quality is a hundred times better than on Lamma Island in our opinion). Not the easiest to get to (we did train then taxi), but to get there as night falls is really lovely. We will definitely go back, and do a bit of hiking next time too.

Different Taste of Hong Kong - Less Crowd & Fresh Air. Worth a visit to Sai Kung even a bit far away from city center. Hong Kong was a small fishing village before its transformation to become an international financial center. During the visit, I saw some traditional architecture, like Tin Han temple & old village; and found many local fishermen still selling fresh seafood on the boat. In town center, there are also many eating places, including Cantonese seafood and western cozy restaurants. I find this place very interesting. I also enjoyed a nice walk along the waterfront and shopped some organic food at the weekend market. Unfortunately, the weather was too foggy. I couldn't enjoy the water front view and take good pictures.

Amongst the best beaches in town. Nice beaches, fine sand and a sufficiently hard access so that they are not crowded (don't tell you friends...:-) ). The best is hiking to Sai Kung and ending up on the beach. Nice reward.

Another time another town.. Catch a bus to Sai Kung .no trains as yet ,well worth the effort an interesting old town plenty to see nice town centre plenty of eating houses .or take a walk down the water front ,amazing,

Delighted place to visit on a nice day!. During my visit to Hong Kong, forecast was rain for most of the time. On the day we wanted to visit Sai Kung, the weather changed to cloudy blue skies so we took the KMB bus there and had a blast taking pictures and walking around the piers. I would want to rent one of those boat rides to remote islands again. I even saw a old timer movie star and singer, Teddy Robin. While having dessert!

Intresting. Lovely place to look round. you have the old and new part. Lots of placed to eat. a couple of placed you can choose your fish, so you know its fresh. Walking along the key is an experience you don't want to miss.

The other side of HK . Situated in the biggest country park in HK, Sai Kung consist of a bunch of villages in a large country park setting with the best hiking trails and beaches that gives visitors another perspective of HK.Sai Kung itself started its life as a small fishing village which today offers an alternate with its waterfront, cafes and seafood restaurants.

Nice, peaceful fishing village.. Many places to eat seafood. Quiet fishing village. Easy to get bus here. Plenty of shops cafes, to kill a few hours. Pleasant area to walk around and explore for a few hours. Easy to get boat trip for afternoon, plenty of locals trying to sell tickets.

Not for tourists. I live only 15 minutes from Sai Kung town and enjoy it so my ranking has nothing to do with Sai Kung from a locals perspective but is relevant for a tourist. HK is renowned as an ultra urban city filled with people, shops and restaurants. Sai Kung is very different and the town itself has had no preperation for international tourists. It will take you around an hour to get there from Central and involve the MTR and then buses or taxis and most would be disappointed. Yes I like the quaint older and untarnished style of town but it is not that quaint to be attractive to a tourist. It is a kick off point for junks for a day in the sun but these are also available closer to Central and TST.

A little bit of peace!. HK and Kowloon are very busy almost all of the time, which is an expected part of the visit, but take a trip to Sai Kung, a peaceful fishing village with stunning island views, boat trips and local fishermen. Well worth a visit.
Great place - over expensive food. Well worth the visit if you like hiking. Good to get away from the city for a day trip. The restaurants we found all very overpriced.

Many trips to Sai Kung. Most people have this image of Hong Kong of skyscrapers and crowds. To see all of HK, you must go see Sai Kung. It is a fishing village/town. You can get a leisurely 1 hour private boat ride on a lsmall junk from the local fisherwomen for about 250 HKD for a family. You can see the geological rock formations and other small islands. Come back and enjoy dim sum and seafood. It's a bit touristy. Or come early and make your way for a 3-4 hour hike on the gorgeous MacLehose trail section 2 (google it).

Three nights free camping over Chinese New Year. We took a trip to Hong Kong for our Chinese New Year break from the school that we work in and hoping not to break the bank spent three nights hiking and camping around Sai Kung. If you are into outdoor trips like this then we highly reccomend walking section 2 of the Maclehose trail and camping on the beaches as you go! The hike is challenging in places but insanely beautiful and the beaches were secluded with very few other people despite it being public holiday time. There are great food and drink options available on Ham Tin beach and also Sai Wan beach, but nothing except a drinking water tap on Long Ke, so if you do camp there then take enough food with you for that night and the next day too. If I were to do it again I would take a taxi to the second reservoir at the end of section one, hike and camp on Long Ke the first night, Sai Wan the second and then Ham Tin on the third. Or with just two nights hike from Long Ke to Ham Tin in one day and finish the trip there with the best food on the trail. Can't beleive the camping was totally free! Love love love Hong Kong

a hidden gem - go and check it out. not too many people seem to know about it. but if you're in Hongkong and want to see something different, try Sai Kung. It's a lovely place. you can go out on a junk boat or dine in one of the many restaurants. a great little town. parking's a bit of an issue on weekends and as there's only one road in/out there are traffic jams a plenty on weekends. old-town is definitely nice to walk through and plenty of little shops to be checked out.

Great day out to escape from the busy city. There are plenty of day tours offer day tour around the island including hexagonal column rocks which are amzing to see. This is one of interesting site to see in hongkong, good for a weekend hiking.The seafood there,however,is not as good as expected.The restaurants just get commercial so the food is not so authentic.

Family Day. This is a GREAT way to spend the day!!! We took an uber out there. Once there you can grab some snacks and drinks. We had to buy a plastic box to act as a cooler. Then head down to the marina and rent a junk boat. I think it cost us around $100 USD. The boat took us out to a private island where we spent several hours just hanging out. On our return we went to one of the many seafood restaurants, chose an incredible looking lobster, and they cooked it up for us. IT WAS AMAZING. This was a highlight of our HK trip. I hope you enjoy as well.

Awsome Experience. Clear waters...nice windy beach...Don't have any restaurant on the beach...absolutely secluded place...so one can enjoy book reading or take sun bath..Get down at Choi Hung MTR .. take the exit C2...catch the green bus 1A..charges around 8.2 hkd, 25 min journey. ..after reaching the promenade hire the boat to go to the beach. Charges around 60 HKD for to and fro including sightseeing for the nearby areas.

Nice but it's not like in the movies to have seafood freshly bought and cooked by the promenade.. Good for a 2D 1N trip to explore the area. Some geological treks nearby. Food wise, Sai Kung is as commercialized as any other area. Nothing special in what's being offered. Not the experience you see in the movies where you can buy seafood off the boats and bring it to the restaurants to be cooked.

Great day trip. If you're looking for an easy day trip away from the hustle and bustle of the city then I definitely recommend visiting Sai Kung.It is not reachable directly by MTR and you have to get a minibus from the nearest MTR station but in true Hong Kong fashion, they are frequent and efficient.Once there, Sai Kung is perfect for a stroll along the promenade, watching the fishermen bring in fresh seafood. You can then pop into town where you'll see many Gweilos who have made this place their home, visit the Tin Hau temple and then wander back down to the promenade to enjoy a fresh seafood dinner served by one of the many Chinese restaurants.

Great sea food experience away from city. Love this place, away from the hectic city, Sai Kung offers good seafood. If you're a kind of adventurous type, you could ride boats do your fishing and eating as well. Worth going.
Small town Hong Kong. This place is the real deal. Great fish restaurants, shops, beaches. A great seawalk with an active waterfront.

Disappointment. We have read good things about this place especially the freshest seafood. So we hired a car and headed to Sai Kung. It was just an okay place. The restaurants are over-hyped and certainly over-priced. The sea front has a unpleasant smell. And there were small boats offering an excursion which we declined. Maybe next time, we explore the dormant volcanoes in the nearby islands. Overall, not much to do here except eat sea food.

Expat enclave. This is an international community (well, maybe mostly UK) , yet still very local HK. Laid-back but plenty of interesting shops and cafes. The MTR does not run there, so it's notthe most straightforward day trip out of central Hong Kong, but buses are fine, and it's worth the effort if you can spend a few hours. The waterfront is picturesque even if a bit frayedaround the edges - it's full of character. This is where you go to choose your livefish from the tank for your dinner. Great walking neighbourhood in any weather.The adventurous and athletic can find great hiking trails close by while the morerelaxed members of your group can hang out in the cafes.

Great getaway from the HK hustle and bustle. Sai Kung was one of the unexpected highlights of my trip to HK. While it is a little distance from central it is definitely worth the trip. Make sure you watch all the fishing boats come in with there catch and sell the food on the docks. Then enjoy dinner at one of the man seafood restaurants where you choose from the amazing live selection! Dinner time can be busy!

Sai kung. We love seeing all the fresh seafood in the large tanks at all the resturant. You can also see the fishermen with their live catch at the end of the pier. You can also hire a local boat for a ride.

Lovely place for family weekend getaway. We took a mini bus there and the charges vwas very reasonable, I was very impressed with the way the fishermen sold their catch at the jetty. We had our dinner at one of popular restaurant,whereby we chose our favourite live seafood stored in the tank and we requested to cook according to our liking..The evening sight was amazing,and we notice some families walk their dogs there. It was a great place for families getaway.

A Nice Village !. Sai Kung is one of the village popular for their fresh seafood. I often here mainly to have a nice fresh seafood. The enviroment is nice and quiet. Many expat live here too. During the winter I often here for a hiking. For those planning to visit Hong Kong, do pay a visit in Sai Kung, it's worth your time.

Great place for hikes. Lots of trails in this area if you are a hiker. slightly off the beaten path. you can also take kaitos (water taxis) to get to more out of the way places. some camp sites available.
Lovely . I really like this place - its very pretty nice beaches, shops to explore and its very dog friendly too ! Have finding the interesting street names and take a few photos !

Great half day activities. Sai Kung is the back yard of Hong Kong which offer great scenery and seafood. It is accessible by taking the MTR and then connect with minibus or taxi. The seafood at the pier are very fresh and price affordable, a local weekend favourite.

Excellent Place to get away from the Hustle and Bustle. Sai Kung had a nice variety of restaurants and coffee houses. We visited an island off Sai Kung with a lot of abandoned houses, the island used to have salt farms, but is now mostly visited by tourists. Beautiful and peaceful.

Sea side escape. Take the MTR to Choi Hung and then mini bus 1A staight to Sai Kung and have a great day away from HK. Lots to see, interesting mix of traditional shopping and more westernised restaurants.Starbucks and Mc Donalds there if you need it. Take time to explore the little streets and alley ways. Some great coffee bars opening up too. You can take a sampan trip out to one of the islands and swim if it is warm enough. Lots of geographical attractions close by too. One of my favourite places to spend a day .

Super place and base. Sai Kung is thriving and busy place but a few notches of intensity down from HK yet easily reached from HK Central MTR to Diamond Hill MTR / bus terminus No 92 takes 30mins. I liked the feeling it was away from it and is clearly the threshold for the wonderful Sai Kung peninsula and country parks and the World Geo Park. Seek out the Geo Park Visitor Centre at the Bus Station and the Visitor Boards on the Promenade.
Its not hong kong. You feel like your not in hong kong. Its small fisher village. There are alot of small seafood restaurants. Its pretty good

Fresh air!. I almost come here every weekend because I play golf here. There are many islands you can hop around by boat, including my golf course.
I haven't been every island yet but I'm ticking the list and getting there!;)

A hidden gem of HK. SAI KUNG - to far to get to, nothing to do - wrong! This is the best kept secret of HK!. Yes you have to navigate both the MTR of HK and a bus - but once you have done that you are in for a surprise! It is an oasis away from the hussle and bussle of HK central. It is a real neighbourhood, a small town within the HK SAR. Taste the seafood - buy fresh from the fishermen tied to the local fish piers; go for a boat trip around the bay. The water is clear here unlike HK harbour! There are many seafood restaurants in the area, you never have to wlak far! And if that is not enough, the hiking and remoteness of the local hills are just around the corner!

Lots of Seafood Restaurant at Sai Kung. Sai Kung is a place that you mush visit when you are in Hong Kong. lots of western and asian seafood place for your to enjoy and have a stroll along the harbourside walk.
Must do activity for a sunny day.. Great choices of seafood, private cruises and restaurants. There are flea markets and pets carnival over the weekend.
Sai Kung. Went to Sai Kung again in November with my friend. This time we had our lunch at Chuen Kee the set menu of HKD 498 consisting a dish of prawns which is not fresh.

Worth the trip out from HK. I was in Hong King for business. We snuck out for a day to visit Sai Kung. It was great to see the open waters, eat great seafood and just hang out. We mostly went for the food but it was nice to see the locals doing their thing and just unwind. The local fishermen have a little street near the bus terminal (circle) where they set up shop on the docks. It took us roughly 1hr from Hong Kong (if I'm not mistaken). Take a look at my Chuen Kee Seafood Restaurant review for a good seafood restaurant. All in all, it was a great escape from HK. Well worth the trip.

Remote but worth to visit place. You can enjoy hiking and watersport in this place. Not over-crowded and not many mainlanders. Country Park is just surrounding the town centre. Enjoy the food there! If visit there during weekend, make sure you leave earlier or you are prepare to stay until very late since the traffic jam is quite troublesome around 17:00-21:00.

Worth the trip. While somewhat out of the way, Sai Kung is district which must be seen. Situated in a typhoon shelter (bay), the back to the '70's look is so NOT HK in 2015 but the seafood is a delight. Lots to see and do. Just wander around and take yourself back in time!

The alternative side to Hong Kong. I have lived here for 3 years. Sai Kung is a lovely place to come and visit as a tourist, particularly if you love to hike. However, try and avoid weekends- as with everywhere in HK is can be awful due to huge crowds. It is about 40 mins from central HK and has a small town full of restaurants and a sea front full of little boats that you can hire to see the coastline or be taken to a little island. From SK you can travel further on into the country park to hike.
So many places to hike. Every time we come to Hong Kong, we go over to Sai Kung to hike a new part. Wonderful place, great beaches, very peaceful

Perfect Hiking Base. Easy to get to by bus and once there, there are many buses going to other places. Although the schedule to some places can be somewhat sporadic ( so check times first)If you like hiking this is a good place to stop at to stock up on supplies.There are several good eating places in the town if you are not wanting to go hiking, but I prefer to buy food for a picnic and get off the beaten track and go hiking.

Village turned Touristic. This ancient fishing village is now very touristic but not in the foreign sense...meaning that it is touristic for locals. There are good seafood restaurants at reasonable prices.
Best beach in Hong Kong. If you arrive in Tai Long Wan beach, you will feel you are in Philippines and no more in Hong Kong. Great place for camping and hiking.

A cute beach town with great restaurants. We've been twice. The first time, to walk Stage 6 of the MacLehose trail to Sai Wan beach, which is gorgeous. The second time, with our host, to eat lunch at Big Fish. Great food. I had black cod, my husband had seafood jambalaya, and our host had crayfish risotto.
Yummy Foodie place. I first visited Sai Kung in 2007 and I came back again this year. If you love seafood prepared Hong Kong style, try it!

Amazing Beaches. The place was very nice..when you arrive the place with empty stomach there's plenty of restaurant that offers fresh seafoods..if you are into hiking adventure you may try coz I tried and its very exciting. The trio beach was so amazing you cant imagine there's a wonderful place and very peaceful close to nature.if you want to do campfire and set your tent in the bench it will be a nice thing to do before going back to hiking the next day. And by the way there's also boat that goes directly to the trio beach from the pier of Sai kung.

Away from all the traffic. Sai Kung is used to be a getaway place for HK people. They used to spent their vacation or a day off at Sai Kung. There weren't that many buildings or shops. But nowadays, it's a blooming cosy city full with seafood restaurants! Do try one of those!

Said Kung escape from the city. Sai kung, lovely area away from the city, there is also a boat you can get to trio beach which it lovely. There are plenty of restaurants and a really nice walk around the harbour. There is also quite a big play area for the children.

Best beach and area around Hong Kong. From everything in and around HK, Sai Kung is absolutely the best and worth visiting. Of course if you are visiting HK for 3-4 days, maybe u are not interested, unless u like outdoor activities and a nice beach. It'll take a whole day. I love it.
Seafood. I like to go Sai Kung every time when I visited Hong Kong because we can buy fresh seafood and hide the restaurant to cook it. It is very wonderful.

A world apart from the bustle of downtown Hong Kong. This town seems a world away from the built up opulence and crowded rat race of downtown Hong Kong and Kowloon. It was easily accessible by MTR plus bus or minibus (the MTR App recommends MiniBus 1A from Choi Hung; the Sai Kung website suggests an alternate approach from Hang Hau if you're on Hong Kong Island; you can also arrive by ferry). Some of the rundown buildings suggest a less developed environment that you might see in rural China or the Middle East. The harbor is full of fishing boats, dive boats, yachts, and ferries of various sizes and shapes. There are countless seafood restaurants along the waterfront with numerous plastic tanks full of creeping and swimming creatures. Had lunch at one of the local restaurants, followed by a cruise around Kiu Tsui Chau / Sharp Island with Kitty's Tours. The cruise was a bit disconcerting, as 12 passengers, the boat driver, and the cruise director were crammed into a small dinghy without life jackets in sight. There was no safety briefing, and the narrations about some coral or sea life and some rock formations were all in Cantonese. After circumnavigating Sharp Island, you're dropped off at the main pier on the Island with the option to return on one of the twice hourly ferries. There's a smaller second island connected to Sharp's Island via a rock and sand corridor that's submerged at low tide; a short hike up to the top of the hill provides great views of the bay of Port Shelter, the town of Sai Kung, the nearby shoreline, numerous islands further out in Clearwater Bay. I think there's a beach on this secondary island as well. It's all very quiet and tranquil, with strange pineapple and other volcanic rocks and a few shells and aquatic creatures in the tide pools. There's a swimming beach with lifeguards and a confined area with netting in the water. The return ride on the ferry was better, on a larger wooden boat with lots of life jackets clearly visible. I can see why the locals would come here to get away from the breakneck pace of city life, hang out on the beaches on one of the islands accessible by charter boat, or sit on the waterfront and eat fresh seafood. Fresh seafood was available for sale off some of the small fishing boats. Of note, some of the kaido ferry boats for hire don't look like they would pass muster with the US Coast Guard. Many of the signs of the ticket booths along the waterfront are in Chinese, although some of the shore agents are adept at pitching in English. But, it's not easy to figure out which particular boat is being chartered, so ... buyer beware. Reassuringly, there were several harbor patrol police boats plying the waters (leaving big wakes behind).

My most favourite place!. Sai Kung is an enchanting village with a strong community feel. There are several ex pats living close to Sai Kung, who join the locals for shopping and outside entertaining in the main square. The are several super restaurants and coffe shops, and fantastic fish restaurants, especially on the quay side. The old quarter of Sai Kung is littered with amazing little shops, from delis to boutiques.

You must do a boat trip around the islands!. Really enjoyed a day out to Sai Kung. I was visiting friends in Discovery Bay and they took me out for the day. We hired a boat - I believe they call it a San Pan and chugged around the islands. It is truly beautiful and so relaxing...especially in the heat! Loads of restaurants and if you like fish it is defiantly the place to go.

Sai kUng is too cool for hiking and food. From the airport we took the Airbus at the Airport Ground Transportation Center. Buses are the cheapest way to get to and from Hong Kong International Airport, and the "A" routes are the most comfortable among all airport bus routes. The Airbus A41P plies between the airport and Ma On Shan. The route is serviced by double-decked buses with air-conditioning. The luggage racks allow to store your luggage while you enjoy a bus ride. The bus stop (Ground Transportation Centre) is situated outside the Arrival Hall on the right side. So, to take a bus from the airport you need to get out of the Arrival Hall and turn right. Follow the direction signs. At Ravana Garden we stepped out and switched to the 299X bus. Within 1 ½ hours from the airport, we were in Sai Kung. It is difficult to find accommodation in this town. There are no hotels. The only possibility is Air BnB and to rent a tent on the beach. There are several places where you can rent a tent along the Mc Le Hose trail. We stayed in the old town (air BnB). The old town is so much fun. Feels like a hutong. There are many many great (fish) restaurants and shops. We liked Sai Kung a lot! There is plenty to see and it has a very laid back vibe.Unfortunately, it rained non stop on the day we were going for the Mc LeHose Trail and the beach: Sai Wan Beach.From town we took the bus to the pier and started our hike back to the Sai Wan Pavillion (about 16 kilometres). The track is great, the path totally concrete; so very easily accessible, not difficult at all….but when you walk in a heavy (typhoon) rainstorm and the whole path turns into one big river, it’s hard to see fun it it.Anyhow, we did it. We believe that on days with great weather, this area must be heaven. Sai Wan Beach is a short hike (approximately 45 minutes) from Sai Wan Pavillion. The beach itself is relatively small, but has lovely clean white sand and a very gentle drop off in depth (ideal for those who want to paddle rather than dive straight in!). A short way up the hill from the beach there are two waterfalls and fresh water pools where you can swim and cool off away from the crowds. Sai Wan beach is flanked by two steep hills either side, forming a protected bay, but this also means that you are totally cut off from any signs of town or village life, and you can relax in peace far away from the sounds of traffic and people that are our normal soundtrack in Hong Kong.How to get there: take the 29R bus from Sai Kung which will drop you at Sai Wan Pavillion (approx 25 minutes). To get to the waterfalls, walk to the end of Sai Wan beach and follow the trail left from the river. The path gets very narrow and quite rocky – I seriously suggest you don’t do this in flipflops! – but after about 10-15 minutes, it will become wider and clearer and you will see the waterfalls ahead of you.
chillax ;). when you are tired of all the shopping malls in hong kong, you should spend some time there to enjoy another side of hong kong. magnificent scenery.

The most beautiful beaches in Hong Kong. Great place for the outdoor activities (hiking/kayaking) and seafood restaurants.Take a boat from Sai Kung Pier to the most beautiful beach in Hong Kong - Sai Wan Beach (Tai Long Wan) or take a bus N94 and enjoy the hike.Be prepared to wait for a taxi/bus to get out of Sai Kung, in weekends it gets really crowded.

Fishing Village, local hang out spot.. Sai Kung is the famous fishing village for the locals and definitely where the true locals purchase the seafood at a much cheaper price than the wet market. You can also have lunch here at a famous seafood restaurant where many celebrities have dine at. The cool thing about Sai Kung Village is that you can see how the locals negotiate for their food and seeing the fisherman selling the fish alive. It is truly fascinating and I highly recommend it.

I don't have words to describe how amazing this place is. If you would like to see other sides of HK it is highly recommended to visit Sai Kung. I discovered this place through recommendations of local people (western people not tend to visit this place so much)Going to Sai Kung would require at least half day. You can either go for a boat trip in the different islands or just go to one of the amazing beach over there. There are also very good sea food restaurants over there.

Very interesting to see how the local people promenade on a Sunday. Had a great time watching the local people, observing the many exceptionally groomed little dogs and seeing the fishing boats, There are lots of fish restaurants where you can choose your own live seafood /fish. (Not cheap though). Can be difficult finding a restaurant where you can make yourself understood in English, and many of the restaurants only have menus in Chinese. Altogether worth the trip. I just used public transport which was cheap and convenient.

The place to be!. Got some of the best beaches and hiking trails in the town.Visit this place during the weekdays and bring your own booze,food and wheels.There is a secluded sand beach that is marked as "Sai Kung Volcanic Park Region" on Google Maps.You have to hike down from the High Island island Reservoir but it's worth all the trouble.Another beach is next to the Sai Kung Pak Lap Holiday Village.You can also rent rooms ,buy alcohol and snacks at the village which is basically a couple of houses.This place isn't organised,so you might end up camping at the beach if there are no rooms available.

I could live here. Visited Sai Kung with friends who live locally.Lovely chilled vibe, lots of families and children out playing sports.Some great places to eat I enjoyed China kitchen and big fish.The seafront restaurants are amazing with all the live fish outside, such a great thing to seeLots of little hidden streets to wander.Fantastic place, I will visit again as soon as I can

Surprising. This was my first visit to Sai Kung and what a lovely surprise. The area is naturally beautiful with mountains a beaches. The town itself has a very interesting indoor market, worth a look plus a busy harbour. The beaches and countryside round about though are the best bit.

Very Authentic. Favoured by tourists and locals alike this is a very popular place at the weekends, best to vist during the week when you can get the true flavour of a small town in the New Territories, many restaurants to visit with an amazing choice of sea food , plenty to see and do very authentic, and certainly not a tourists trap. Accessible by public transport .

Nice sea views and local villages. Sai Kung is arguably the only place in Hong Kong where you can see very nice mountain and sea views plus a good walk to the local villages and hillside. This is a place where high rise building is not allowed so you have a total different experience from the rest of Hong Kong where high rise buildings are everywhere due to extreme land shortage. You have to take bus 92, 792M or 96R or minibus 1A or 101M from the city to the terminal stop and then take a local taxi to go to where you want to go and call another to meet you after the visit. As there are many routes of visits, you have to go to the map and decide which route you want to visit first. The easiest trip is to go to the local reservours. Some local buses are available but they are not very frequent and are normally operational during weekends and public holidays only. More information is available from the Hong Kong government websites for Sai Kung tourism.

Fantastic. We have recently moved here and it is gorgeous!!! There are plenty of bars and restaurants to choose from and boat trips to islands and beaches are wonderfully cheap. There is a great open air swimming pool that is worth a visit too.
Full of adventure. Very lovely place - beaches, seasides, hills, trails. Full of fun, adventure & eco things. Hurry up, Must go!
Boring place except for the night market. Boring place. The place is a little hard to access and the MTR ride is long. Frankly there is not much over here except for the night markets.
Sai Kung. This is a pretty fishing village in the national park. Some nice walks and plenty of cafes and restaurants. A nice place to visit if you want to get away from the hurly burly of Central.
Of the usual tourist track. Special, Hong Kong a bit of the usual tourist track , a bit of cointryside in Hong Kong, try the seafood retaurants !

Nice village but very touristy and can be really crowded. Sai Kung is a small fishing village in the east of Hong Kong. It's quite nice there: nice scenery, good sea food, can go on some boat trips... but it's also a very touristy spot, which takes out a lot of fun.Well, admittedly I was there during Chinese New Year at the weekend, so no surprise it was crowded. If you avoid public holidays and the weekend, then it should be a nice place to escape the bustling center of HK.

A Fun Escape from the Skyscrapers. Traveling out to Sai Kung for an afternoon / evening is a great change of pace if you get a little tired of the crowds and high rises of Central and Kowloon. The junk-filled harbor ("junk" meaning boats, not garbage- although there's a fair amount of that too) is atmospheric. The multitude of seafood restaurants along the quay all seem to be pretty identical, any one seems ready to serve of up a great Cantonese seafood meal. Where we ate, the clams with black bean sauce were fantastic, and I had my first opportunity to try Mantis Shrimp, which was remarkable!It is worth keeping in mind that after 7:00 PM public transportation back to Central is sparse; expect long waits to catch a bus.

Sai Kung - Retreat for the City Dwellers of Hong Kong !. This used to be a small fishing village, until part of the sea was reclaimed and turned into a promenade. A picturesque harbour with old style junks, tourist cruisers, and yachts moored up.In the mornings, you can see the indigenous local people doing their shopping in the local fish, meat and vegetable market. The more affluent locals are often accompanied by their maids or nannies and you will struggle to find a vacant table in the local eateries from 8.00am to 14.00pm.From Monday to Friday, you can enjoy leisurely strolls around the village and take a trip to one of the beautiful outlying islands, but at the weekends, this place is bursting at the seams. It's regarded as an excellent weekend retreat for the City folk with some of the best seafood restaurants in Hong Kong. Expensive, but delicious. If you fancy having a go at cooking seafood, there are many stalls on the seafront offering Lobsters and Crabs of various sizes, Shellfish, Prawns, Fish and Sea urchins freshly caught that very day.There is a wonderful Irish pub along the terrace, by the mini-shuttle bus rank, which offers a great pint and which shows PL matches. Frequented by ex-pats, it has a fantastic atmosphere.

A chilled out gem of an escape from Hong Kong bustle. If you fancy getting away from it all in Hong Kong, take a metro to Choi Hung, exit to the street and look for the number 1A minibus stop and ride to Sai Kung, a lovely backwater with a chilled vibe - grab a beer, choose dinner from the seafood restaurants along "seafood street" or take a trip on a sampan to one of the beaches along Clearwater Bay, such as Hap Mun Bay, where you'll find a relaxed little beach with a cafe, a hire shop for parasols and inflatables and views around the green hills of Hong Kong.

Quaint but lively place with lots of lovely seafood places. A lovely bay around this town with some beautiful views and nice walks around. It makes a nice change from the hectic high-rise madness of the city.The village itself has seafood restaurants galore, each with tanks of fish for you to choose from for them to cook and prepare.
Seafood adventure. Going to Saikung is going to the village area. Althoug there are a lot of Seafood restaurants over there it is also worthwhile going for shopping.

A good place to avoid the cityside. Sai Kung is a good place to rest away from the cityside from the hustle and bustle city of Hong Kong. It is known from it's delicious seafood there, including Hong Kee, Sheng Kee and much more delicious seafood restaurants there. It's near to the sea, and you can take several boats towards the islands near Sai Kung. Overall it is a excellent place to rest from the city and eat delicious seafood there.
MOST AMAZING BEACH OF HONG KONG. Most amazing and calm beach of hong kong.. I went there for Hiking over night. had the best experience

Quite and great seafood. Seafood restaurants and the cafe/bar away from the heat with big electric fan blowing away the hot air. Better than air condition and more Eco friendly on the environment.Great stop over to other islands from Sai Kung, great way to explore other areas in Sai Kung.

Getting away from the crowds. My girlfriend and I stayed at a friends place outside Sai Kung on our short 10 day stay in Hong Kong. It was a wonderful place to be. There is a big expatriate culture and lots of great along with lots of local seafood places right on the water. We decided that if we were lucky enough to live and work in Hong Kong that this is where we would live. The crowds are a a lot smaller here than in the center of Hong Kong. We were there in February so I would guess it would get much more crowded in summer.We also did a hike of a nearby trail and it was a fantastic view on top of the mountain we had to ourselves.All around a great place to be.

Fishing Village at its best.. Beautiful fishing village.A must if you're in town for over five days! The bus ride there is fun and offers some intense views. Travel tip: Board the bus sit on the right side on the upper deck to capture the true essence of visiting Sai Kung.
Will go again. Very nice area, plenty of fresh fish restraunts and bars full of ex pats that are always good for a laugh

Seafood Restaurant Village. It is good for foreigne tourists to visit for western style village and you can enjoy famous seafood there.
Also, you can enjoy some natural places and get close to the nature, BBQ and Hiking.

Food not as delicious as expected. Great place to see the sea if you want to enjoy the sea breeze. But limited beaches. Lots of tourist. If you are take the small bus with limited 16 seats prepare umbrellas in advance as the waiting area as there is no shelter. The fisher boats selling the fishes will not entertain you if you are only asking for prices. THere are also a flea market selling dried stuffs and sovenoirs as well. Don't be afraid to bargain for a good price before buying. Seafood restaurant very expensive, food not as delicious as describe by others mentioned in tripadvisor.
Spend a weekend here. Famous for Chinese seafood restaurants. However, you can also find good western restaurants and desserts. Can be reached by bus and minibus.

Awesome place for nature lover. Saikung is a verry beautiful palace to live and to go as outing reaching there by train bus or taxi is easy but definate consune time ...the best n fastest way is train to hung how and a bus just from the mtr station 101gose directly to saikung...meny small boat trips or hiking to meny trails and beach..my best hike and bote was to saiwan village which have a beautifull beach and a natural water fall.

Gorgeous day out. Gorgeous way to see HK.As a tourist one never gets to see this side of HK or even expect it. But its a peaceful and gorgeous day out. Take time walk on the beach, eat at the many seafood restaurants..

Nice seaside with amazing view and landscape. Sai Kung is located in the East of HK - it could be quite difficult to reach by public transport if you don't have your own car. It's a nice seaside with a nice promenade where you will often find locals taking a stroll and exhibiting their (sometimes overly exaggaratedly) well-groomed pet-dogs. You can go on boat trips to nearby little islands and inside the small town, there is also an alley with many nice little cafés and restaurants. There is also a good number of seafood restaurants.

Seaside getaway. From Mongkok, you can take a minibus from the station at Dundee street (1 end of Ladies Market). The bus will generally wait for a total of 16 passengers before departing. We waited 10 minutes in the bus. The journey lasted 25 mins and cost 16 HKD. The bus journey was actually more interesting than Sai Kung itself traveling through windy mountain roads. The return bus stop is Not where you alight but at the stadium opposite to the ParkandShop place. After so many years, the mini bus drivers are the epitome of the character of Hong Kong from the past.Sai Kung itself is a simple seaside place with many ferry owners touting for boat trips to the surrounding islands so you can decide how long you want to stay. We walked around and bought fresh seafood from a boat vendor to be cooked at a nearby restaurant for a fee.
Worth the long trip. The best area in Hong Kong. Very beautiful. You feel like you are in Thailand. Hard to get to but definitely worth the trip.

Overrated town but great countryside and coastal areas. Sai Kung is a huge area in East Hong Kong, so it can't really be rated as a whole because some bits are bad and some bits are good. The bad bit generally feature around Sai Kung town which is a bit like a seaside town in the UK - think Skegness with nicer weather. However, the town is a necessary evil if you want to get to the good bits which include the surrounding country parks, beaches and islands. The time to avoid SK is at the weekend when everyone in HK descends upon the place and the two roads in and out of the town become gridlocked - late morning time and late afternoon are the worst time with people heading in and out respectively. A bus journey can be extended by 30 mins at these times! If you are a visitor, then it is well worth leaving SK until a weekday when it is much more easy to get in and out of.
Great taste for Seafood. Must try to eat at Sea Food Restaurant, it is delicious , but the place is rather difficult to find, must pass thru the local village and take a walk from Car Park
Away from busy city life. A little fishing village offering abundance of seafood. Easy access by bus across Hong Kong and buses are frequent. We did not visit the beach to comment

Amazing seafood restaurant and a peace land in this busy city. Fresh seafood and immediately cooked after ordered. And the neighbour is quite and peace, if you are looking for places that is really different from Mong Kok or Central, this is a place for you to go!

mixed of sandy beaches, greenery and delicious seafood. lunch at Sai Kung is a bliss. go to pier to enjoy luxurious seafood at any restaurant for a very reasonable price. steam fresh catch of the day costs USD100. and upif you are on a budget, you could order set lunch menu with shrimp, crab and steam fish for USD50. ppyou won't regret to spend the whole day in Sai Kung.

Did you know.... That you can buy seafood from the little boats next to the pier and then take it to any restaurant near the coastline to have them cook it for you? It is fun to be able to choose your own food! Perfect for the picky eater ;)don't forget to haggle :)

Sai Kung, try the sea food but take in so much more.... Sai Kung is another area of Hong Kong that is famous for its incredible sea food but has a lot more to offer the visitors. Easily accessible by Mini Bus or Bus from many locations around Hong Kong Sai Kung makes a great full day excursion. Wonder around the boardwalk area and see the fresh sea food markets where people sell their catch straight from the small boats. Many restaurants have tanks of fresh fish and other sea food for you to choose, how ever the boardwalk also has many smaller less expensive eateries to choose from. I found a great little fish and chips stall that served some of the best fish and chips I have had in a long time. Just a little further down the boardwalk was a great burger place that had tasty and filling burgers with all types of fillings. All around this area you will see items from all over the world on offer, lollies from the UK, Beer from Germany and American style burgers are just a few of the delights on offer.A definite must see place when you are planning your trip to Hong Kong whether you go as part of an organised tour of you jump on a Mini Bus or Bus, getting there and back is easy just make sure you take your camera and don't think you will be able to see it in an hour of two as there is a lot to see and do in Sai Kung.

Just meet with Hong Kong's everyday life. Sai Kung is located in the New Territories and for sure not as crowded as Hong Kong's city centre, therefore it suits as a starting point to discover that stunning Asian metropolis. There is a coffeehouse in the centre of Sai Kung offering white coffee and croissants for example, so the coffeehouse may will remind you of your European homeland.It is no problem to get to the centre of Hong Kong which is served from Sai Kung by tube (round about 60-minute journey by bus and underground).Do not miss to go and see 'The Peak' in the evening. From its observation deck you will enjoy an amazing view of Victoria Harbour and the town accompanied by an exciting laser light show being presented every night at 8pm.

Fresh seafood abounds!. Sai Kung is a fishing village away from the crowds of Hong Kong situated in on the coast in a lush tropical landscape. Fishermen sell their catch from their boats along the wharf area and many seafood restaurants line the promenade with live sea creatures in tanks ready to be cooked. Just an amazing area.
