Nice old style fishing area. We always enjoy taking a bus to the fishing village and spending an afternoon or evening in this calmer, old style, fishing and boating area. Love the vendors sea food sold on the pier!

Good for Seafood and nice beach. Sai Kung is a very different place from other Hong Kong areas. The atmosphere is very relaxing with a lot of seafood restaurants by the sea side. The seafood are freshly cooked with Cantonese cooking style. Good to spend a lazy afternoon drinking coffee follow by the delicious Chinese seafood cuisine.
Great place for a day out. Many good seafood places with all of the goods live in tanks.. Not sure what many of the are though.

Clean Cantonese seafood. The best location for foreigners seeking to experience Cantonese seafood at a high level and in a clean environment. If you eat three things in Hong Kong, this must be one...dim sum and BBQ pork are the others.

My favorite in HK. So different than Central HK. I discovered this on my fourth visit to HK and got totally hooked to it. Food, ambiance, crowd, beach - sai kung has everything and a lot cleaner than central HK

Seafood heaven. Strongly recommend not to travel in the noon, better go after sunset, otherwise find some nice café along the pier. We took more than an hour to reach Sai Kung by green minibus. A long ride from Kowloon side, but it worth after see the seafood street. All the giant seafood and shellfish placed at the tank for you to pick. Apart from the seafood street, some fishermen also sold their catch in the boat. Locals ordered from the pier and fishermen then lifted that up. But we enjoyed the seafood dinner in the proper seafood with many suggestions by the waiter-Ming. A walk along the pier after dinner was recommended.

Seafood Hunt. We travelled to Saikung by the green minibus. It was a comfortable 30 minute ride from the city. Upon arrival we could immediately see the numerous seafood restaurants which their seafood in tanks. These make for a nice photo pic. The evening period is particularly nice for a walk about as it is cooler. There is also a quaint market place where fishmongers sell their catch in the boats. Customerspoint to what they want and agree on the price. The fishmongers are deft with their hands - you could observe just how quickly they de-scale the fishes. I understand that it is possible to buy seafood from the fishmongers and take them to the restaurants to cook. But I would recommend that for visitors who are especially not conversant with the local language to just patronise one of the restaurants and order your food there. The dinner we had was ok, not fantastic and looking at other diners, we could have done better with food ordering. A nice experience overall. By the way, the queue for the same minibus for our way back was a long mile but no panic, the buses came one after another and we waited just 20 minutes in that long line to get on the bus.

What a beautiful islands. I'm so pleased we made the trip. My husband, my niece and I visited there together. We took MRT first, then took a long ride by bus. It's totally worth it. We took a boat to visit a few islands, it reminded me of some islands in Carribean, the water was so pretty and clear in some parts of shore.

Nice getaway in Hong Kong. Sai Kung is a territory towards the north-east of Hong Kong S.A.R. It comprises of several islands (70 odd) and some beautiful scenery. Well known for beaches and some beautiful hikes in the country park. A really great hike that I like is starting at Man O Shan (just towards the west of Sai Kung country park) going up the hill which has spectacular views and then coming down to Sai Kung. There are a number of restaurants and bars which have come up in this area lately, so a good getaway overall. It also has some good diving spots, not comparable to countries like Thailand or Indonesia, but nevertheless, it is one of the few spots in HK. Worth visiting this place if you are a resident in HK or a tourist!

not crowded. Sai Kung is a peaceful village by the sea, plenty of fresh fish available if you like fish, Sai Kung can be reached by local buses from Hong Kong takes a 45-60 minute trip, This is a worthwhile trip if you are tired of the crowds in Hong Kong and Tsimshashui,
great food. Catch a mini bus out to sai kung and see Hong Kongs alternative lifestyle. Everything moves slower and enjoy the seafood watching life go by or have a beer at one of the many pubs

Sea Food Paradise. Sai Kung is definitely the area you want to go to for the freshest seafood and the widest variety. An outdoor restaurant is excellent on a warm evening with an ice cold beer as an accompaniment.

Must go in Hong Kong. Whether or not you like beaches, boating or water sports, Sai Kung is a must-go in Hong Kong. Over weekends it's usually crowded with both locals and tourists who go on a boat trip. There are also a lot other that Sai Kung has to offer - barbeque, kiting etc, Sai Kung is also well renowed for its seafood restaurants - relatively pricey but you get the freshest food and a good seaview.
Could skip this if you are from the US/EUROPE or are familiar with beaches elsewher!. Only beach in HK.Real hot day and scalding sand!Could not rent a Tent anywhere.Only one 7/11 around.

If You Chose Your Moments A Great Place. Sai Kung is great, but there are some caveats to this statement. Things to Avoid:- driving in to Sai Kung after 9am on summer weekends- driving out of Sai Kung after 3pm on weekends- ordering exorbitantly priced fish at the seafood restaurants- saying yes to the touts at the waterfronts offering boat trips to "amazing" rock formations (they aren't!)- visiting the dog beach on Monday after the junk operators have thrown garbage bags of rubbish over the side after dropping off their guests- swimming drunk of a junk without supervision (we rescued one guy and dropped him back at the junk and they had no idea he had nearly died on their watch)Things to Do:- get the guys at Loaf On to set up a table in the old town street and eat amongst the locals on a weekend night- enjoy the friendly smiles and great food and drinks at Casa- say hi to Connie at Classifieds and enjoy probably Sai Kung's best coffee and cake- buy some prawns and have them cooked ready to take home from one of the seafood restaurants- visit Ken at Little Harrods for anything you may need (really, anything!)- have an ice cold Asahi and the butter chicken served by Raj and his team at Jojo- go to Bacco on a Friday night and listen to the great live local music and then settle in for a very late nightWe lived in Sai Kung for five years and are leaving in Q3 2015. Very sad to leave as it is a great community and a great place to hang out (especially during the week!).

My favorite place in all of Hong Kong. Sai Kung is close to Clear Water Bay, where my University is located, and is my favorite place to escape from the dull University life. It has everything that you need, nice restaurants, shops of all kinds, beautiful beach, and yet somehow avoids the typical high rise buildings of Hong Kong. I love to go there and simply walk along the town and waterfront. People would bring their dogs for a walk, some would be flying kites, others playing with their drones, this place is awesome at sunset. For good Indian food, go to Jojo Indian restaurant. For Thai, there's May's Sawaddee Thailand, right across the road from Jojo.

local fishemen village and grat seafood. this was our second visit to Sai Kung. we love to see all the fresh seafood infront of restaurant. we pick and they cook for us. Also, it is very interesting to see local fishemen sell freshly caught seafood from their boat at the pier. we charter a boat for fishing for 3 hrs. one boat asked for HK$1500 and other asked HK$900. boat ride was nice; however, we caught only very very small fish.

Squid Fishing. There are many boat that go out from Sai Kung Pier out into Sai Kung sea to do squid fishing.My Hong Kong friend took the both of us from Singapore to have a brand new experience that we never did in our life.Squid caught are cooked on the spot, they are really fresh and yummy.I will recommend anyone to do squid fishing as well if the chance come by.

Sai Kung. My favorite place in HK! Not easy to get there; takes a while depending where you live. Beautiful scenery, delicious foods, and the atmosphere is always lively and cheerful! There are many beaches around the area, as well as a swimming pool, so its a perfect place to go on the weekends on a hot summer day!

For beach lovers. Sai Kung is a somewhat desolate place in Hong Kong and a bit time-consuming to get to from the heart of Hong Kong. But once you get there, it will all have been worth it. The beaches are nice, and there are some really great seafood restaurants. And you can charter boats to take you out to the islands in the bay. If you enjoy nature and scenic views, then go to Sai Kung, it is a small slice of paradise in the bustling metropolis.
Nice.. So amazing that this is so close to HK island, another world, lovely but beware of the coral seeded in the bay's to stop mainland 'visitors' back in the early days.

Fishery village, and you choose your fishes.. Make your choice of many restaurants around there, they will show you to the live fishes swimming in the tanks, jumping out of it when you make choices. They will cook it for a style as you like. Discussing how is it cooked with the staffs is already a part of enjoyment.
love the area. love the food. the walks along the promenade. perfect place for Sunday family time. lots of places to see as well. great food!

Peaceful. Nice place for seafood, a stroll along water. Enjoy swimming at nice and small beaches and hiking on montain trails nearby, watching lots of dogs strolling in hamony at sunset and seafood at night.

Nice day at a fishermen village. Many seafood restaurants.. Sai kung has never been my final destination of a day. It has always been a place on my way to Tai long wan. It is a good place with lots of supermarkets, cafes, restaurants, swimming and beach stuff and clothes. It has a walking area right by the sea. A good place to get some delicious seafood dinner. There is not anything that I do not like about this place.

A little germ in the crowded city. We took a day out and took the taxi from central to North point and then took the MTR to Po Lam and then took the bus 101M as we though to kind of travel like a locals & try the bus + MTR combo. The weather was fantastic and the sea view was great too. There were loads of people taking their time walking about and also some are coming back with the bags/packs on their back with their family. One can take boats to get to other islands and also try the seafood restaurants at this place.There are also some fresh seafood on sale in the boat - it was quite a cool sight that we had to stop and observe. The vendor will put the seafood on a net to pass it on to the customers on the pier. Quite a local sight which we enjoyed. The air was so much better than central hong kong. We will definitely go back and try to explore a bit more of this area. Great on a nice day.

One day trip with great views and nice seafood. Great place to have a short stroll along the seaside, grab some nice food, have a boat ride to explore beautiful area of dozens of tiny islands (shortest one takes 1h only).Perfect spot for enjoying super fresh seafood. Quite pricey but worth it when you are a true foodie. Start from picking the seafood, they will come and tell you the price after a while. If you are ok with the price you can choose the way you want it to cooked. Ask staff for recommendation, they usually know best. The aquariums in front of the restaurants are amazing, even for taking photos only.The old town is nice when you wanna eat with locals and be lost among tine stalls and narrow lanes.
Seafood!. If you are a seafood foodie, this is heaven for you! So many choices to pick and you will not be disappointed!

Had a great time walking through old street. Our friends took us to Sai Kung and walked through the old part of town. We ended up ordering fresh seafood from the restaurant and had a fantastic late lunch with good friends.

Great place for a weekend getaway. I went with a friend for a weekend getaway. Sai Kung is home to a lot of seafood restaurants and a variety of other types of cuisine. A walk by the sea and inside the little town is definitely interesting and relaxing. We went from Sai Kung to a small island nearby called Tap Mun. What a fantastic view! Loved it, loved it, loved it!!!

Backyard of Hong Kong. Hong Kong is a very high populated city with more than 7 millions of people. That is why you find most of the places in the city are crowded and busy. In my opinions, one of the best place to relax and enjoy for trekking, cycling or having a picnic with your friends or family is going to Sai Kung at the weekends. Public buses or mini-buses are available to get there. You may enjoy one full day or some people may camp for overnight at the beaches. One attraction particularly welcome by the visitors is having seafood dinner at the local seafood restaurant near the public pier of Sai Kung. Price is reasonable and you may sit in the open air at night. I went there also to buy seafood from the public pier where about 30 sampans parking there to sell fresh seafood. Prices are cheaper than what you pay at the wet markets in the city.

LIttle treasure. Situated in a 'typhoon shelter' area, Sai Kung is a gem. World class seafood dining at very reasonable prices. Take a step back in time - walk the dock area, have dinner, a drink at one of many bars and do some shopping. You will go back again.

Spectacular view. Spectacular view at the Eco park, never seen the rock formation anywhere, easy to get to whether by boat or taxi, if you like to hike to the dam, the taxi driver can take you to the closet point, it is recommended to bring bottled water for the hike during hot days

Nice place for an afternoon. Nice array of restaurants, but getting there can be a drag when you have to choose between green minbuses and KMB busses. If you aren't sure, ask at the hotel for the best way to get there.Some of the seafood restaurants are incredible, with a wide range of live seafood to choose from. It is a little difficult to deal with if you start to think about how the seafood is treated as it is crammed in so many small tanks. You can see the small fisherman selling their wares at the pier. There are also small tours out into the surrounding areas.
Back Garden of Hong Kong. Beautiful beaches ... all natural islands ... All sorts of watersports ... many seafood restaurants ... relax and small town

Seafood and a floating market. Waterside seafood restaurants in a buzzy and lively town which has lots of other eateries. If you do on Sundays there is a floating market where food is sold direct from sanpans. The seafood restaurants are unforunately only average quality and expensive. Lamma is better
Great Place. Nice place to walk around, great country side and and lots of food options. Also dog and family friendly.
Walk around. Take a walk around and check out the harbour. You cannot get any fresher fish. And the character of the place will stay with you

Expat Paradise. In New Territories: Sai Lung is an area where most Expats live and work. It's a paradise, there are town houses and less apartments, everyone seems to have a pet and the markets gives a village feel and there is an Indian restaurant here which is probably one of the best restaurants in Hong Kong called "Jo Jo's". Its expensive but the expats love the food and the service. It's a small restaurant but if you are planning to be here then a visit to this restaurant is a must... Amazing fingerlicious food!!!

Good restaurants. Do have a seafood lunch or dinner at one of the many restaurants. Take a 1 hour sampan or boat-ride around the harbour. It is interesting way of seeing the coastline. easy to reach by NO. 92 bus from Diamond Hill
Hustle and bustle of Chinese fishing village. Great to get away to Sai Kung to see the greenery and mountainside living with fishing village village of Sai Kung at the base.

Nice but no village. Once a fishing village it is now mainly a tourist area with seafood and boutique shops the main attraction. It is possibly the best fresh seafood place in the whole of Asia and these days many tour groups from China come and drive up prizes. Still worth a visit. I usually go very early (before dawn) to have some early breakfast and listen to the locals talk.

nice day-time escape from HK Island. This is a nice day-time escape from HK Island or TST. No MTR connection, but easy to get to if you take the KMB No.92 from Diamond Hill MTR Station to Sai Kung. Sai Kung has many things to offer - the East Sai Kung Country Park for good trecking, the Sai Kung Promenade where on many days local fishermen moor to offer their catch (go with a local, as if you go on your own and cannot haggle in Cantonese, you'll be ripped off), the many seafood restaurants (rather pricey, and quality is probably better in some similar places in Aberdeen or Ma Wan Chung), the little shops, etc. The place is popular with the expats, and the promenade with dog owners......

It's not just about seafood. Sai Kung is relatively easy even for a tourist like me to visit using either a regular bus or a mini bus from various areas of Kowloon. We got on a mini bus (1A) from near MTR's Choi Hung Station to Sai Kung. It took us about 25 minutes.It was a gorgeous late afternoon on a week day. It wasn't crowded, and we enjoyed the perfect breeze on our face, sitting on a bench at one of the piers.As usual, there are several boats on which fishermen or a grandmother are selling their catch of the day. Even if we didn't understand what everyone was saying, it was fun just watching the interactions of them and the customers.In addition to all the seafood restaurants, there are quite a few interesting stores and coffee shops in the area. We enjoyed exploring Sai Kung and eating nice seafood dinner from a late afternoon into an evening.On the way back, we took a regular bus (792M) from Sai Kung to Tseung Kwan O Station.Again, since it's not too difficult to reach Sai Kung, you should try and explore just a little bit different Hong Kong here.
Interesting day out. Very different to city. Locals buying fish from boats was fascinating. Needed a local to help you choose from menus.

Go back in time and eat seafood. Different feel to Hong Kong and Kowloon, less bustle and more laid back. Very traditional Chinese village and I don't think it's changed very much for a long time, I remember visiting years ago and it seems the same. There is a big expat community here too, if that's something you are looking for. Well Sai Kung is THE place renown for seafood and fish, all along the water front are the restaurants with their displays of choices. Amazing. Still good value, but barter.Enjoy !

Oasis in HK. Sai Kung is a very different place from other HK areas. The atomsphere is very relaxing with a lot of seafood restaurants by the sea side. The seafood are freshly cooked with Cantonese cooking style. Good to spend a lazy afternoon drinking coffee follow by the delicious Chinese seafood cuisine.

A beautiful daytrip. We took a bus here and the trip, while long, was beautiful. Once we got there it was a little tricky to find everything but using our phone, we were able to get around ok. There's definitely a full day's worth of things to see and do here. Don't miss the seafood restaurants!

Great seafood, but the ecopark was a trash heap.. The value and the quality of the seafood out of the aquariums right on the boardwalk was delicious, fresh, plentiful, good value, and above all tasty. The boat ride to the ecopark was clean and reliable, but walking around the bridge to the island that covers up in high tide was full of garbage, plastic bottles, styrofoam chards, discarded paper etc.

Great area to hang around in HK. You find Sai Kung quite different than any other seaside town in the world. Hong Kong has such large population and her people always try to find somewhere away from downtown. Sai Kung becomes a very popular place for families and friends. The town could be so busy that you would not believe. But if you explore a little inland where the country parks and hiking trails are, you definitely feel different.

Refresh one's mind. I love going to Sai Kung when I am feeling dizzy about my daily life. I have found that air in Sai Kung is extremely fresh and I can refresh myself by going there. I love staying in the pier for watching others' activity. For example, some will do fishing there. People will hang around with their pets. I love looking at people all around. I can also hang around there and find something delicious for my meal.

weekens in Sai Kung. last weekend stay in Sai Kung, is big different as Kowloon and the big city, we rent a boat for 1 hour it cost 250HKD, very nice lady pick us up and show us around the coast, a lot of people walk around with there dogs, you can buy souveniers ,dry fish etc. but the reality almost all seafood are imported from Malaysia, the business mens sales to the boat people they put on there own boat and re sale it to the tourists

Seafood Central!. Great for day trip on the weekend. Quite another flair than the big city. Some decent beaches close by where you may relax, then in the evening you may go to one of the numerous seafood restaurants in town. They all have an unreal selection of fish and seafoods.I am getting hungry just thinking of it..The place may get very crowded on certain holidays or on weekends, parking is not easy, and sometimes there may be a lot of traffic, but it is worth it.

Away from Hong Kong crowds. Great place to go and get closer to nature in Hong Kong. In the morning before noon time can go there is people to buy those fresh seafoods from those fishmongers from their boat. It is fun to see how the transaction is be done. After, take a walk along the promenade, to enjoy the sea breeze and lastly, to enjoy the freshest seafood feast in great deal. Not my norm place to visit Hong Kong and 1st time to visit there even though I been visiting Hong Kong for 10 times. Will visit again, will like to hike some hills there.
Touristy. Nice but very touristy sea shore town with alot of sea food restaurants. Good to go see, but not too thrilled to go again next time.

Like a day on vacation. Coming from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong Island a drive to Sai Kung is like a day on vacation. We went on a weekend and the promenade was full of people (showing off their dogs) and stalls where you can buy souveniers, organic produce etc. When you walk along the peers you see the fishermen selling fresh fish, clams and crabs. Further down in town there are a number of fish restaurants. We ate at one that stated something about Guide Michelin (sorry I forgot the name) but the food we had was fresh and delicious. Value for money: good. We then wondered around the streets of Sai Kung, visited the Tin Hau Temple and had a Starbucks on our way back to the car. Sai Kung is a nice little town, not so touristy as Stanley and we will come back again

Excellent bargin for seafood lovers. Be there before 12:00 noon and pick any one of the restaurants and order a special lunch deal for 2 or 4 and you will be rewarded with a sumptuous fresh/live seafood meal of you choice for half the normal price Try to avoid going there during the weekends. You can book a trip sailing around the nearby small islands before lunch. Choice the short one instead of the more extended one if you just want to experience a ride in a traditional Chinese fishing boat. Make sure they are well equipped with Life jackets.

Beautiful, amazing Sai Kung. My son is lucky enough to live in Sai Kung and we have visited several times and are going again next month.It is a lovely place to visit, no high rise buildings,little streets full of interesting shops, market stalls, fantastic fish restaurants, plenty of seats along the sea front where you can watch the fishermen selling their catch. Get one of the sampan ladies to take you out on their boat for an hour, fantastic. Wonderful friendly people. Visit the gorgeous Grass Island too.

The place where good near seafood restaurants gather from Kowloon!. Here, there are a lot of restaurants where I can order one's favorite dish from with a choice of a fish and prawns, a shellfish by oneself.You may taste seafood of genuine Hong Kong if you postpone a leg a little.You arrive by bus by taxi in around 30 minutes.

Freshest Seafood in Hong Kong. Stopped here on my last night before heading home to the U.S.This is a quaint little fishing village,reminiscent of the old days.There were actual fishing boats here, selling seafood to the locals.The variety available was amazing but also very colorful.There are several restaurants on the pier,all showcasing their live seafood and encouraging you to look.Huge crabs, lobsters, scallops, abalone and the biggest shrimp I have ever seen!We ate a wonderful meal consisting of a lobster prepared in a cheese sauce with noodles, scallops and two kinds of shrimp plus great broccoli ( had to have our greens).Total cost was $120. USD which would have been the price of the lobster back home!!This is a must see if you visit Hong Kong!
good sea food. this place is famous for sea foods in hong kong. You will get to see a sea food market in sai kung . people keep on selling on their boats.But these are quite expensive. can try once.
Relax Day. Saturday, just walk around in sai kungfeeling the breach and wins make we feel relaxwe also bring our puppy, we had a fun day

Still have the old HK fishing village feel. This is one of the oldest fishing village in HK, a little remote to get too, but a taxi ride can get you to anywhere in HK. This is definitely very different and you can pick and buy your own seafood live and take them to be cook at one of the restaurant next door, but be warned this is a tourist trap and they will over charge you if you do not speak Cantonese. Also, the local restaurants are famous for switching your bought seafood with some of their, best to go with a local friend. But just watching those live seafood is better than a visit to the Aquarium.

Picturesque Little Fishing Village. Very quaint little village where we saw fishermen who live in their boats. Interesting, especially if you have never seen a village like this. We have, but we still enjoyed it.

Can't get any fresher fish to eat.. This is a small fishing village,with a couple public piers. The local fishermen dock their skiffs by the seawall,and sell live animals of all types out of their boats. Along the board walk are restaurants,with large to small aquarium tanks. You pick out who you want to eat,and they put them in a bag, give you a tag,and you give it to your server in the restaurant. Then you go over the menu to decide how you want each item prepared. Some are roof top places,and you have a stunning view as you dine. To dine just as dusk settles,you can see the town light up, in the glow of electric,and kerosene lanterns. It looks like some Mediterranean fishing village, like I've seen on postcards, and is so very romantic.

Chuen Kee Seafood restaurant. I visited Chuen Kee Seafood restaurant at the seashore of Sai Kung Promenade. There has many kinds of seafood and you may able to see some of the creatures that you have never seen. Ask the manager for their restaurant signature and you will love it.
Okay for hiking.... It's a lovely place for hikes especially with your family, there is lots of nature to see...I do advise it but only if you enjoy hikes,

Nice get away. quite respite from the business of HK. easy to get to via the MTR and buses. Go see the other side of HK.Some excellent restaurants and some local bars.Worth the time, and no need to drive

Very pleasant, though slightly busy fishing village. This place was really nice and apparently it's where a lot of the locals head at the weekends ot get out of the city.There's plenty of restaurants and boat trips on offer down on the docks and some family parks, good bars near by. With the international school nearby there is obviously a good expat community out here.

Enjoyable Sunday outing. This is a great place to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong and see what Hong Kongers do on the weekends. It's easy to get to using subway and bus. Stroll the seaside promenade, watch the fishing boats come back with their catch, rent a boat to motor you around the bay, poke around the little town with its shops and restaurants, and eat in your choice of many types of restaurants. If you prefer the familiar ex-pat experience, there is a Starbucks and there are restaurants with English language menus and familiar cuisine. Or stretch yourself and choose a place with a Chinese menu. Pointing works wonders. You can find everything from sit-down to walk-up window.

Nice place for all!. Many places for relaxing ourselves.We can play many things! I enjoy it very much.The sea and other places are good in a busy city- HK.I hope all of you can enjoy^^Thats a Nice place for all!I hope my boyfriend can come with me next time to have a dating hahaha
Must-visit near Hong Kong. An ideal place to go for seafood lovers. Try to stay a little bit until sunset, you're going to love it!
A great little fishing Town. Some great restaurants on the sea front if not a little expensive. Ex pat bars and restaurants away from the front. Try Steamers for pub food and reasonable prices
Fishing village. sampan trips and a golf course. Old market and lots of restaurants and bars. Essence of old Hong Kong still lingers. Transport on PLB (public light bus) very cheap.

Lovely place. Take a walk, eat and just enjoy.
Not many people there, which was a great surprise.
Lovely place to spend an afternoon.
Definitely worth a visit.
Great place for scenery & fresh seafood. Great weather, love the rustic, quaint feel of the place. I really enjoy the fresh seafood there too.

A lovely Sunny Sunday outing. The family decided that, being a Sunday, an outing to Sai Kung should be attempted. So, all of us piled into a car and drove over from Cyberport via Aberdeen tunnel, using the harbour tunnel.All in all, it was a pleasant drive of about 30 km and we found the parking pretty cheap compared to Hong Kong standards. Just 4 HK$ an hour as compared to a Sunday 30HK$ in Central and much healthier too as there is much to do in a much more healthy environment.Had lunch in Sri Lankan AJ's. Good food, but as children were with us, so had to compromise on the spiciness of the food, which somewhat detracted the cuisine. This, the owner was not very happy with, as he said that Sri Lankan food is best enjoyed with its original spiciness.Finished the day with a walk down the promenade, where all the Seafood serving restaurant's abound. You can make a selection from the vast repertoire of fresh sea food floating in their glass cages and they will cook for you.Walked around a bit to soak in the atmosphere. Enjoyed surveying the giant Chinese Bunyan tree adjoining the children's park, where the musicians too entertained the crowd.All in all, a perfectly entertaining sunny Sunday.

Can beaches and Hong Kong fit in the same sentence?. Sai Kung village is nice to visit, I mean, as a complete opposite of urban Hong Kong, but still so bound to it, but I'd guess many people visit Sai Kung is because it is a great hub to visit the many beaches that spread along the coast. And I mean magazine-photo-white-sand-blue-water beaches. We usually visit Sai Wan beach which is more or less a surfer's getaway (you can rent a boat to take you there for more or less 350HKD/person). It is possible to take tents and camp on the beach and there are a couple of reasonable restaurants there with simple food. I believe some people also visit Sai Kung for water sports.

Nice getaway. We took the MTR to Choi Hung station and minibus 1A all the way to Sai Kung town. Along the way you get to see lots of greenery and even a yacht club. It was raining so we didn't get a chance to take a boat ride to the surrounding Islands. The view was very nice along the promenade. We had a very delicious seafood lunch at one of the seafood restaurants . Everything was super fresh. Lots of people walked their dogs along the promenade and it was interesting to do some people and dog watching . Highly recommended for a nice day out of the city and see another side of Hong Kong.

Loved our stay in Sai Kung!. Sai Kung offers a quiet, relaxed, and great cultural experience away from the city. Close enough for a day trip. Chueng Kee and Hung Kee restaurants offer an awesome outdoor dim sum breakfast. Walk along the bay, on the pier and see the fishmen at work. Good shopping and wandering through the back roads! The light bus is easily accessible and cheap to get to and from.

My Favourite place in HK!!. Sai Kung is my absolute favourite place to hang out in HK. It has everything one needs. From Starbucks to paisanos, Subway. I love going to Sai Kung on a busy Saturday afternoon and soaking in the sun. :)

Sai Kung. Was there on 17 Jan 2015.Take a MTR to "Choi Hung" (Rainbow in Chinese), exit C2 and take a mini bus 1A all the way to the end. The bus journey is less than 30minutes and cost only HKD8.40. Octopus card can be used.Saw quite some fishermen selling their stuff from their boats. Did not try buying from them as was first trip there. Went to a restaurant to have a meal. Realised that these restaurants will actually cook if you were to buy from the fishermen....depending on how much you bargain from the fishermen and if the restaurant have an exact comparison, otherwise, it is hard to tell which is considered more/less pricey.In any case, the restaurant range of seafood is more and I saw the cooking costs can be here HKD30 + there add HKD25 etc so by the time the item is cooked haha not sure what the cost will be also.Take a good stroll by the seaside. Especially during the cold weather, it is great and there are some stores selling some stuffs aside from dried seafood.The cappuccino served by a western restaurant sandwiched by two big seafood restaurant (slightly hidden in an alley) is good price at only HKD15.Quite some people walk their dogs along the promenade and it's a nice sight.Ah, there is a public toilet opposite the bus interchange. Ask around if you need directions. There are some signs but may not be very prominent.When I am there next round, I will look out for their "bo lo char siew pau" as I heard it is great. Best time to visit is probably winter to spring where the weather is good. Oh, it can be a bit colder than down town so do bring slightly warmer clothing. Plus the wind blowing from the sea.When I came back around 5-6pm, had a long queue for 1A mini bus and waited for about 4 to pass by (Less than 30minutes) before finally boarding one.

Quaint fishing village. Nice fishing village in Sai Kung country park. Loads of seafood restaurants where the fish and prawns are swimming around in the tanks until they hit the wok. Additional bonus of shopping to salt fish and dried shrimps along the waterfront, direct from the fisherman and women. A bit crowded at weekends but still a nice place to go, especially with your dogs!

An old stamping ground. Sai Kung is the place to go if you want to get away from it all, unfortunately everyone seems to have the same idea and the public areas are always packed. BBQ is the order of the day and its a fun way to pass the time watching the locals trying to get their charcoal alight. You can buy fresh fish at the quayside and there are many vendors selling cooked and uncooked meats. Good Thai food is avaioable at the Resort and the beach pub sells snacks and a good selection of drinks. Even with all the people it's still less crowded than Nathan Road.

Sai Kung. I took my children here in December and it was good. Good to get some fresh air and there were a lot of street hawkers. They all make nice jewelry and stuff. People were walking their dogs and riding their bikes. We tried the seafood there but it was kind of expensive but seemed kind of fresh. It is good to bring family and spend a day there.

One of the top attractions of Hong Kong. I live in Hong Kong, and have not yet said no to a hike in Sai Kung with friends! We were just there this afternoon and though it was a bit hazy it was a lovely day. Plan on an all-day hike, perhaps followed by dinner in Sai Kung town itself. Bring plenty of water; I found that only two bottles left me a bit short. Pack snacks and lunch as well, because though some of the villages have restaurants it is not certain they will be on your trail. The trails are often exposed, so bring sun protection. Some might like having a walking stick, as the trails can be steep and uneven. Enjoy!

Food stalls. The choice of live seafood is good but the price is very high and expensive.The seating is not too comfortable. However, the walk outside the restaurant along the water front is very pleasant.

Go Island Hopping in Sai Kung. Allow travel time of about 2 hours to get to Sai Kung if coming in from Hong Kong island. Get off from Diamond Hill MRT and board bus number 92 to Sai Kung Peninsula. From there, buy a ticket from ferry operators there for island to see picturesque shorelines and small, mostly uninhabited islands. Alternatively, take bus 96R for Wong Shek Pier and take a bum boat to Tap Mun island

Nice seaside town in east Kowloon. Picturesque and nicely kept small town. You can stroll the harbourfront, walk on the beach, bathe in the sea, play sports, watch the fishing boats returning early afternoon to sell their catch to all comers. Definitely an interesting day out.There are a number of fresh seafood restaurtants on the harbourfront selling fish so fresh it it still flapping. Some say these places are expensive, maybe so, but the prices are not totally crazy. There are many other bars and small restaurants if you want to eat other than seafood, or more cheaply.Definitely a nice day out, especially if the weather is kind.

Best Seafood!. It's a very interesting area in which you can buy and eat all kinds of freshest seafood. I had my first lunch in 2015 there and I was extremely satisfied. Go there to share plates after plates of delicious seafood with your family, enjoy the seaside, people and dog watching, and long walk after eating all those seafood. A much needed break from Hong Kong's high-rise and busy streets.

Great nature destination with great seafood. Went to Sai Kung one evening for some nature and seafood. Fantastic bus ride through scenic forests. There are about a dozen or so restaurants on the dock all pretty much selling similar dishes of seafood. Pick your fish fresh, kill it and eat! The dish I had was a set, great value for money and some of the best seafood I have eaten. Not much more to do there but the seafood and hiking I am told. Well worth the 60 min trek out to Sai Kung if you have the time.

Interesting. This is a very nice place, this was a second visit for us. The water front is usually quite busy and if you like eating fish there are plenty of restaurants to choose from. Very few shops which is a change from all the big malls in Hong Kong. Given the time do venture out to Sai Kung
Hustle and bustle.... Great little fishing village, but charter a boat and head to Sharpe Island for an amazing beach and beautiful crystal sea

Local weekend quick getaways. Sai Kung is the eastern part of Hong Kong where it's situated around the sea. You can almost always see the sea on the ride into the outer skirt of Hong Kong. It is also the place to go if people want to get away from the City. Sai Kung is famous for its seafood eating culture, local dessert and specialty coffee shops. There are many beaches, national park and many cultural traces where you can explore. Many trails to walk on and many camp site or barbecue sites for the public to use. Really a great getaway for locals, especially it's at most 1 hour away from any part of Hong Kong by car.
Day trip. nice little fishing town, great to wander around on a Sunday afternoon. Superb range of seafood restaurants
Sai Kung day. sai kung day i go with my family sai kung day ~there are small board selling seafood ~~lt congested with traffic and tour groups, particularly at weekends.
Relaxing place. Good place to relax and eat seafood. You can see many small boat at pier and selling seafood.

My favorite seafood village. My favorite seafood village. Located less then an hour from Central. Beautiful nature. Good walking trails around it and the most important freshest seafood prepared the way you like it.

Chillout. Great place to chillout and take a boat trip to the surrounding islands. It's about an hour from Central and couldn't be any more different. Good selection of cafes and restaurants on the sea front.

Seafood with friends gathering place. Frankly speaking, the quality of seafood is neither superior to cuisines in most part of territory nor price is more valuable, but the overall ambience of the seafood market, promenade, sidewalk along the port, and lots of bars, fish and chips cafe...make up the environment look like away from Hong Kong. Transport is easy from city center, it's a very good place aging big group of friends meeting together having seafood, fun, dessert and beer too.
Is getting better and better. Is getting better and better, cleaner, more variety of cafes, still awesome seafood restaurants to choose. and a great getaway from the city.

A touch of old Hong Kong. Hong Kong seems to delight at being totally modern and at the leading edge of any technological innovation. It's tough to find much of the old Hong Kong - Sai Kung is one such place. The alley ways of the old town exude character. Somewhat disappointingly it is getting rather congested with traffic and tour groups, particularly at weekends. Excellent seafood restaurants line the waterfront, and there are some respectable international restaurants around the central square. Take the MTR to Choi Hung or Hang Hau and catch a minibus to Sai Kung. Relax and enjoy !
Awesome. Good place for hiking and seafood lovers. Nice and peaceful natural scenary. Some tourists come to Sai Kung just for hiking.

Love the trekking. Trekked from Man On Shan to Sai Kung. Was a relatively easy trail to walk on solo. Sai Kung has a very unique feel to it, with all the boats at the jetty and seafood restaurants around the area. you can be sure to taste the freshness and experience the surrounding.

Brilliant Fresh Seafood. We treated our Hong Kong hosts to an evening meal at Sai Kung. We selected our seafood from the great variety of live sea creatures swimming in the reasonably large tanks.Food was fabulous. Atmosphere rustic but great. Prices were cheaper than in the city but not cheap (about USD 70 per person).Well worth a trip from the city but better if you have locals to take you there.
One day trip. Weekend i always with my family come to countryside,西貢should be my favourite placeCan be fishing take photo andFresh seafood to taste itBut the price is expensive ~~

MacLehose Trail. Really good views of the Beaches when standing on top of the hills. Populations of the wild cattles are almost as many as tourists you see there, which reflect the rural park is well protected.

Amazing seafood & lots of dogs. The most unique place I have visited in HK. Almost every second person in the area will have a dog and its usually a small fluffy one. We had yum char and almost every outdoor table had a seat for the dog; similar situation at the cafes.Amazing seafood restaurants, although not cheap. Area gets very busy during the weekend.

Seafood and more seafood. We took our group of 12 to Sai Kung and they were delighted with the locals trading live fish and seafood from boats tied up to the wharf. We picked one of the seafood restaurants along the front and had the most authentic chinese feast of our trip. We caught three taxis from our Hotel with chinese written instructions from the hotel in chinese and each cost us about $30 Aud. Great trip.

The best beach and hiking in HK. This place is simply wonderful!!! In the crowd and stressing life of HK is possible to found a peaceful and wonderful nature. The hiking can be short (first stop in the first beach) or long....The beaches are simply wonderful and the waterfall unique. The best period is probably from Setember to December wherein the weather is not too hot(as well as the sea water) and clean. Also better going during the weekdays wherein the beaches are probably only for yourself....
Fish and other seafood.. Nice village in general (yes, there are villages in HK), but you go there to eat. Not cheap, but worth it if you like seafood. Enjoy!

where it feels not very hong kong. its a village by the sea. full of small restaurants and pubs. people are friendly, you will find a mix of locals and expats.if you don't have a car, you could get there by taxi or mini bus from Mong Kok or TKO.its worth the trouble.
Our favorite. Love the little village, the food is the best ever, especially the seafood restaurants and the Hardware store is the most amazing shopping ever

Hong Kong’s backyard. Sai Kung has been known as the “Hong Kong’s backyard”. It is around 45 mins away from the New Town Plaza in Shatin. Hong Kongers visit Sai Kung to catch a break from their daily stressful life. There are many restaurants alongside the beach and the piers. However, some of the Chinese seafood restaurants are obviously overpriced. Try to explore in those small alleys in the market… there are some fantastic food served with rather cheap price if you do not mind the environment… Residents in Sai Kung are usually very friendly so it is ok to ask around if you get lost. The beach near the Sai Kung pier is rather small and often crowed with people during weekend. You may take a ride to get into the “deeper Sai Kung” where there is exceptional beach and you can get closer to the mother nature.

camping that changed my life. crazy stories after another. Sai kung is a place that holds lots of memories for me. i was camping there during autumn last year, i went for hikings, trails, waterfalls, cliff diving, beaches, swimming. You can do almost everything there. it is one of the beat places to go. do try out camping though, it's fun :D read more here: http://www.trevellers.com/2013/11/27/deutsch-invasioncamping-in-sai-kung/

Carefully choose seafood restaurant. We were going to Sai Kung to eat seafood and have a bad experience, we chose live lobster and not cheap, when the lobster cooked we tasted it and it can tell it was not the live one we chose, we knew it was not live lobster as we had lots of eating lobster experience. We didn't say anything and will not go back again.

Quaint fishing village. We were disappointed with the restaurant there. They were not very interested in serving us as we were not locals. We did go on a san pan cruise with a little old lady for over an hour or so. Haggled over the price and ended up paying what we wanted. Very good value for the money.

See the Sea food!!. Nice to be out of the bustle of Hong Kong and eat a great sea food lunch. Some of the sea creatures on display could be from a science fiction movie! But it was great. Well recommended for a visit

amazing seafood. Absolute worth it to drive there for a delicious seafood-dinner. Lots of restaurants next to eachother. You choose the seafood from the shops in the street and the restaurant cooks it as your request.

A day in the "country". We love it here -- are living here now -- and would suggest a day, as it's a truly wonderful way to get out of the city, enjoy a kayak ride in clean air, amazing hiking with even more amazing views, great seafood restaurants and a charming old section of town. But, please don't come on weekends. There are WAY too many tourists then and we definitely don't need more!

A very different Hong Kong. Take the underground train to Hang Hau and a mini bus or taxi to Sai Kung. An old fishing village with lots of sea food restaurants, promanarde and ferries of to the local islands. A popular expat town with several good quality Western restaurants in the town square.

Could spend a week here. We went to Sai Kung by bus from the city - once we found the bus stop it was a really easy trip. As soon as we got here we hopped on board a boat which took us to an island to swim for the day - it was breathtaking! The lush green mountains beautiful blue water.. really an escape. I would certainly return here if given the opportunity. No doubt in my mind. For me it was right up there with the Caribbean.Once back to the village we walked around to all of the boats where people were selling FRESH seafood, I mean really, you can't get any fresher!The down side to the village for me - and only having a day here - was that I didn't know any of the restaurants and constantly felt like the waitstaff or restaurant managers were trying to get over on us. Lots of pressure to order very expensive food. So much so that we didn't eat anywhere, we got up from the table and went back to the city for dinner. I think that if we had a little more time to get to know the area we could have enjoyed some good seafood cuisine.Overall - great trip and I would definitely return
Not sure what the whole fuss is about. I've been there a few times as people keep raving about it but I still can't get the point, it's just like any village in Hong Kong, nothing special.

Sweet little fishing village, a break from Urban. People are lovely. Love this sweet little place. According to a friend who works in Hong Kong, this the The Seafood Village - Seafood, is apparently cheap here. But I'd say, go for the relaxing, beach side walk. I was lucky enough to visit on a Sunday, hence being able to be by the Sunday market, and witnessing families bringing their children out, dogs a-strolling. The setting is sweet, vendors are lovely, everyone is just lovely. Really nice place for getting in touch with nature (yes, take the hike option, that is), and for getting in touch with yourself, away from the bustle that is in Hong Kong Island/ Kowloon :)

Great place to get out of the city!!. Sai Kung is a bit far from the city centre but it is worth to go there. You can walk along the piers but since we were quite a big group, we rented a boat with the owner in order to get away from the mainland. We spent the whole day in the sea, swam in the middle of nowhere and wake boarded. Really nice getaway with a beautiful landscape!!

Good Seafood. Getting here can be quite a trip. Once you get here, buy the seafood directly from the fishermen. They are cheaper then you would buy it from the restaurant. You can bring to any of the restaurant and have them cook them for you. Of course it will cost you some $$$ and also you might have to buy a few of their dishes. Ask how much first before you give them your seafood to be prepare.It's not often that you would do this in Hong Kong and it's quite an experience.

Not a lot here but seafood. But that's the reason to head out here. You wont' do any better than select one of the great places on the waterfront here. Those guys over in Aberdeen have NOTHING on S.K. The white fish grilled and with vegetables are the best--even though everthing else in the tanks looks delectable. Given the bus transit times from Shatin, I recommend a taxi.

Best Undiscovered beach in HK !!. When you visit Saikung in Hongkong, there is a beach called as Pak la pon inside the National Geographic park. It is the best beach in hongkong which is very difficult to find.. Amazing clear blue n green water, white sands, amazing secnic beauty. But for reaching to this beach there is a hike of 1 hour which is really difficult n tiring but when u reach this beach all of its gone .. Must visit Place :)

Don't miss the waterfall in Sai Kung!. Beautiful beach, there is a waterfall nearby if you look hard enough for it where you can jump about 10 metres into the water.One or two cafes to buy warm food/water (and coconut water!) but not a huge choice.

A nice place for lunch!. Kind of the HK version of North Shore Long Island for Hong Kongers. Suburban, spectacular and diverse seafood, great outside dining right where the creatures are caught. If you are curious about the New Territories--this would be a worthwhile destination there.

Great place to visit and quite different from mainstream Hong Kong. This place is a great little beach front town away from the main areas of Hong Kong. Its in the New Territories and out in the Eastern area . We visited on a Saturday and it was great. You had locals walking their dogs, café and restaurants with large numbers of live fish for eating, down at the wharf there were boats tied up selling live fish to locals. The place had a real buzz.On top of this you can get boat shuttles out to the different islands as this area is more wilderness than dense high rise. A good place to visit if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.

A must-visit Place in Hong Kong. We went there for sightseeing and dinner. The boats docked below the water front are filled with different types of seafood, crabs, fishes, clams and so on. You may purchase and bring them to the restaurant and get the people to cook for you. Of course, you got to pay for the service charge. I had dinner at a restaurant called Chuen Kee. It is pricey but worth it. So delicious untill the next day, i return back for dinner again (I stayed in MongKok anyway). After dinner, you may head to Mun Kee for dessert. It is super nice too! Strongly recommended this place to any tourists.

Hiking & Paragliding in Sai Kung. Lovely place to visit in Sai Kung! Famous HK seafood restaurant, local desserts, boat trips from the pier ….. hiking in different small islands outside the port, paragliding from Ma On Shan down to the Sai Kung town …. haha it's all you can do!Sai Kung has been my favourite place to have seafood with family and visitor friends in HK! When friends come over, I would take them to eat seafood there! Currently I found that ppl could paraglide from Ma On Shan down to Sai Kung and the flying journey is obsoletely beautiful!!!! For more information, guys can visit www.x-flyhongkong.com for their tandem paragliding service. You don't need any flying skill but you just sit in front of the pilot and he will do the rest to fly you up in sky… if condition is allowed, he would drop you in Sai Kung from the Ma On Shan mountain. It's all depends on the wind and pilot's decision that day!

A relaxing Saturday activity. Visiting Sai Kung is a relaxing Saturday activity. Watch people buying all types of sea animals from the fishing dinghies moored at the wharf. Indicate what you want to buy, put your money in the net they use to reach up to the wharf and then receive your purchase. Take it to one of the restaurants lining the bay and have it cooked for lunch. Otherwise just choose from the fish/shellfish tanks outside the restaurants. Wander around the shops, or take a junk ride out to one of the islands , or just an hours trip around the islands and bay. There are many types of restaurants to choose from if you don't like seafood, Indian (Malaysian), pizza and Chinese.The 299 bus from Shatin will get you to Sai Kung.

Noisy and smelly. Disappointed with my visit here. The town is congested with traffic, seafood restaurants shabby, and worst of all the waterfront stinks! Sure, a view of the sea is nice but all in all not that pleasant.

Sai Kung for lunch. It was a beautiful spot along the water and the sea food was fresh and wonderful! One can take boats from there to tour around. We did not have the time for that. The restaurant that we ate in was called Sea Food Reataurant with a Michelin 1 star rating.

Short trip for Sea Food & Look-around .... Only had time to walk around Sai Kung city center (a rather small town center). It's charming! With many little cafes, eateries & food/snack stalls dotted in the narrow streets.. Perfect place for 'snack-hopping' from stall to stall.. trying out local traditional snacks/tidbits . Ended the short trip with a fabulous sea-food dinner at 全记 sea-food restaurant located at SeaFood Street. Very fresh sea food and not too pricy… personally rate is much better compared to those at Lamma Island . Surely.. will make another trip to Sai Kung!

Fish of every kind. We were only westerns there. Watching locals buy fish from boats was so interesting. Unfortunately we did not not have the confidence to buy fish from tanks at restaurants as menu not in English.

Dragon boat practice. Great waterfront area where you can watch dragon boats going in and around all afternoon while you take a coffee or tea. The promenade shops are fun and walking out along the water is always great
Fresh Fresh Fresh. is really good experience to travel at Sai Kung. all the seafood really fresh and nice, but not cheap. good to spent a day at sai kung, relax and enjoyable day trip.

Nasty-- noisy--. I find it very difficult to eat at one of these huge beside the street places where they clean the tables with filthy dishrags gray with use, where no consideration can be given to any deviation to the menu, and where it is just a huge mass of people rushing through to order and eat as fast as they can. Just not my idea of good eating.

Great Little Fishing Town. If you like seafood this is the place to come. This place used to be a quiet little fishing town but now it has turned into more of a tourist destination. Worth a visit though. There are some great restaurants here and the local area is quite pretty.

If you can handle the hour traffic jam..... I like Sai Kung, I really do...but the insanity of the standard 30 mins traffic jam to get in and out you have to wonder if it's worth the trip! Some good restaurants and shops, and the scenic country park about 5 miles further...

Lovely place with an impressive sea food. We actually went there twice. It is a lovely place and lots of hikes start there. You can also go on a short trip on a boat - they will take you around some island and then drop you on a beach, from where you can be collected later. This is the place for a sea food lover - the choice is the most impressive in Hong Kong. We have not tried it and ate in different restaurants, but - IMHO - you can try whatever you want. Everything is available.Lots of little eateries available as well as small shops.Sai Kung is worth visiting on weekends - it is crowded but little ladies with their perfectly groomed dogs (often carried in a baby stroller) are definitely unforgettable!

Nice place if you like fish .... A bit of a pain to get to and park but otherwise an interesting mix of fish retailers, shops and restaurants.It seems to be much more humid here than downtown HK, don't ask me why ... I'm not really one for pointing out particular fish in a tank to eat within the next 20 mins, but if you like that sort of thing you're in the right place. Lovely fresh fish are in abundance here, as are their accompanying restaurants, plus a nice mix of other restaurant-types, too, if you need.I found it a bit cruel that the fishermen left their catch gasping for water on the ground for all to see, especially the horse-shoe crabs ... mind you it doesn't surprise me considering the other things I've seen in China.Interesting place overall - if you like fish, that it ...
Interesting enclave.... It was very interesting to watch the locals buying fresh catch from the sea from the sampans at the pier.

Get your fish on!. I like heading to Sai Kung when in town. While the seafood is so abundant most everywhere, the vibe and feel of sitting out cafe style, choosing your (insert seafood type here) alive and kicking makes for a wonderful experience. Prices are reasonable, and the tourism is heavy, but mostly Asians, not Americans or Europeans.It's a very wealthy area, so you see the beautiful people walking their beautiful dogs kind of place! Lots of expats too. Don't miss this, and certainly leaps above Tai O for selection and cleanliness.

Local tourist attraction to be avoided. Difficult to get to, expensive to get to. Difficult to get a taxi to leave. Unclean environment. Lack of English at restaurants. Dirty bathrooms. Price nickel and diming (gouging) at restaurant (for tea and drink set-up). Why bother?????

seafood anyone?. ask anybody, or any local, and they'll tell you sai kung is famed for its seafood.true, famed it is, but, imho, undeservedly so. why? sai kung's seafood restaurants mostly cater to the touristic crowd on weekends, and this includes the many locals who happen to go to sai kung for a trek, family walk, family outing, …i've had the bad experience of being 'openly' ripped off by some restaurant.i chose a set menu and during the course of it they came up several times explaining they had run out of king praws, salmon, etc.yes, you get it… all expensive items were suddenly sold out and were proposed to be exchanged for cheaper varieties.could i have walked out in the middle of a meal, without paying?? maybe or maybe not.i experienced this on 2 occasions!hence, my favorite seafood place in the whole of hong kong must be lei yue mun (near tsueng kwan o) on kowloon side. that's where the freshest and cheapest (comparatively speaking, i.e. bang for the buck) seafood can be had!

My Most Memorable in Hongkong. Sai Kung is far from the main island of Hongkong. Not many Filipino tourists have gone there. But I had to go there to visit a friend who has been living there for close to a decade. We had to take a train ride from Times St., and we were met by my friend. We still had to drive from the train station to go to Sai Kung. It is a neat place. We had lunch at a dimsum place, and their food was delish! We went to the seaside where they had a lot of seafoods for sale, and also a lot of souvenir items. And, I have never seen so many dog breeds in one place! What a charming day it was! The next time I go there, I will charter a boat from Hongkong Island to Sai Kung. My friend said that it was quite cheap. Or maybe she was talking in US dollars?

Busy but great beaches to enjoy the sun. Great place to take a picnic and enjoy the sun. it get very busy on the weekends so get there early. The bus ride over is nice and will give you a good overview of life outside the busy Central district.

Busy and too touristy. There are some great places here, but avoid weekends as too busy and do not patronise the seafood restaurants along the waterfront. They are an absolute ripoff, much better food elsewhere in Hong Kong. Try Mui Wo, Lamma island or Cheung Chau.

Still the same..just. Sai Kung village used to be a special place to go. Thank goodness it still is although I fear its quaintness in the near future will be ruined through development. Good walks, fresh air, fresh seafood.
worth a trip. Great to see parts of HK that are more remote. Hiking and boating and camping, as well as awild herd of cows to see on Grassy Island!
Quaint Village. Took us a little while to travel the distance but it was worth the trek. Recommend strolling through the old town before enjoying your fresh seafood feast!
Brilliant Sea Food Dining Experience. A great night out and we ended up dining with a Nobel Peace Prize recipient who was on an adjoining table!! This is a must do for anyone who loves seafood.

Strolling in Sai Kung.. We used the MRT and local bus to visit Sai Kung with some friends. This is a good break from crowded Kowloon as you can walk around in this suburb very easily. There are numerous seafood restaurants, and some very popular fresh " tanks" of seafood. Don't expect any bargains here, but the food will be very fresh.There are beaches here to enjoy and not all that crowded. I suppose it depends on the day you visit.You can also walk down the jetty and bargain with fisher folk for a ride in a Sampan. We did this and enjoyed an hour out on the harbour for a very reasonable price. Arrived back at the jetty not long before a cracker of a downpour hit the place.If it looks like rain, carry an umbrella, you will be glad you had it.

Excellent Place for seafood and golf. Sai Kung is a favorite place for expat, good seafood and other European restaurants. Get the ferry to the Golf Cource at the Pier run by HK Jockey Club. You could get away from the overcrowded Hong Kong for a day and enjoy the beautiful nature parks as well. So many destination and routes you could choose from Sai Kung. Expected to spend a day there.

From Beach to Seafood. Been there many times with friends and families. Sai Kung offers many outdoor activities and government managed parks. Locals visit Sai Kung for hiking, beach, swimming, sight seeing, offshore fishing, BBQ, picnic and visit live seafood restaurants (fish tanks lined up along the street for viewing and shopping). Public transportation is the best options as parking is limited. A few spots are very remote where public transportation is very limited. Some can only be reached via local fishing boat (can be arranged in advance). Sai Kung center is about 45 min away from TST in Kowloon via Taxi. Summer is warm so pick a AC restaurant for better dinning experience. Some restaurant offer roof top dinning area (if you are lucky to feel the sea breeze) Weekend and public holidays are SUPER BUSY. Traffic jam and ocean of people packed the area. Do make advance reservation for dinner. Shop around for live seafood (common dishes). Those closer to the center cost more but they are conveniently located/popular. Speak Cantonese do help or have a friend take you around. Written note will help ordering at restaurants. My advise for 1st timer: get there and have dinner so that you are familiar with the logistic (2-3 hours experience). For second and more visit: Pick a spot for some outdoor activity and then have dinner (full or half day excursion). Have fun :)
loaf on. loaf on was so yum !request a table on the ground floor. the little town is enchanting wish we had more time to explore it

Nice change of view. Take one of the boat tours (very inexpensive) for a 1/2 hour tour on the water. You can get off at one of the islands and spend the day on the beach - there are regular boats that will come back and you can catch back. Be sure to take your own water/food. Beach atmosphere. The seafood restaurants are awesome. Use the mini green bus for a more of an "express" trip. Otherwise, if you catch the regular bus, it will take double the time to get there and will stop at every single bus stop. The mini green buses stop only when they have an opening. They carry only 16 people. All buses are air conditioned.

Sea Food Must. Here is the real Hong Kong life relaxed and far away from the daily life. Easy to reach by Taxi or Public Transportation. Weekends are crowded with HK Residents from Hong Kong Island or Kowloon. Good Seafood restaurants at the promenade which may be a little expensive - calculate HKD 1500 - 2000.00 per 4 persons (with lobster dish)

Escape the city. A lovely fishing town near to the MacLehose trail. Didn't stay there but a good place to get the connections to and from the trails. Looked interesting with a sea front area, jetty and shops and restauarants

Hong Kong Sai Kung. Beautiful bay area surround with beautiful trees and scene with clear water for swimming and water-sports, excellent scene with water-dam and reservoir plus little island for boating, k-car racing, fishing, BBQ and recreation, superb sea-food of all kinds mostly just catch from the deep sea and varieties of food for food-lovers, and many trials and scene for joggers, bikers and dog-strollers. Whatever kinds or objectives you are, you will definitely find one or more suitable thing for you to spend a whole day there. Last but not least, the air quality there is fresh and superb ,and of course, the trees and mountains there are green.
Perfect day out on the water. Hire a sampan and head out to the sea arch. It's beautiful! Enjoy a lunch in Sai Kung after a morning out on the water. Go before it starts to get cool.
Hard to find but worth it. Very nice village at the new territories. Go there if you want to try fresh seafood. Also you can find very nice and empty beaches in this area.

Beautiful.. A lovely area by the sea with a village feel and some superb seafood restaurants. People are friendly and more relaxed than in the big city. Sai Kung is another world and thoroughly worth the journey there. Go on a weekday if you can to avoid the weekend day trippers.
Fabulous walk. We drove up, got the boat across the bay and took a fine walk over the hill to the beach on the far side. Magical stuff

Excellent for light travelling.. This is one of the most popular hiking, swimming areas like Tai Long Bay, Long Ke...Pleasant walk for family or friends. The road are well set with lot of good guide around the whole route. There are also some popular Geopark with lots and lots of interesting land features like interlocking spur, headland .... At last but not the least, please don't forget the famous delicious Egg Tart on sales at Sai Kung Mkt on the way back!

Worth the visit. If you have time, it's worth a visit just to see the onboard fish markets at the main piers and to hop on a boat for a visit around Sai Kung Country Park. Sai Kung country park is full of little islands and beaches. If you walk around to the second bay you can rent at a very reasonable price a canoe and canoe around the islands. I did it with the kids and they loved it, though the sudden thunder storm on the water turned out to be a bit more of an adventure than we were really looking for !! It's also quite an experience just to view the seafood fish tanks at the door of all the restaurants at the pier

great fishing village. get out and about to see some country side , hong kong is not all about city lights,take a day trip to Sai Kung, great little fishing village , plenty of wonderful species to eat. you can even charter a boat to cruise the islands. mix of old and new - the old village and some new shops as well , great food too!

Wonderful fishing area. We recently visited with locals who were able to tell us a bit about the temple to the fisherman, the local restaurants and that buying fish directly from the fisherman's boats is cheaper! Only if you can speak Cantonese though - otherwise there will be a lot of pointing and hand gestures. Thoroughly enjoying seeing all the goings on off the back of the boats. You can take a day trip via boat to the National Park - definitely coming back to do this.

Lovely area and beautiful beaches. Sai Kung is the second largest district of HK. There's some really nice beaches along this island. If you like seafood this is the place to be, it's also very nice picturesque area where you can take some really nice pictures and at sunset I recommend be by the beach - it's a beautiful scene.

Seafood Restaurant Heaven. Sai Kung is a picturesque harbour village of fishing boats and yachts about 40 minutes drive from Kowloon. Apparently it is a very popular place for locals to visit on weekends because of the fabulous seafood restaurants that line the waterfront boardwalk. I ate at the Tung Kee Seafood Restaurant and the food was sensational. You pick the live seafood that you want from huge fish tanks and then they cook it in one of the house specialty ways. Definitely worth the drive.

For the seafood and something different from the busy city life.. the must try is the seafood feast when you are there!!! This is my second time at Saikung for the second time. I would recommend to go at around late afternoon so you could see the changes in the landscape while dining. :)

Interesting way of selling seafood!. Went there with my friend's uncle n bought some seafood directly from the fishermen in their fishing boats. it was a wonderful experience as we got to see the various fresh seafood on offer.Worth going for a day for the experience

A different view of HK. We set off from Nan Lian Gardens, getting the bus from across the road (outside the chi lin nunnery entrance). Bus ride was great and took us through soe beautiful spots. Arrived in Sai Kung which has all sorts of places to eat - including a McD's. We hired a Sampan for $400 for a family of four for two hours - it took us all around the rocks and the geo park. It could have dropped us off at a beach and collected us later but just being on the boat and seeing the rock formations was lovely. really nice but not sure we would do it again.

Seafood and outdoor activities. Sai Kung is out in the country side of Hong Kong. Its about 30 minutes drive from Tsim Sha Tsui. In "downtown" Sai Kung, there are many seafood restaurants on the water. The big ones have huge seafood display with live fish, shrimp, lobster, clams, snails, eels etc. The most impressive are the giant garoupas. On the weekend, there are also small boats parked along the pier and coast selling live seafood. These are sold in buckets with price tags. When you buy some, the fisherman will bag it up and "hand" it up to you using a long handled net. You then put the money into the net. Besides eating, you can also go to various islands, boat tours through the many ferries that start from Sai Kung.

Good base for a junk trip. Get a cab to Sai Kung. Its just easier. Stock up on food and drink at the local stores at the pier and then head out to your junk trip. Its an experience not to be missed. I can't vouch for the sea food because I didnt get the chance to try it, but many people recommend it.

A blend of the old and new. Situated in the New Territories, a train and bus ride away from Hong Kong Island, Sai Kung is a place bustling with life. It is possible to take a two hour-long walk that takes you from the old Chinese Hong Kong to residential areas in which 'ex-pats' or Westerners live. At one end of the main commercial district is an interesting Taoist Temple and old quarter full of restaurants and shops selling good ranging from French and Dutch cheeses to Chinese incense and paper replicas for burning at the temple. It is easy to spend an hour wandering the narrow streets. Next to the old quarter is the Wet Market which sells fresh vegetables, fish still wriggling in buckets, meat, tofu and many other foods. Next, walk along the sea front for a kilometre or so and look over the side of the pier to watch local Hakka people selling fish from their small boats. If you wish, you can buy some fish -- choose your fish which will be hoisted up to you in dish on a rope and pulley, then put your money in the dish which will be lowered back to the seller below. After your walk, select a seafood restaurant on the seafront or one of the many the multi-national restaurants located in streets behind.

Great seafood. Sai Kung is worth the trip. Great seafood. Fresh as you can get.Amazing tanks full of all types of seafood out the front of seaside restaurants. The town is also interesting to walk through and look around. Take a wonder through locals food market.Its a bit wet and smelly. But worth the look.

Coastal turistic village out of the mainstream. This is a place mainly for locals although very touristic. It is out of the well-known touristic mainstream but if you have time its worth a visit. Very nice sea-side place where you can get boat trips and even diving (although HK is not the place for diving ...). Many restaurants with seafood around.

Perfect pier-side seafood. The trip to Sai Kung was filled with wonderful sceneries.
Rows of shop houses along with a splendid selection of fresh seafood. Prices were reasonable.
we have 6 tasteful dishes of fresh seafood at an estimated SGD90 .
Worth the visit

gateway to Hong Kong outdoors. We stayed in Sai Kung (Lung Mei village- dragon's tail village) for two months and we enjoyed every moment of it! Sai Kung is the gateway to the most beautiful country parks in Hong Kong. Almost entire Sai Kung area is a country park. We did so many hikes out of here. There are buses and ferry out of here and go to popular hiking spots or beaches everyday or on the weekends/holidays. You can easily find information online or join local meetup hiking group. Sai Kong town itself is worth a day trip to explore. It was a old fishing town and still has it old charm. Floating villages dock their boats with all kinds of live fish or shellfish selling directly on the dock. Few seafood restaurants line up along the oceanfront with massive display of seafood in tanks. Many tourist come here for the famous seafood feast. Many old sampan boats take people out exploring endless islands around with stunning views and interesting volcanic geo formations. You can rent a party boat too!So if you visit Hong Kong, try to make at least a day trip to Sai Kung, better to combine a hike, you will see the most stunning views of islands and will be surprised by how much beauty Hong Kong can offer

Small Place. We visited Sai Kung in June. Sai Kung is a small place and it don't have much things except there were many seafood restaurants. The price was quite expensive and the food was ok. There were not many shops or place of interest for tourists. I won't go there again if I were to visit Hong Kong.

Over-rated & Expensive. I was told by local Hongkongers not to go because it has become very touristy & prices have gone up a lot over the years.... only tourist go. The seafood at Tin Wan in Aberdeen is cheaper & fresh - just as good. If you go to the New Terrirories, the seafood gets cheaper... & that's where locals go.

Not Fishing and Not Village. I took a break to go to this place during my Hong Kong visit because of the rave reviews. The first thing I noticed that, while marketed as the "Sai Kung Fishing Village", it was not a village at all, more like a mid-sized town (I think the population is ~12,000). If you therefore expect an authentic Hong Kong fishing village experience, you'll be disappointed.Next thing I noticed was that there wasn't much fishing going on. At the very edge of the town there was a fishing boat harbor (I didn't see any actual fishermen), but the vast majority of the shore is taken up by the promenade, which is anything but fishing-related. The promenade is just a large commercialized space for water sports and transport boats to nearby islands. Maybe one of those has a fishing village? I don't know. I didn't take a boat, and in any case none of the boat operators seem to speak English, so unless you know exactly where you want to go, talking to them is pointless (unless you speak Cantonese).The prices all around are on the expensive side—the seafood restaurants can have prices double of those in Hong Kong/Kowloon, and the food is not especially different.Going into the town itself, it's actually somewhat nice, in that it's much less crowded than Hong Kong, but overall it's unremarkable. There is a Buddhist temple on the main street, a public square and... that's pretty much all.I leave some hope that the atmosphere on the islands is more authentic, you can go there by boat. However, you really need to know where you're going in advance, I assumed that for a tourist area this wouldn't be difficult to figure out. I was wrong.

Beautiful, cheap windsurfing/kayaking. Although it's starting to get developed, it still keeps a lot of its fishing village charm, with fishermen selling their catches off their boats right off the pier.
