Lots of paid tours take you out to the geological reserve, but my favourite part is the beautiful scenery, and the fact that you can rent kayaks and windsurf boards for ridiculously cheap prices. Then you paddle around and explore the islands in this sheltered bay.

A Great Day Out. A true escape from the bustling city of HK, in an environment that is certainly more relaxing. A stroll in the promenade and in the public pier (there are two) is a rewarding experience. Take the time to watch the fishermen in their boats by the pier to segregate their catch in different containers: live fish and seafood for sale to whoever is interested. The village itself offers a temple and a wide range of shops from Starbucks and McDonalds to classic chinese street restaurants. But the main offering is its seafood restaurants. For the Brits that miss home there is even a fish and chips shop (Chip In).The 'must' visit restaurant for seafood lovers is Chuen Kee (any of the many by the pier). It is a Michelin recommended restaurant also endorsed by famous food writer Chua Lam. You can choose from a number of set menus with many offers. We chose the set menu for two where we could order 4 dishes out of the 14 offered.We chose sauteed lobster with noodles and cheese sauce (apparently the shop's speciality), stir-fried clams with black bean sauce, steamed fish with ginger and spring onions, steamed crab with chinese wine, a vegetable dish (pakchoi with garlic), and fruit (watermelon). The cost of these was HK$418 which is a real bargain considering that all the dishes were in full portions.We returned to HK with the 16 seater 1A minibus as suggested by other contributors who we thank for their suggestions. A wonderful day out which we strongly recommend!

Fantastic place to stay... Quiet, beautiful and full of fish...... Sun, sand and fish.... If you love your seafood this is the place to stay. Fresh seafood restaurants clutter the seafront offering all sorts of delicacies, the pubs are friendly and offer reasonably priced drinks, all the amenities you need and readily available public transport with the nearest MTR station 1 hour away by the 101M (8$HK) bus or 25mins by taxi ($100HK)The streets are small and busy and full of sights and smells along with some familiar favorites. There is a quaint seafront which is teaming with locals relaxing in the sun and regular boat trips to the local islands. Overall this is a fantastic place to stay away from all the hustle and bustle of city life while keeping it close at hand.

Great Place for seafood lovers!. Took a mini bus which too more than an hour to get there. Interesting drive, however our mini bus broke down & the bus driver hailed another bus for us. As it was a different company we had to pay the fares again! The feel there is so different from rest of Hong Kong as one of my friend exclaimed " we arrived south of France!" It is a pretty charming area by the sea coast with lots of small boats around. Many are fishermen who bring in their catch to sell direct to the tourists there. We bought a big squid, prawns, fish,shell fish, clams...whatever they could offer we bought a bit. There is a restaurant at one end which will cook for a fee and we ordered a plate of vegetables and drinks from them. They charge a sum for cooking. As our Hong Kong friends knew the owner of the restaurant we were able to book a table easily. Quite a fascination for some & it's something different one can do in Hong Kong!

Sai Kung - a day out with fish. Sai Kung Town is a great day out with fish. Eat them, swim with them and of course purchase them to take home. I am never against small fisheries even though I am an environmentalist. I am aware that some of the fish comes from Indonesia and Malaysia - sadly. The key to eating fish is to eat local and eat fresh and challenge imports and big specimens are likely to be from elsewhere. However in Sai Kung - you can eat vegetarian if you prefer - a trim and tasty breakfast at Jaspas - lunch at Sri Lankan AJs and afternoon tea at a cafe that sells sublime mango jam, Let's Jam. I love strolling the alley ways - the is a the galvanised steel bucket maker, the lion dance costume maker and the best car park views across the bays. Wonderful....
give the dogs a run. many restaurants seafood , chinese and western can take the dogs of the lead and have a a great stretch of there legs and a beer for yourself

Great Getaway. We went to Sai Kung pier and hired a boat to take us to one of the island beaches for 30hk dollars return ticket. The beach was so clean and the water was clear. It was a great getaway from the crowds and we had the whole beach to ourselves!

A Must-visit for Sea Food and the Quiet. After visiting Nan Lian Garden, I read up online and followed the directions on how to get to Sai Kung. I was surprised with the number of sea food restaurants on site. The atmosphere was more relaxed than the rest of Hong Kong, with tiny shops and quaint cafes that took my time checking them out, It looked like a small community of artists are beginning to build shops in the place. It was atmospheric and chilled- out. Worth a visit if you extra days in HK.

Place for seafood. It is a pleasant experience as I met someone who introduced me to an evening concert, free of charge.There is a swimming pool in Sai Kung. The sea food is excellent and reasonably priced.On the whole a wonderful experience.

Worth the visit. Sai Kung is worth the trip. Great seafood. Fresh as you can get.Amazing tanks full of all types of seafood out the front of seaside restaurants. The town is also interesting to walk through and look around. Take a wonder through locals food market.Its a bit wet and smelly. But worth the look.

Seafood galore!. I thought Hong Kong was all about tall buildings and more tall buildings! A short ride from downtown and you are out in the country. Sai Kung is a lovely fishing town, where the boats tie up beside the promenade to sell their catch, and there are several outdoor restaurants where the fish are kept alive in tanks, just waiting for you to select which one you want for dinner!Parks for the kids to play in, and lots of little shops to browse through.A good destination when in Hong Kong!!

For seafood lovers. Sai Kung offers you a great place to walk around, see some small fishing boats and taste the most fresh fish and seafood. Kids will love to see the many variety of live sea creatures as they are displayed in each of the many restaurants. I love to go there and walk around.
Seafood at Sai Kung. There are few seafood restaurant near the Sai Kung Pier (last stop of green mini bus. If happen you choose Chuen Kee Restaurant, you must try their famous lobster spaghetti.

Another side of HK!. I had no idea that there was 'another' side to HK! (Other than the high rises, bright lights and frenetic crowds.) And this side was so much nicer! A bit out of the way, but using the exceptional public transport systems/bus, we got off at Sai Kung Geo Park for a look-see, then took a 11km circular walk through the undulating hills of the peninsula. Lovely views and attractive, pristine beaches, clean air. Altogether well worth the effort. And Sai Kung town is a lovely little place, with a bit to see: waterfront, temple, place that sells english teas, and just masses of lovely seafood restaurants. So make a point of getting out of the city and visiting! You won't be sorry.

a gem to visit in HK. if you want to see HK 30 years ago, go to Sai Kung! Most areas are still in ther 1980s other than some new buildings along the water front. No high rises that poke into our eyes and you can see the nature looking into the ocean side.
Nice place. I love here. Many many thing happen here and they are the best memories of us. I want to eat sea food and stay here before

It will remain in my memory. If you go to Sai Kung. Then visit also the bay of 'Hoi Ha wan'. There you can snorkle (yes the water is clear ad fine and there are no sharks). There are some magnificent coral reefs. But please respect the natural environment if you snorkle there. There are a few reefs, and they like to preserve it. You can take public bus number 7 to Hoi Ha Wan from Sai Kung. Love is in the air at Hoi Ha Wan.

Laid-back spot by the sea.. Sai kung is a little laid back village by the sea. A great spot to get away from the crowds of the cbd, and the many seafood restaurants in the area have some of the freshest and tastiest offerings around, without the big hit on your wallet you would experience elsewhere, eg causeway bay or kowloon.If you have a couple of hours free during your time in hong kong, sai kung will be well worth your time for a visit.

Visit. A wonderful village on the bay in Hong Kong. The village is charming. The restaurants are great and everything utterly fresh taken from the longest line of fish tanks you will ever see! You can hire a ride on the water and that is lovely. A great place to see!

Quaint Experience. It was a fishing village in the past. Nowadays, people take the ferry from the port to other islands. We went there on a Sunday. Many families took their dogs out for a stroll. The spread of seafood being offered at the restaurants is eye-boggling. We were told that we might sight some celebrities there but sadly no! We were there rather early. The walk inward towards the residential areas, market and town square gave an interesting insight to how the locals live. The trip there by the mini-bus was rather terrifying!

Where time stands still. This is my favourite place in all of Hong Kong. The old meets the new. Fabulous western restaurants and Chinese fish restaurants sit side by side. At the jetty you can hire a boat and visit the islands. I thoroughly recommend Yim Tin Tsi which is being made into a heritiage village. Boats leave on the hour every weekend. Take a hike to the beautiful Tai Long Wan beach and Ham Tim. Marvellous views.

Out of the way. Sai Kung is still a popular place for expats to live, although a bit out of the way, you would need a car if you lived out at Sai Kung. Is a lovely beach area and the air is clearer too, nice expat shop selling Australian foods and wines at good prices is called "The Bottel Shop", lots of lovely bush walking and swimming and canoeing, go if you have the time!http://thebottleshop.hk/shop/about_us

Best place to have dinner after hiking in the area. The village itself is nice, with many tourist both local and expat hanghing around. The pier is an amazing view, with all fisherman down in the water selling their fish to custoemrs on the dock. They use kind of basket and stick to exchange fish and money. In the area around there are many hinking, some very long other quiteshort and easy, for all kind of expectation. All of them are easy to find in the indication around there or on internet. If you want you can take some boat and go visit the floating restaurants some km away from the village itself. And you can also use those boat to arrive to the best beach of HK, Tai Long Wan. In the evening is a must to try one of the many restaurand on the sea, where you can choose your own fresh (=alive) fish and try the real local experience. Be brave and try what they suggest you!

Great hiking area. Sai Kung is a lot of people's (both tourist and local's) favorite beaches in HK and I can see why. It took a long time to get there and it felt like the place we got dropped off was in the middle of no where. If you're a traveler that loves to hike like me, then I definitely recommend Sai Kung. There are some areas where I needed to grab onto trees and then other areas with a nice path. We hiked for a good while and ended up at a cool area where we can swim. You can also climb the rocks and jump off of the top into the pool of water. The jump isn't that high, it was just exciting to find a great spot. When we were there, there were locals there just chillin and having a picnic. After a while, we hiked out and down to the beach. The views along the way were breathtaking. Once you get to the beach, it's is pretty cool. The fishing village has fresh seafood and you can pick the fish you want to eat before they cook it for you. It's definitely a day long adventure so plan ahead. Also, I recommend to bring, good sneakers, swim suit, water and a camera. Go see Sai Kung for yourself!

Best Beach in Asia - Tai Long Sai Wan in Sai Kung. Tai Long Sai Wan, I would say, is the best beach in terms of views, accessibility and supporting. It is a 45 mins leisure walk from Sai Wan bus stop. A 4-hr walk within the region would let you feel how great is the area, Tai Long Beach, Tai Long East Beach and Ham Tin Beach.

Popular with young expats before hitting the clubs. it's a long bus ride in the dark but this place is great to go out to for a few pre clubbing drinks and dinner and also if you enjoy seafood.Unfortunately I missed the floating markets, however having visited a lot of the lesser known fishing villages know that tere much less touristy and more authentic places to visit like Tai-O where the houses are built on stilts, street vendors stoking their little drum bqqs and little winding laneways full of things to discover.You'll find a lot of bizarre fish of every size and description like many other areas and you can choose and have cooked, but if an animal loving vego like myself might find it a little upsetting.I got there too late at night to really explore as much as I would have liked and had limited days in Hong Kong to come back, although if it had been exceptional would have made the time.Best for nightlife.

Super fresh fish and seafood. Not for the faint hearted as you can see your fish and seafood before its cooked. Get a table overlooking the fishing harbour - it will cost you a bit more at these restaurants, but the view is worth it.

Local fishing village and very good seafood. Sai Kung is a little ways away along the coast from the busy part of Kowloon. Attraction: fishing boats and seafood restaurants with lots of live fish in tanks. Take the MTR to the Choi Hung station, exit C-2, and take the 1A minibus on a 20 minute ride over the hills to Sai Kung, which is the last stop on the 1A line, so you know where to get off. Walk to the seawall at the bus stop area and turn left. You'll find several restaurants. We went to Chuen Kee restaurant which is popular with the Chinese and was recommended on a T.V. food program. It was very good fresh seafood, the price is reasonable, and the service was attentive and helpful. Take the 1A minibus back to the Choi Hung MRT station. You can find Sai Kung and Chuen Kee restaurant on the internet.
Quieter place, great food. Great place to go for seafood or western style dishes. Nice walk along the seaside, also some nice beaches (so i've heard), a nice getaway from the city

Seafood paradise. Along the promenade you have a wide variety of restaurants to choose from, each showing in tanks what they have.It's also nice to take a walk around and snap pics at the many boats out in the bay.For a table in the best restaurants you can have to wait quite a long time.Prices are definitely affordable even if not a complete bargain like in other parts of HK.In my opinion for seafood lovers it is a must-go spot.

fishy place to eat. When in Hong Kong go over to Sai Kung through the eastern tunnel and head for the water front where there are loads of resteraunts with the live produce happily splash about in tanks. Local fishermen sit below the piers selling their wares. Go and eat where the locals eat, you will have to wait for a table but it is worth it.
Great seafood restaurants. Sai kung is a great place to go and walk along the beach and to eat at one of the many restaurants where you can choose the fresh seafood you would like to eat.

Local fish. To savour the tastes of local fish, Sai Kung is a must. A reasonably short and inexpensive bus ride will take you right to the promenade where you can see the local fishermen brining in the daily catch and selling direct from the samll boats. Then you can eat at one of the many seafood specialist restaurants to provide an added bonus to the trip.

Nice and Relaxing. This is a nice place to visit. The walk along the waterfront is so refreshing. Many pedlars are seen selling fresh seafood. There is a famous shop selling the best "por lor pau" I have ever tasted in Sai Kung. Not to be missed!
oasis!. i took a taxi there and spend more time than i should. beautiful trails and had a delicious seafood lunch after picking my own seafood! got to go!
Quiet and serene. I love this hamlet. Fantastic scenery and vibe, plus great seafood. Go out on a sampan. It is fantastic.
Worth the visit. Good place to see a different side to HK, waterfront, fishmongers, restaurants, easy bus and taxi access.

Sea Food Paradise. If you like seafood, your dinner will be alive in a tank, caught fresh that day, waiting for you. Whether snapper, grouper, abalone or lobster is your favourite, you will find the fresh taste extraordinary compared to shop bought 'fresh'

Great little place by the sea. Couple of the big Chinese restaurants displays their fresh seafood in aquariums and customers basically choose what they want. The price of the seafood item is one thing, then there is the fee for cooking them!! So do not think its going to be cheap or reasonable. Its one of those do it once for the experience.

Do Yourself A Favour. Hop on a bus and spend the day in this lovely area.
If seafood is not your fancy, we had the best pizza here outside of Italy.
There is a lovely bookshop along the boardwalk where you can go upstairs to sit on a lovely lounge with amazing views and grab yourself a bargain amongst the secondhand books.

Sai Kung Country Park. Brilliant. Had a wonderful day walking with the company Walk Hong Kong in this huge Country Park. Walked to two villages that have no road access. Sensational. Highlight of entire holiday

Peaceful and pet friendly. I went to have a walk there with my friends and since we arrived I felt calm. Excellent place if you just want to scape from the pollution and noisy city. You can see many dogs, a floating sea food market and also if you have time (2 hours), can take a boat tour (50 Hkd) to the island around Sai Kung with the option to stay in the island for the time that you prefer.

Perfect Winter Outing. Beautiful Green-Blue Water, boats carrying fish, lovely sea food restaurants with sumptuous set lunches and different breeds of dogs being walked by their owners, Sai Kung is the perfect attraction for those wanting to spend a nice day away from the hustle-bustle of Hong Kong City. A dog lovers Haven, Sai Kung has plenty to offer. There are boats which take you to different islands and villages near Sai Kung which is an added bonus. We took 1A from Dundas Street in Mong Kok and before we knew it we were in Sai Kung. This was by far one of the best impromptu plans ever!
Great Seafood. This is a place you must go! Incredible on a lovely day. Sit outside, enjoy seafood however you would like to. Not to be missed.

Amazing harbor and seafood. The water's edge is lined with seafood restaurants. Fisherman pull up to the water wall with fresh catches. Sai Kung is well worth the long van ride and you can follow up lunch with a walk along the nearby dog park. Sai Kung is difficult to get to because you need to know the van routes that will take you there. Of course, you can hop on a taxi but it is a long ride from the center of things.

Laid-back quiet fishing village close to Kowloon, good day trip. This is a good break from the bustling, noisy Hong Kong; I took the small yellow bus 1A from Dundas St in Mong Kok, only HK$15 each way, 40 minutes ride to Sai Kung.Its a fishing village with good seafood restaurants along the harbour front, though not that cheap and a bit touristy. Many offer a set menu from HK$300 / £25 plus. Its cheaper to go a couple of streets inland and eat with the locals. I visited Sushi Tenku and had a great set lunch for HK$100 / £8.The village has a similar feel to Stanley or Aberdeen on the HK island south side. Shopping is less good though. Quite a few expats stay here as they get a bigger flat/living space and quieter, cleaner living environment than in central Kowloon.There are boat trips to the out-lying islands. A nice day trip.

Long hike, away from the city. Winter time tip: No speedboat will come for you - plan an early hike, unless you'd like to night hike back to the road to get a cab. Would say its an intermediate hike good for those who find Dragon's Back and Twins piece of cake.

Hong Kong’s Village. Don’t call me mad if I ask you the question have you seen a village in Hong Kong. Sai Kung is just that – a fishing village nestled in the Sai Kung peninsula in the New Territories of the north-east. The history of this village dates back to the year 1400 and despite all the new developments in Hong Kong Sai Kung retains its rural character. The MTR has not yet made its debut here. So, to reach Sai Kung your last MTR stop is Diamond Hill and from there you take the bus. Sea food eateries are the life line of this place and the choice is enormous and here you can choose your fish and get them cooked to your liking. The promenade is a great place to meander. For hikers Sai Kung is a delight and they can lose themselves to the charms of the Sai Kung Volcanic Rock Region.
Lush, spacious and beautiful. We traveled to Sai Kung to visit family members that relocated due to jobs. The area is very beautiful with plenty of open space, albeit very hilly.
well worth a visit. get the 92 bus from diamond hill to this gorgeous little town away from city but only 30 mins on the bus which will cost you 50 p.Nice area stunning views and very good food

One of the Best days in Hong Kong. I would highly suggest making a trip out to Sai Kung if you are looking to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. We took a group down to one of the beaches right off the pier and rented kayaks for the day. We hopped around islands with our kayaks all day, and it was perfect!! The water is clean and clear, and the white sand beaches are so fun to hang out on. There are even some islands you can go into and climb the trails! The pier was clean and filled with a lot of dogs (with owners of course). We did spot a feral cow!There were a lot of good food choices! We had some thai food that was out of this world. Unfortunately I don't remember the name. It was right by the bus stop down a little alley on the right. Amazing food. The overall atmosphere of Sai Kung is very relaxed and a great place for outdoor fun!

Appreciated this suggestion from a local. To get to Sai Kung, go via the MTR Green Line to Choi Hung, then exit C and then take the light green minibus 1A. Reverse directions when returning. And hold on tight because as soon as the bus door closes the driver will take you on mad rush to Sai Kung. We had been either on Hong Kong island or Tsim Sha Tsui for a few days and it was so refreshing to be taken away to the 'country side'. Plenty of places to eat either along the Sai Kung promenade or a through the village. There is even the global fast food chains such as McDonalds. You can choose your fresh seafood and have it cooked for you. You can buy fresh seafood from all the vendors along the pier. They are on their boats while you on the promenade and exchange of goods and money is via a pole with a net. Plenty of dried seafood to purchase. Some samples to eat as well. Very family oriented and pet friendly. A pleasure to have visited.

Beautiful fishing village away from the busy city. I stayed with my partner at a family apartment here for 2 weeks whilst we travelled around Hong Kong. It was just perfect. Fresh sea air, fresh sea food and friendly people. It was very multi-cultural as there are a lot of ex-pats living there but I can see why they'd choose Sai Kung! I would definitely want to retire there. Great little cafes where we ate macaroni soup with ham for breakfast and also look out for the small shop in an alley way near the mini-bus terminal that sells fresh egg waffles and bubble tea! There are gorgeous views of the mountains and it's not too far from the city by minibus. It's just a shame there aren't any hotels in Sai Kung, they'd do really well.

Good place for an afternoon visit. We wnet here for an outing whilst in Honk Kong. Easy to get to by public transport - advise take the little bus rather than the double decker as less stops. We stopped and had yum cha at a restarant overlooking the bay which was very pleasant although make sure you are hungry as we got charged a minimum of HK$500.

Sampan Seafood at great prices. Tucked in a quiet Eastern side of Hong Kong, is a fishing village well known as SaiKung where you can find very good seafood restaurants though on the pricy side. For me, it is also the best place to get inexpensive bargainable seafood from the fishermen at the ferry pier. A 1-kg Red Lobster goes for HK$500 (about US$60) and you will be spoilt by all the choices available including scallops, geoduck, clams, crabs, garoupas and my fav lobsters. Look for this blue sampan, this fisherman is friendly and so are his prices. Remember to negotiate.

Fantastic Sai Kung on Sunday !!!!!. After visiting Chi Lin Nunnery and Nan Lian Gardens @ Diamond Hill bus interchange, I took double-decker Bus 92 to Sai Kung. Sai Kung District's heartland is a coastal area characterised by beautiful scenery, charming small villages and stunning seascapes. The area is known for its pristine beaches and quiet living. After strolling and buying dried scallops and shrimps @ Sai Kung Waterfront Promenade, I took Mini Bus 1A back to Dundas Street, Mongkok.

Took a while to get there and not worth the effort. We were told by friends that this was a seaside town renowned for its fresh seafood restaurants. We were put off by the giant tanks of fish and ended up going to a Western restaurant on the square! We are adventurous eaters but Sai Kung did nothing for us.

Great get-out-of-the-city location. This seaside town is a long bus ride from the city but well worth the effort. It feels so different, with a more relaxed feel to it. Have lunch in one of the seafood restaurants, take a long walk toward the little beach, or take a boat tour to see the Hong Kong GeoPark in the near by island.
Fab, fab, fab. Brilliant place to visit. Observe the locals shopping for fresh fish, many great fish restaurants. Still has its lovely traditional fishing village charm. ;-s

Best beaches in Hong Kong!. I've been to Hong Kong more than 20 times, and I come here almost every time to enjoy the sandy, smoke free beaches. There are 1st Aid workers as well as life savers, the water is very clean and it's a really nice place to relax and get away from it all! The toilets and showers at the beach are available to use free of charge.
Good Fishing Village. Wow the fresh fish in the boats and restaurants is amazing. Had a wonderful seafood meal and then went for a cruise in the small boats for 2 hours. Was a wonderful experience

Unspoilt Hong Kong. We visited last weekend as we were hiking stage three of the Maclehose trail. It was one of the most beautiful hikes we have done here in Hong Kong. After our hike we had lunch at AJ's a wonderful Sri Lankan restaurant in Saikung town. Saikung is not so difficult to get to. You can get a bus from Shatin or Diamond hill. This is definitely a different side to Hong Kong than Central or Kowloon. A must visit if you have the time.
Relaxed village.. Off the beaten path a bit. Great place to go for fresh seafood. You can watch them bring it right off the boats and then onto your dinner plate.
country living in Hong Kong. great countryside, fabulous restaurants. Select your food and see it cooked-fresh from the sea.Easy to get to and great boat trips available

Great place - well worth the trip.. We went to Sai Kung on a Sunday, when all the world seemed to go there as well, even though the weather was a bit damp and drizzly. No matter. We'll be back - next time to eat at one of the fish restaurants on the front, joining the HK middle-class (and their pooches). I'd recommend taking the bus out to Wong Shek Pier too, and getting a ferry to somewhere. Next time.
Best seafood restaurants. This is the famous location where you can visit restaurant after restaurant and pick your seafood from the live aquariums. Fresh from the sea to your table. Worth the visit!

Best beaches. I went to Sai Kung and went hiking around Sai Wan, it was fantastic. Beautiful scenery, picturesque beaches, and great food. The water is so nice, much cleaner than most other Hong Kong beaches and it was very calm when I was there. I'd highly recommend going here, it was one of my favorite experiences in Hong Kong.It's great to get away from the city for a bit, I was shocked at how natural and beautiful it was. There are many places to go and many hikes to do and ferries to and from the beaches.

Seafood place. It's a bit of a journey about 45 mins from Central by cab if non peak time travel. Head down to the main pier, choose the fresh seafood and they cook it to your preference or leave it to them. Prices change so ask before you have them send it to the kitchen. Great for seafood and fresh seafood if you enjoy this.

Love the place love the seafood!. Maybe its off the city, hence lesser PRC visitors. Place is wonderful to relax and eat seafood. Went on a weekend, saw many locals with their pooches! a wonderful day to end the week.
Great food at Loaf On (Look On) Restaurant. Had dinner at Loaf On Restaurant. They are located at 49 See Cheung Street, Sai Kung. Clean, white table cloths and great wine selection..
Great Place to Chill. Great and affordable seafood. Place was quiet during the weekdays, however, you could walk around freely and enjoy the sea breeze blowing to your face.

Great fishing village. fanstastic live fish resaurants and fihing boats selling fish at the pier. Great opportunity to get a feel for some of the older traditions. have a walk thru Old Sai Kung, eat at the reastaurants go up to the park area, it is so different from Hong Kong you actually wonder where you are

More about Tai Wong Lan. Sai Kung was actually the end of our day. We caught a cab out to some spot in the middle of nowhere from where we hiked down to Ham Tin beach, enjoying the beautiful views along the way. Our reward was a refreshing cool beer and some lunch. The restaurant had a fence running through it. Apparently they had built a little too far down the beach on to what is classified as state land. The what would have been an attractive sun deck is now behind wire netting which seems like a pretty pointless exercise of bureaucratic power.After lunch we hiked up the stream to the waterfall where the more adventurous of my children jumped in. A great photo opportunity. Next we took the trail to Tai Long Sai Wan beach and enjoyed more glorious views. After another refreshing beer we took a boat to Sai Kung. I'd normally say this is the best way to do it but the heavens opened and our front seat vantage point proved a very exposed place to sit.At Sai Kung we watched the shoppers haggle with the fishermen to buy their catch. I couldn't even tell what some of the catch was. We finally selected a sea food restaurant (whose name I forget) and had the same problem. After photographing the exotic sea life in the tanks we had to choose our dinner but didn't know what it was. Fortunately we just had to point and the waitress recommended a cooking style for each of our purchases. She made good choices because dinner was fantastic - a perfect end to a great day.

Sea, fresh air and nature within HK. A lovely place to visit and a respite. Highly accessible, you can either take mtr, hop onto mini bus, or take the double decker bus or taxi. Recommended to take the bus as you would be able to see coastline of HK. Bus ride takes more than an hour so best you leave city around 3 pm, then when you reach Sai Kung, you can walk around. Fresh seafood can be purchased from boats near pier if you are staying in Sai Kung. Or you could eat at the restaurants facing the pier. Prices are reasonable for Hong Kong standards. After dinner take a stroll in this new village town and have a coffee or beer before you head back to city.

Beautiful place. This a lovely area and such a contrast from the hustle and bustle of 'down town' HK. Take a bus from the Visitor Centre to explore more of the area and take in the islands and scenery. Don't leave without trying one of the seafood restaurants.

an unforgettable day in Sai Kung nature park. started the day at the Royal HK yacht club in Sai Kung then took a motor boat trip winding our way along the coast line and around a few small islands - stopped in Jade bay for champers and then sped on to Jaspers for a long lunch.. what an amazing place. Sai Kung is also excellent for bikers walkers and fans of water sports - its just past Clearwater and well worth a trip - it has amazing sea food restaurants

See food and seafood. This was by far our best new territory island visit. Take the MTR to Diamond Hill, stop at Chi Lin nunnery and Nam Liam gardens outside then catch bus 92 to Sai Kung. The seaside resort has local fishermen arriving with boat loads of fish kept alive in plastic buckets for sale. Along the promenade are many seafood restaurants all with fish tanks displaying a huge variety of fresh fish to be purchased and cooked for lunch. The lobster noodles was an absolute winner for me.

Fun way to enjoy great sea food. A popular place great to enjoy a very good sea food,.U choose what u want from big aquariums everywhere and just sit inside the restaurant to eat it.Popular but good !!!Incredible price !!
Eat & See. If you enjoy places like Southern France seaside restaurant, you may want to try this area to enjoy having seafood next to the pier. Quite cozy area although food are not cheap.

Trendy over priced area and to many qui loh foreign workers.. I've been to Sai Kung at least 50 times, just to see buddies and the food sucks and over priced. The only thing going for Sai Kung is the Piasano's pizza. To many white people who think the own the place. I do like the view of the water and the boats. Stay away from the seafood restaurants over priced.

seafood paradise. great local fishing village with lots of small waterfront restaurants. the freshest seafood you will find in hong kong. and not a tourist trap like the floating restaurants at aberdeen

Country side at its best. Sai Kung is great for people looking for a peaceful hike, a walk through the country side of Hong Kong.There are many restaurants to try and there's things to do. Sai Kung is best on a good day out!

See a different side to Hong Kong. If you want to see a different side to Hong Kong then Sai Kung is worth a visit. Compared to the busy streets of Central this is like a sea side town. Head there in the day or evening and see the fishing boats selling dried fish or have an amazing fresh meal where you can actually pick the fish out of the tank yourself.

Is that HK? Great surprise! Great seafood!. Local friends decided to bring us there and we are forever indebted to them for showing us a HK which we did not know existed! It is like a small town and the pier and promenade was most interesting. The fishermen were selling their wares from their boats and their partners were hanging off the railings (on the other side of the promenade, like on top of the water!) as they were not allowed to sell on the promenade! They sell all kinds of seafood. The promenade is alike St Kilda pavement on Sundays.We had seafood in one of the restaurant, and it was really fresh. Not everyone's cup of tea as the fishes were still alive when you are choosing whatever it is you want for lunch. Cooking charges were separate and the more people, the cheaper.It seems there are a lot more westerners living in that area although it is quite far away from HK city as the environment is green and there's great hiking trails, etcWell worth a visit if you have enough time or decide that you have had enough of bustling HK.
Sea Food place. I enjoy a dinner with my friend right there and the food was very nice but i did not know the price since my friend paid for me.

Different from Urban Hong Kong. I personally think Sai Kung has a lot to offer and despite it not being a main attraction to tourists, it is still considered a place for holidays for Hong Kong people. There is quite a lot to do such as country walks as well as being able to dine in some of the greatest Seafood restaurants ever. I think it is definitley worth a visit if you havent already been.

Not quite what I had expected. Something went lost in translation when I asked some native friends to take me to a harbour where I could take some nice panoramic pictures of HK and they took me to Sai Kung. Even with the super efficient hk transportation system it took one hour to get there. The sun was scorching and there is not much shade on the promenade unless you take refuge in one of the many seafood restaurants or small shops. The fishermen pull up to the peer with their daily catch for sale. There are also various size boats, modern speedboats and junks that one may take to nearby islets. I guess it would make for a different Sunday but I as a tourist with only a few days in hk it would not make the top of my list.

Great place to visit.. Dinner or Trek or even go snorkeling.. One of the few places where tourists don't go much.. don't know why. Its a great place to just hang out or have fresh sea food dinners or then from here go on some great treks..u can even go snorkeling not to far from here...

A bit of a change - lovely!. Sai Kung is a peaceful little harbour village in The New Territories. It was suggested to me by a friend who visits Hong Kong regularly and I was so pleased that I followed up on his suggestion. Getting to Sai Kung was incredibly easy. Just take the MTR to Diamond Hill and change to a number 92 bus and stay on all the way. The 92 bus route is a lovely scenic ride too (as long as you sit upstairs). Sai Kung itself has a selection of seafood restaurants with an amazing array of delicacies from which to choose. The promenade is a pleasant stroll and the small old town is also worth a brief wander - it won't take you long. It's one of those places that doesn't appear in the guide books and. I'm glad but give it a go (by public transport) and you'll be glad you did.
Great Escape from HK Island. Great beaches but not so great diving, the problem being the visibility: you can still enjoy taking a boat and any other water sports.

One of the best places to visit while in HK. The village is easily accessible by minibus from Hang Hau MTR. It is not a particularly picturesque place but you can stroll along the promenade and have delicious, fresh and cheap sea food. But, if you really want something different, take a taxi to the High Island Reservoir (about 100HKD each way) from where hiking trails to some great beaches begin.

Sai Kung. Probably some of the best sea-food restaurants in the New Territories. Walk passed the many harbour front restaurants displaying their live menu in tanks and choose your fish at any of them. They are all good

Traditional Fishing Village. One of the many fishing villages in Hong Kong. It is only a 30 min car ride from Kowloon. There are many fishing boats lined up along the pier that sells fresh seafood. It has also become a place where family let their dogs go loose. There are many seafood dai pai dongs that offer delicious and fresh seafood. There is also a bakery that sells delicious pineapple buns and egg tarts. However, i do recommend Cheung Chau Island more.
Cliff jumping in Sai Kung. For those who like hiking, Sai Kung is a good place to go on weekends to escape HK! Great to go there with friends!

A place to see the past meets the present. It's the traditional side of Hong Kong: the streets are narrow, parking looks random and buildings on the two sides of the streets appear to be tired. But it makes you feel at ease. We ate at a restaurant just next to the bay. Different kinds of sea creatures are in water tanks and look very fresh. The dishes were tasty and the service was good. If you are not in a rush, sitting in a nearby tea house for an afternoon tea would be very relaxing. One thing: the restroom of the restaurant was messy, which is not totally surprising. Sorry I forgot the restaurant's name...
fish fish fish. what fish would you like for lunch? or any other wierd and wonderful creature. Pick it fresh yourself along one of these fabulous restaurants

A different side of Hong Kong. Sai Kung is a lovely seaside village a half-hour-or-so bus ride from the centre city. The bus ride shows you some of the countryside and village houses and the sparkling sea and little islands nearby. Arrive on an empty stomach and fill up on fab dim sum or seafood at one of the local restaurants - we just wandered along the waterfront until we saw a place packed with locals and it was great. If you have a few days in Hong Kong this is a really worthwhile outing. It is also possible to take sampan rides around the islands. We didn't have time on this trip but have in the past and it was a great way to get a closer look at the islands - just compare prices between operators and don't be shy about negotiating!

Such a great change of pace! . Not too hard to get to, and a refreshing and interesting change of pace. Fresh seafood dinners, lots of dog lovers, and colorful scenery. Take the mtr to diamond hill transportation interchange. Take the 96r or 92 to the end and enjoy a long, windy, coastal mountain ride
An Oasis in Hong Kong. Full of charm, scenic beauty, cute little local restaurants and divine seafood this is a location not to be missed. I loved my visit here, and will come back for sure.
disappointed. Was lead to believe this was the best seafood in the whole of hong kong the waterfront was very ordinary and the seafood did not look to clean and the town very average. clean

Excellent place for city break. I live in Hong Kong at a place near Sai Kung. It is a really nice place. I always go there in the weekend to pretend that I was in a different country since Sai Kung is a place does not like Hong Kong. No tall building, no big shopping mall, not much people in weekday (be aware that there will be many on weekend). You can expect big blue sky, great sea view, fishing at the pier, BBQ at the beach, snorkeling, diving, hiking, picnic etc. etc. Sai Kung is a place that you can go a hundred times but still fun to go for the hundred and one time. At Sai Kung center near the pier, there are some fishermen selling fresh fishes on boats and you can see how they manage good to sell on floating boat~! Some boatmen near the pier would sell the ticket to islands nearby. They offer very reasonable price to many beautiful islands such as Sharp Island and Half Moon Bay. Really good views but do more research before going to those islands. Some may not offer toilet facility. Besides the Sai Kung center, the BBQ sites, hiking area, beaches, picnic sites etc. are also great to good. I love Sai Kung very much. This place is a escape from Hong Kong. Hong Kong break.

This is a very beautiful old fishing village. This is a very beautiful old fishing village steeped with tradition and a beautiful family atmosphere. The waterfront has many wonderful seafood restaurants serving absolutely delicious freshly prepared seafood at very reasonable prices.

Beautiful berth connect to island. My friend's took me to this area for a half day leisure walk. It was quite far away but the tempo is definitely slower than in the city centre. I've seen quite a lot of western people are jogging, relaxing near at the yatch port. The scenery is beautiful, local fisherman is selling fresh sea catches on the boat. I've heard the "crab" is sold $180 each which is considered quite expensive. It is a relaxing small place which is worth to take a look.
Great walking trails. Great expat hangout, saikung has some amazing walking trails, lots of greenery around, absolute must-do if you're the outdoorsy type!!

Fresh fish and bustling atmosphere. If you want to buy or eat real fresh fish in Hongkong, this is a must to go. Plenty of fishing boats sell fresh fish along the promenade of Sai Kung village. The restaurants around serve very delicious fresh fish meals and even some shopping around for daily goods is very good. The way to get there leads you through a hilly road with plenty of green of palm and other trees, beautiful scenery and already a movie for your senses if you are normally used to concrete jungles only. Good escape from Kowloon or Hongkong Island to a more greener and more relaxing environment.
Still much the same. Avoid the shark migrating seasons - waters still lovely though a little cold. Must eat seafood there!

A dare. This was a trip to nowhere. SO HAPPY we did it. This is the Hong Kong that most people do not see. There are no glitzy malls, no bus loads of camera happy tourists, no pretentions. More than a town is a village commanding incredible views over the ocean. There is a Michelin Stared restaurant but we decided to dare eating at a cloister of sea front restaurants that looks more like a fish market. The food was delicious. The staff who hardly spoke any English were beyond helpful and we left amidst smiles, handshakes, cellphone pics from both sides and even a stolen hug .
Seafood paradise. super fresh seafood and a wide variety. you could choose from the restaurant or buy from the nearby fishing boats.

A Lovely Afternoon Getaway. Would definitely recommend Sai Kung as an afternoon side excursion. It's not difficult to get to, (92 bus), and just getting to walk along the piers and see the fishing boats was a real treat. It felt quaint and was nice to be out of the hubbub of the city. The town is great to check out too, with narrow walkways and some fun little shops. The tanks at the restaurants are a must photo opportunity, and I ate at Chuen Kee seafood restaurant (had a good meal). Boat tours are also offered, but I didn't have time to take one. It was a really nice afternoon, definitely check it out.

A gateway to different islands. Sai Kung is not only a place for locals including expats to hangout, but also a gateway to different attractions such as Yim Tim Tsai and High Island Reservior. If you are a dog lover, you could see a lot of people bringing out their beloved dogs for a walk on the weekend. There is a flea market on the weekend. A lot of of seafood,Thai and western restaurants to cater different people. Often you could encounter a lot of cows on the road. Their ancestors used to work on the field.

Relaxing spot away from the bustle of the city. I love this place it doesnt have any hotels ... yet... but it is a special place. it has a very relaxed atmosphere.The seafood restaurants make this area famous. Huge tanks of sea life...fresh for eating/viewing.The boats on the water makes the area pretty.The area is not the cleanest but it worth a visit.
Some quietness just outside the city. Just an hour from our hotel, the Sai Kung area has good walks and of course great sea food. A nice combination, and a welcome change from city life.

Very interesting place, and lots of seafood to choose from. Sai Kung is a little out of the way from downtown Hong Kong. I know many expats live there and commute but for travellers it is a bit removed. Still it is very interesting to visit. There are many sellers ofan aray of seafood and price are cheap. It can get very busy here on weekends with local visiting as well. You cna do some other island crusiers from here too.

A fishing village near Deep Water Bay. Take a bus or the MTR (subway) to Hang Hou and taxi to Sai Kung, a fishing village with open air restaurants by the water. There are ferries or small boat rides to the bay to spend time away from the crowded downtown scene. .
Lovely days outing. We had a wonderful days puting in Sai Kung. away from the hustle and bustle of Kowloon. Its a peaceful part of the Hong Kong experience with lost of nice places to eat.

Great Fish and Chips. Was pining for fish and chips and as family are from this region - we visit without fail whenever we are in the territory. The fish was succulent and excellently prepared. Would have liked more chips but that is just me being greedy. They prepare a mean hot lemon tea. On the day we visited it was quite cold and the blustery wind from the sea meant the hot lemon tea was welcome.

A great day trip out of the city. We were looking for something to do and saw Sai Kung on Tripadvisor so decided to go and have a look. From Kowloon you take the red mini bus from Dundas St, Mongkok (just near Ladies Market). It takes about 30 minutes to get there and the ride on the bus is very interesting if nothing else. These drivers know their way and the way to drive on Hong Kong roads but as a visitor it is a bit unnerving. Sai Kung is a lovely little village. There are plenty of shops to look in and restaurants and bars to take a break in. Walk along the jetty and watch locals selling live fish from there little boats tied alongside. There a boat trips you can take to go to smaller islands offshore but we didn't do this as we only went for a couple of hours. The scenery along the way is very pretty and we would consider staying at Sai Kung for a few days on our next trip to HK.

Fresh seafood, straight off the fishing boat. The fishing village is a nice respite from urban Hong Kong. What greets you first as you walk along the seaside promenade are weird sea creatures, some gigantic, floating in large tanks. A sight to see. We had the freshest shrimp and calamares at one of the restos. Then good coffee at a small cafe. The rest of the afternoon, you can spend just walking on the promenade, watching Hong Kong-ers playing with their pups (there are a lot of poodles on this island!) or fishermen peddling their catch. It's a very local scene here, with photography buffs, sporty types and families enjoying a weekend by the sea. Would have liked to take a hike and then swim, but the day was overcast. Definitely worth a return visit.

Great day trip. We travelled here by metro to Choi Hung on the green line then took a minibus from right outside number 1A direct to Sai Kung. Did not take more than an hour from Central and felt like we were miles away from the city. Very quaint old fishing village with nice little back streets and lots of seafood restaurants. We walked along the seafront and then up through Tui Min Hoi village which was fascinating and gave a glimpse of how the locals live here. Had lunch at one of the seafront restaurants and then took a boat across to Sharp Island. There is no need to go with one of the touts there is a regular ferry which cost HK$4 return. The island there is very small but a nice walk around and you can cross the tombolo when the tide permits to another small island very pretty. When we got back across all the local fishermen were bringing their catch in and selling on the front. Great day would certainly recommend it.

See another side of HK, quiant and diverse. You can get to Sai Kung either by boat or taxi, we wanted to take the boat but it only runs on a Saturday so we took a Taxi at a cost of HKD150 we returned on the 16 seater bus which cost HKD15/pp and it took the same time, both a good experience though.There is lots to see in Sai Kung, walk along the fisherman's wharf and see the locals trading and buying their very fresh fish, a fascinating thing to observe. Go off the main streets to see how the locals really live, there are a myriad of little narrow streets with some quaint shops and people!There are lots of places to eat, grab a coffee or a beer. On the harbour front there are lots of seafood restaurants with heaps of tanks with live fish for you to choose, a sight to see to believe.Well worth the effort if time permits.

Go on a weekday, weekends can be crazy!. With a one lane road leading into and out of Sai Kung, weekends where the weather is nice can be a nightmare, as it seems most of HK has the same idea. That being said, Sai Kung is a good place to go for some good food, a walk around in the green spaces, or as a jumping off point to explore the outlying islands there (highly recommended) or the nearby Country Park.

Blue Skies, Fresh Lungs.. Lots of nice seafood restaurants around here. Best part by far, however, is the fresh, clean air that can be found here. Really nice change from the normally polluted Hong Kong city air.
Great country feel. Quiet laid back sea side town feel. Plenty of restaurants, bars, cafes and pubs. Great getaway from the hustle of Hong Kong.

The other side of HK for a few day trip or walkers. You really have to get out here, take a speed boat around the bay and find some of the sand beaches that even at times have rip tides. I came across two Australian surfers camping on the beach. This shows you another side to HK for those on a longer trip or keen to get out the city and see nature. Their are great expat style eating places out here also. I loved it.

Another Side of Hong Kong. Went there on a public holiday, for Tai Long Sai Wan Beach, a beach mostly visited by locals only. Took 96r from opposite Macdonalds to Sai Wan Pavilion and hiked for around 45 minutes to Sai Wan Beach. Very interesting experience, thoroughly enjoyed the fresh air and nature! Had delicious Soy Beancurd when I reached Sai Wan Beach and caught locals surfing the waves. The 96R bus is a local bus service so information is not readily available online, (bus schedule in picture attached, taken on 30 March 2013). Had seafood lunch at a seaside restaurant after at Sai Kung Town, abit pricey though I figure its as fresh as it can be, spend about HK$400 on 2 pax for (fish, abalone, prawns, scallop and a side of vegetables). Very delicious Pineapple bread and egg tart available at one of the shops, must try!

far but worth wile. we had our super fresh fish dinner at sai kung
it is a little bit distance but you MUST do this
all the live fish, great cooking and delicious dishes
you go there and you always will remember well

Village life. Travellers think HK is all about skylines and dense population. Sai Kung is just a brilliant fishing village with many European restaurants mixed with old style Chinese restaurants. The old village is really worth a walk through. Travel by MTR to Choi Hung and pick up No.1 minibus.
TIP: TRY TO AVOID SUNDAYS!!

Seafood paradise. You have to be there once to experience, you can choose you own fresh seafood, all sorts of fish, escalops, all sorts of crab, exotic sea animals ... then the cook will make it to your taste.
yummmmm

Outdoor Paradise of Local Hong Kong People. You can only find HK is no longer a small place to explore here. Sai Kung is the largest country park with the best beaches, breathing mountains and friendly villages good for hiking, camping even living...
But it needs TIME to Explore!

Fisherman town. Went many times to Hongkong but no time to take a bus around, this time I managed to take a bus to Sai Kung terminal. Take MTR to Choi Hung and exit C2 walk outside bus 92 or private mini bus 1A. Half an hour journey crossing valley and hills. It was a Sunday and there were many families bringing children and dogs. This is a port where u see many boat people below selling all kinds of seafoods which you might never seen before.

Well worth the trip. We got there by MTR to Diamond Hill station and double-decker bus to Sai Kung. This is a lovely seaside spot in the New Territories. It is a seafood town where the locals sell all their live seafood directly from their boats. The way they store the seafood onboard is worth the trip to see by itself. There a a lot of open air cafes along the waterfront where you can have very fresh seafood meals. The whole area is picturesque with many small islands, the mountains, and all the boats.
Beaches and seafood. Every local knows that Sai Kung has some of the best sea food you can find in Hong Kong. The restaurants might not look 'clean' but trust me, the food will still be excellent.
Seaside town. Saikung is a small seaside community with seafood restaurant, BBQ location and lots of dog lovers. I enjoy Saikung.
A bit disappointed. After a long trip to get there we were a bit disappointed as the restaurants did not look very clean but the variety of creatures in the fish tanks was amazing

Loved it. Very tranquil and great to get away from the main city. Transportation via bus is very easy. I ate at alot of different places here and they were all good. The fish market is good to see and the little boats who are selling their catch of the day is interesting.

Sai Kung Peninsula. Sai Kung Peninsula was awesome. Took bus from Sai Kung town and alight at Pak Tam Chung. Then took a cab to Highland Reservoir and hiked back about 8.5 km. Panoramic scenery, fresh air, peace and tranquillity. We returned back to Sai Kung town for seafood dinner at Chuen Kee which was overpriced. Overall, fantastic experience!

Good seafood. Seafood there are really fantastic. There are many people eating with their own puppies by the sea. I really recommand foreign travelers to come. There are also a restaurant called Moon Kei, where its desserts are very yummy. You must try once in your life.
seafood. We had great seafood. Atmospheric and the kids had more fun viewing all the fresh seafood tanks at the restaurants than if we'd been at an aquarium!

Fishing Village. After several visits to Hong Kong, we finally made it to Sai Kung and what a treat it was. The lovely little streets are full of character and with fish venders and restaurants galore.

Jersey Shore in Hong Kong. Most people think of Hong Kong as one large city, but as seen from the plane flying into Hong Kong Airport the island is large and along with the surrounding "old-territories" some truly vast amounts of undeveloped open space. What catches your eye is the myriad of small sea harbours that face the sea. Sai Kung is one such area. Connections from Hong Kong are a bit tricky, but all doable and fun. The MTR gets you on your way with a few quick changes and then you jump on one of the many small buses that will take you out to Sai Kung. Sai Kung itself is a small fishing village with lots of small shops and restaurants, but what makes it so lovely is the atmosphere, views and smells of the sea. The Hong Kong Scout Association has a large Leadership Outdoor Training Centre located across the bay. From there trails cut up and around the peninsula making it possible to do a pretty neat trek from Sai Kung itself.
Eh. I expected Sai Kung to be much nicer, more relaxed. It wasn't. Busy and kind of dirty and the main square left a LOT to be desired. Get some green space!

Beautiful little spot. I went on a Sunday with my HK host/friend , and was quite pleased. It is right on the water- so much so, you can buy live fish off of the boats on the dock. The scenery was beautiful and it was another time when I felt that humans are the same everywhere you go. It was a very pleasant experience and the fresh seafood at the restaurant was fantastic.

Best seafood in Hong Kong. I have a friend visitng Hong Kong from Japan for three nights few months ago and this is the place I brought them for dinner. Swimming fishes and all sorts of live seafood everywhere should impress every tourist. No seafood place in all countries I have visited come remotely close to being comparable to this area.

See another side to Hong Kong!. We actually stay with family here when we come to Hong Kong. It's easy to get to using the mtr and buses. And well worth some time away from the city! Little markets, fantastic fish restaurants, a beach, water excursions, this really does have it all. And it's so different to the hustle and bustle of the city! It's changed so much since I first came here 9 years ago. There's a lot more ex pats here now, and a lot more dogs! But it's a nice area, with lots of streets to explore, and plenty of people that speak VERY good English to help if you need it. Please do come spend a day here to see another side to this amazing region!

Real contrast to the city. Worth going here just to experience the contrast between this village and the bustle of Hong Kong and Kowloon etc. Beautiful scenery and excellent seafood restaurants, choose your dish from the live tanks. Good prices too. Overall great value for money.
Fresh seafood, Small Town. Love the fresh seafood but is not that cheap. The neighbourhood is fun to spend an afternoon walking. Many small shops and a long row of seafood resturant.

Seaside Lunch Treat. Fresh seafood, cooked perfectly, a nice view of the open sea, seeing a slice of the fishermen/vendors selling their fresh catch from their boats, piers where one can board small boats to go to the islands, a quaint quiet time, lovely sea breeze, a great view on the way to this seafood haven these and all is Sai Kung. Been wanting to go here in the past and finally got to have a taste of the place. Wonderful place to just hang around the open spaces and see people walk their lovely dogs during the afternoons! A must visit to see the other side of Hong Kong !

Scenic hike at MacLehose stage 2. We did the 4 hour hike at MacLehose stage 2 and was rewarded with beautiful view and great seafood along the seafood street in Saikung town after the hike.We did what locals do - buy fresh seafood from the the wet market (at a street behind the seafood street - ask for directions from the local people) and brought them to Good View Restaurant for them to cook at a cooking fee of HKD70 per dish.
Great sea side. There have a good see view, especially if you rent the boat service to bring you out the sea. Besides, there are a lot of sea food restaurant offer a wide variety of seafood.

Good Seafood. The only place with Michelin star seafood Restaurant in HK.. The market here is cool, you buy your seafood by conversing with the fisherman who will be at their sampan at the harbour below. They will then lift the fish up to you. pretty cool experience. but i guess, it'll be better if you can speak cantonese since these fisherman are mostly traditional locals.Have a seafood lunch / dinner after, they have gigantic crabs and fishes. Never see such big live seafood until i came to this place. There are 2 restaurants here with Michelin Star. And they are the only two seafood restaurant in HK. So do check out the food. Price slightly steep, but i guess seafood is always expensive even in other countries.
Stunning views of the coastline. Its a nice to getaway from the hectic pace of Hong Kong Island to be beside the sea and get some fresh air.

A very pleasant day out at the beach. Sai Kung is a pleasant beach side area that is popular with locals in summer and offers a good range of nice restaurants and a very nice stroll along the waterside boardwalk.Highly recommended, but very busy on summer weekends.

Fun. Good way to check out how old fishing culture interacts with yuppies and housing developments. It does all work and there are lots of restaurants to choose from and scenes to record for posterity.

Visit for a very different HK experience. As I was staying in Sha Tin I decided to take a bus out to Sai Kung to see the town and the seafood restaurants in particular. The bus ride is very picturesque with good views of bays, the sea and small mountains in the distance. Sai Kung is a great contrast to the international frenetic activity in the city, a small town on the seafront with a thriving fishing community and some spectacular harbour front seafood restaurants. It also has some interesting quiet backstreets to explore. Sai Kung is the gateway town to some large areas of natural beauty but on my short trip I was only able to visit the town. I had a decent plate of scallops and vegatables for lunch (difficult to have a great seafood meal when you're eating alone) and then took a different bus back to Diamond Hill MTR and into the Kowloon madness once more. Very nice trip.

Lovely place to see another side of Hong Kong. This is a beautiful area - it has everything: sea and country walks and great food too. A nice place to visit to see another side of Hong Kong away from the bustle of the shopping malls and traffic. Take a picnic and find one of the BBQ pits or eat at one of the many restaurants in Sai Kung town.

Good way to spend a few hours, getting away, sampling great seafood. Pretty much echoing what everyone else says about Sai Kung, very pleasant. Go during a weekday to avoid the crowds. Also warn the restaurant cooking your seafood that you know the difference between stored seafood and fresh seafood!!We ordered the crab and lobster, neither was fresh. The meat should not stick to the shell. It was beautifully cooked, but there was that feeling that we had been tricked into thinking we were going to eat the seafood out of the tank. The fish was definitely fresh though, and couldn't tell with the scallop. Still a very good meal.
My favorite part of HK. Fishing village. Geopark hiking. Hiking Maclehose trail and stumblng intohidden, secluded beaches.Boat tours.

Lovely breathtaking view. Me and my friend did the Sai Wan Peninsula 14km hike around the reservoir and ended our trip at the Sai Wan Pavillion. Worth attempting provided you are fit, with plenty supply of water (I mean at least 3L on a hot day as there are no "refilling centers" along the way). Breathtaking views of the volcanic landscapes and the blue sea. Easy to get to - just follow the instructions on hong kong discovery website. Please ensure you take the left turn to get to the bus to Sai Kung town, as you approach the T-junction (which is about another 30mins walk). DO NOT take the right turn to Sai Wan town, which is a small town with no modern vehicles, unless you still have the energy to trek down to have a look at the town and trek up again to go to the bus stop (We did that involuntarily and it was tiring!!) Beware of snakes..

A small town atmosphere in HK. The seafood here is every bit what the locals say. There are many good restaurants hidden in the alleyways that are a fraction of the price of the seafront. Also a great place for a romantic walk. Best to make your visit here in the Summer.

So Much Green. There is the Michaelhose trail which is interlaced with many trails of varying lengths and difficulties but it is well worth the time and effort because there are some fantastic views when you reach some of the peaks. Easily accessible by MTR and bus.

Scuba & eating. We were in Hong Kong on a weekend, this was maybe our 10th stay there and looking for something new we found this Beautifull place full of great places to eat with live seafood and scuba combination was really great!The place to do scuba is not really as in the caribean, but you can see something different over there !! Interesting combination !To go there you need like 1 hour. Take subway tl last station "Po Lam" and then a bus to Sai Kung !

fresh,expensive,average taste. 5of us went to tung kee in saikung. the service was good,the seafoods were very fresh(live)with expensive cost. but the cooking was not so good with bland taste. the scallop was totally overcooked. the beach village of saikung worth a visit though it's a bit far.

Sai Kung Sundays. Sai Kung is great on Sundays. Full of people with puppies. the floating fish market is enough to keep you entertained for hours and the fresh seafood at one of the restaurants is a experience.

the other side of hong kong. I love sai kung!not what you expect from a city known for it's skyscrapers. A lovely little village with a beautiful pier walk, dog park, little cafes/ eatery's, markets, pubs and the quintessential fish restaurants. come for the day and enjoy kayaking and the nearby geo park. great day out, and the hong kong locals agree, so be sure to get there on a week day to avoid crowds.

A board walk and restaurants. Sai Kung is easy to reach on busses, from Tseung Kwan O, for example. It offers scenes of local vendors offering fish directly from boats. Fish restaurants are somewhat expensive, 500 hkd for a late lunch for two, but could be viewed as an experience.The bus ride (regular transit busses) from Tseung Kwan O gives some scenery.

Worth a day trip. Big harbor with a ton of small boats. Nice bayside restaurants serving very good seafood. Unlike Stanley on HK island, catering more to Western tourists, this is a place favored mostly by mainland Chinese tourists.

Good value for seafood. The number of seafood and large fish aquarium is impressive. We went to Cheun Gee and had a dinner menu for 6 people. We had lots of seafood and it was not too expensive (around 1300 HKD). Interesting experience.

Loved it!. We took bus 92 from diamond hill mtr, after visiting the nunnery and gardens, to sai kung on a day trip. It was great to watch the selling of food from the boats on the harbour. We walked past the restaurants to fond a fantastc kids bookshop where i found some chinese picture story books written in English. The reading room, 21 hoi pong st sai kung, well worth a look.We travelled onto wong shek pier via bus 94.I wish we had the entire day in sai kung to explore, oh well, next time!

A fishing village gone touristy. Yes there are fishing boats selling all kinds of seafood but the town has gone touristy big time. There are several tour boats and shills touting trips to the Geo Park Islands or sampan rides. There are several seafood restaurants on the harbor front with live seafood in tanks up front. None of which appealed to us as they seemed to be kind of shabby and uninviting. A tout handed me a sheet promoting a seafood set lunch. At HK $458 (US $55) per person we thought it is a bit steep in a harbor village. As we walked around it became obvious that McDonald's and Pizza Hut were doing great judging by the number of people eating there. Bottom line: You can get to Sai Kung by taking the MTR (train) from Tai Wai to the end of the line and then the 99 Bus. Or you can go to Sha Tin and then take the 299 bus to Sai Kung but this may take longer.

Worth the trip. A little bit of a ride but certainly worth it. Lots of great restaurants, but locals tell me prices and portions will vary if they know you're a tourist. Make sure to take the time to walk up and down the waterfront and check out the fishing boats selling sea creatures. Great place for some pictures, especially by the large fish tanks.
nice and dirty. I GOT to try the seafood here but i've foud that fish taste like mud, so farmed raised fish or to many in one timestay away if you know fresh taste of fish

Resort type of town...very relaxing!. I went to Sai Kung the day I came back from Singapore which was like 3 in the afternoon. The bus (92) ride was a little long from Hollywood plaza in Diamond Hill to Sai Kung. Make sure to get off at the last main bus stop about 45 min to 1 hour ride. The day we were there was a little foggy and misty so the view was not that great out the window but I am sure that it would be beautiful if it was a clear day. Once you get off the bus, you will see the pier right in front of you. People are lined up bargaining along the wharf because the boat people are down there selling there fresh seafood. Make sure if you buy seafood and bring to a restaurant ask them how much they will charge extra for bring stuff in. Shop around if you have to. I think I would come back again if I have more time and explore a little more. It was a very romantic place to walk along the pier in the rain but I was there with my family to eat that night.

Nice seafood restaurant village. 20-40 minutes drive from the city center depending which part of city center but it is worth to visit and experience real Chinese sea foods at reasonable price but should be careful for selection of restaurant.

A great day out. Wow! this is certainly a place to put on your travel itinerary. Its a great day out and why not stay for a happy hour later in the day overlooking the water and having some great well priced seafood.
A good place to visit. Many seafood restaurant and fresh seafood at the harbour. Also a few nice bars. Beware of the water side restaurant and not asking for the price of anything...

Must see!. Pick your fresh seafood from the tank, and have the restaurant cooked to your order, with photos to remember it by! If your arrive early enough before sunset, you may even be lucky enough to witness some fishermen coming in with their catch of the day, though it has become an increasing rare sight to catch!

Beautiful and relaxing!. Away from the humdrum of the city, this stunning sea-side locale is perfect to find a few moments of sanity. If you love the sea and the sea-food, this definitely is a place not to be missed. Takes about an hour from the central hongkong to reach here via train and then a bus-ride. Jaspa's is a consistently good place to eat at. An excursion in the old part of town, dotted with a couple of temples is also good. I normally grab a nice pizza here. There are some nice beaches and nature parks, but one needs a full day to explore them.

Love Sai Kung!. Sai Kung is a lovely laid back part of Hong Kong! It takes about an hour to get there from Central at the weekends. but it is worth the trip. The seafood restaurants are great and it is very interesting to see the fish "market" at the pier.

Nice getaway from the city. Sai Kung is a nice little get away from the city. It has plenty of seafood restaurants along the promenade and has a more country local feeling to the place. One of the main attractions is the access to other islands and nearby beaches with a short trip in a sand pan. Many junks leave from this area as well, which are great value and a fun day out in the water swimming, eating and drinking.

Only if you're after really fresh seafood. Its a good 45 minute drive from Kowloon. So plan to go there if you really want to have fresh seafood on a very local venue. Have a local take you there to ascertain a quality experience.

A good place to walk around and feel the local Hong Kong. We visited this place so it make me feel a friendly town like in Hong Kong. We bought some fresh scallops, crab and shrimp out of a fisherman's boat. Many restaurants offer open sitting areas for visitors to enjoy fresh seafood made by the top-notch chefs. Food was usual good, service efficient, not much to complain about. All in all! A good.

Relief from hum and heat of Hong Kong. Great little day trip from downtown with easy MTR to bus transport. Interesting sights, great people, dog, and (feral) cow watching, wonderful seafood both in the tanks and in the mouth. Really nice diversion. We visited in the evening and didn't take any of them, but it appears that many boats provide further excursions to outlying islands which would make it even more special.

Sai Kung - relaxing retreat from the crowdedness of the city. As local residents, we spend time in Sai Kung quite regularly, finding it a nice retreat from the crowdedness (and chaos) of the city. It’s a nice location to dine, relax and there are a few activities you can partake in when visiting this area of Hong Kong. We also consider Sai Kung a very family friendly area in Hong Kong. The main dining area is along the Sai Kung Promenade where you can find traditional seafood restaurants. There is also a nice collection of western style restaurants spread around the city, including classics like Jaspa's on Sha Tsui Path. There is also good Thai food in Sai Kung as well as plenty of western bars and even a couple of good coffee shops.The main activities in Sai Kung include spending time on the promenade, taking junk boat trips to the smaller outer islands as well as the relatively new Geo Park tour. However, our favourite activity is simply watching open seafood market which lines the piers along the promenade. All matter of seafood seems to be available and being sold by the seafood sellers docked in boats along the piers. It’s a lively, hygienic and very photogenic environment, making it a genuinely fun place to visit.Other things to do in Sai Kung include a visit to the nicely restored Tin Hau Temple in the town center as well as a handful of other Tin Hau temples spread out in the Sai Kung area. The old town center, offers a bit of a labyrinth of narrow ally streets and make a fun area to explore. Additionally, in the Sai Kung area there are some nice beaches and country parks for hiking as well as access to a public golf course. Overall, Sai Kung is a great area to explore, dine and spend time while visiting Hong Kong. Similar but more rustic than Stanley on Hong Kong Island, Sai Kung is one of the best locations to just relax and enjoy a seaside environment when you tire of the noise and crowds of the city.

Sai Kung. Sai Kung is a must see when visiting Hong Kong. This is a very beautiful old fishing village steeped with tradition and a beautiful family atmosphere. The waterfront has many wonderful seafood restaurants serving absolutely delicious freshly prepared seafood at very reasonable prices. A walk along the waterfront is fascinating and great to watch the local people buying their fresh seafood supplies from many boats moored to the docks. The beaches in this area are beautifully clean and many water sport activities are available for the adventurous at heart. We will definately spend longer here on our next visit.

Seafood and ferries. Sai Kung was a very old fishing village before. It is now popular for seafood and many Caucasian settle there due to low density. It has a very small town with many shops and many good restaurants of different cuisines. You can get to Sai Kung by many buses and also by minibuses. It is normally about half an hour ride to get there. You can go to many small islands in Hong Kong from there as well. The seafood market is an eye opener. You can pick and choose live seafood and they will prepare it for you to your liking. However it is important to ask them the price beforehand to avoid confrontation. In all it is a place with many interesting local charm.
Take a boat to the beach. On the harbour front hop on a boat which takes you to outlying Islands - fantastic day out, return and enjoy seafood from one of the amazing harbour front restaurants.
Get to Tai Long Wan.... This is the best beach in HK and should not be missed. A healthy 1 hour hike over to the beach followed by a crystal white sand beach. It does not get better than this in HK!
Clean water!. One of the few beaches in Hong Kong that isn't polluted! The water was clear and the beach was peaceful.

Great day out. Sai Kung is a great day out. Lovely waterfront promenade to walk. Second hand book shop sells English language. McDonalds.Take MTR to Diamond Hill and KMB bus 92 from there. Whole trip costs about £1.Sai Kung is gateway town to a couple of sections of Maclehose Trail. Take KMB Wong Shek Pier bus from Sai Kung.Also get off bus on way back at Hebe Haven.

More like China Harbour than HK. We were lucky enough to be staying with friends who live in Sai Kung otherwise it's unlikely that we would have ventured our of HK Island. What an interesting place. Getting an octopus card for the metro and buses is a must and very cheap. If you get a metro to Hang Hau and then the 101M bus straight into Sai Kung, it will take just over an hour.
