The place has oodles of fish restaurants all where you chose what you want and they cook it for you. The place fEels much more like local CHina and is a breath away from the big city. A great contrasting experience.

A world away from HK bustle. We spent a day kayaking around Sai Kung islands, it was great. We stopped at various islands along the way and had a swim, drink and sunbathe. Afterwards we ate at a lovely seafront fish restaurant and watched the sunset .Sai Kung is a wonderful place, one that alot of tourists never get to see, an escape from all the crowds and a true gem of HK.

Great half day or day trip from HK. We got a taxi from Kowlooon to Sai Kung and the cab only took about 30 minutes and was very reasonably priced. Sai Kung is a relaxed fishing village right on the water overlooking islands and various peninsulas so the water is very calm. We lunched at a great restaurant about 10 minutes walk from the taxi rank (turn left when you get to the water) ...I can't recall the name but its just past BBQ King. Great seafood meal including crab and prawns and a few beers for 4 adults and cost $Aus100.We organised for a boat to take us around the small islands for about half an hour but you could swim, go for a longer boat ride, rent kayaks, go fishing. Would be great for families as well.

A different side of the city. Over the years I've been to Hong Kong at least 15 times, always travelling with family. As I grew older and trust in my independence increased, I was allowed to stray from the family more and more (I'm 20 now)One of my old friends lived in Hong Kong for 10 years and I happened to be there when he was so we went to Sai Kung where he used to live. WOW! It's a totally different aspect of Hong Kong, a quaint and beautiful fishing village. The local sea produce was stunning, stacked up in fish tanks. The views were lovely and it was nice to see Hong Kong, a city I've grown up in, from a new perspective.

Retains charm and atmosphere.. Sai Kung town, which now has a population of about 13,000 was a small undeveloped fishing village until the fishing industry declined in the 1970’s and many fishermen moved into other businesses such as fish farming, eco tourism and seafood restaurants. A major reclamation project between 1978 and 1993 led to subsequent development of new buildings, shops, promenade, piers, public swimming pool and other facilities. Improvements to roads and public transport have seen the town grow to become a commuter town popular with ex-pats but the town still retains much of its old charm and fishing village atmosphere. The colourful harbour is always a hive of activity and sampans line the promenade selling catches of seafood direct to the public and local seafood restaurants.The plan was to have lunch at one of the many fish restaurants along the promenade, where you can choose your own fish from the tanks, or even direct from the fishermen, then discuss with the waiters how you would like your choices cooked. (Text taken from my Travel Tales blog where you will find more photos)

Although a long trip... it was well worth it for the FOOD !. We travelled all the way from Tung Chung .. MTR then mini-bus until we arrived at Sai King.. restaurant after restaurant with fresh food on display .. ordered a banquet .. food was absolutley devive.. then headed along the water front, where local fisherman were selling fresh fish from their boats directly to the public.. a real eye opener.If there was a boat rather than bus would be a deal better - but the food was just fab !!

Relax and Enjoy the Food. We've been here for a few times already. I like being here.Its a bit far, but that's the point. You get to relax and feel the different side of the usual busy hk. Walk along the seaside and enjoy the breeze. When you get hungry just get into any restaurant and enjoy the really fresh and delicious seafood. We've tried different restaurants every time we went there and they're all quite good. You could choose your "dish" from the aquariums outside the restaurants. And the price is reasonable.

The ideal spot to live in HK. A coast village that has a more peaceful vibe than the rest of Hong Kong. Mountains and sea make up for a beautiful nature environment. No annoying skyscrapers but still a good bus connection if you want to get to that part of HK. The very best of seafood in HK and lots of other small eating establishments of all origins. Most of them offering authentic, yet cheap dishes.

Get a junk to Hap Mun Bay!. At the pier/boardwalk, ask any of the people walking up and down for Hap Mun Bay. They will give you a price (I've never been ripped off), and you can haggle or just go with it. Then you get a semi-private boat ride through the bay. It is AMAZING. They will take you to a really pretty beach, and come back every hour to make runs back to shore. You can tell which junk is yours (a few come by) by the color of the flag. Don't worry; they won't leave you there. This is by far my favorite thing to do in HK. If you have a minute to leave the city, or you're just searching for some beach relaxation, this is the place. Make sure to pick up snacks in Sai Kung town because there's not too much on the bay.

Quaint village. Sai Kung is quite a distance to from downtown but the journey is well worth it!It has retained the charm of a quaint fishing village. A perfect getaway from the craziness of the big city. The center square is dotted with local char chan teng and cozy Western style cafes. I love the Pier where local fishermen park and sell their daily catch. You can also easily hire a sampan or a small boat that brings you to the geo-park, sea urchin farm or secluded beaches on neighboring small island. Along the pier, there is a whole row of huge seafood retaurants. All sorts of live seafood, even gigantic garoupas, are on display. My toddler loved it!Sai Kung is a perfect place for a beautiful day trip!
great food great sea view. great food and great sea view, many interesting stores,, easy to get to, great pricings, lots to do,,,,,,best seafood in town
Sea food and golf. Sai kung is a great little fishing town. there are mountains to hike, a golf course on one of the islands and many restaurants of all tastes...Seafood is highly recommended

Great place to live (and enjoy seafood)!. If you want to escape from the busy pace on HK island it's a good destination. People there are relaxed and enjoy the countryside. If you are lucky you can afford a nice house with some sea views and family atmosphere there and buy your fresh fish at the fishermen on the waterfront or if you are visiting you can have delicious seafood at one of the restaurants there that offer live fish to choose from. Only Sundays I would avoid as pretty crowded and all dog owners come by to walk (and sometimes show off) their pets.

Another side of HK. Away from the hustle and bustle of the city, Sai Kung is a nice seaside town with many fish & seafood restaurants. It is a bit far from Hong Kong / Kowloon station and you will need to take a green and white micro bus to get there. The buses come and go frequently.It was nice to have seafood but the restaurant we went to didn't ask how we preferred the items to be cooked, so it just came out as they decided. Maybe you need to insist.Overall a pleasant excursion.

OK we're biased!. .....you just can't beat lovely little Sai Kung.....despite the weekend traffic!!Lovely walks along the promenade, great restaurants, lovely locals and expats alike....a great place to live and visit...

Hidden gem of Hong Kong. Though most people living in the region automatically head down to Thailand or the Philippines for a beach holiday, Sai Kung is a beautiful place for a day or weekend trip. A visit there feels like a mini-holiday -- particularly due to the contrast of Sai Kung's relaxed vibe compared with Central HK or TST. Some of the beaches are great. And the seaside restaurants are fun (though understand prices before ordering any of the fresh seafood).

haven in Hong Kong. If you want to escape the hustle and bustle of the city head out to Sai Kung. There is a overly bay, great places to eat and a very much more relaxed pace of life. Hard to believe you are still in Hong Kong.
Go there if you have time. A unique destination. Try to visit of you have time. Not too many tourists. Lots to see and do. It is a great experience too.

Chuen Kee. Had dinner there on last night in HK with my business colleagues. Seafood was picked live downstairs and had dinner on the 3rd level open landing. Food was as usual good, service efficient, not much to complain about. The lai liew har was really tasty, the squid was crispy and springy, and the fish was nice and fresh.Price was expensive though. For a party of

Sai Kung. Need to escape the rat race... Sai Kung's not far away, and whether it is too eat, or generally hang out. Of course all the great hiking is in the area also. Watersports.Great photography locations. Very busy on the weekends in summer, not to be recommended. Weekdays best. Also can take junks out to the surrounding islands to get even more remote.If you like dogs, there are plenty of them here of a weekend, pushed around in chairs. Or dressed up in there sunday best.

What ambience for a seaside township. Travelling by 'bus to reach there is a wonderful scenic experience alone, in airconditioned comfort...go top deck if you can. Sai Kung is a terrific port as it is bustling with seacraft of every description in the harbour, small ferries, boats , sampans etc., a good pier , fishing trading seen on the shoreline, great park land new seating and wonderful sculptures in bronze, (look out for the Dragon Boat and it's rowers ). Many and varied shops, restaurants and cafes, a marvellous choice. We visited there on several occasions, plus the Post Office staff were so helpful with our articles to mail overseas. Very closeby is the Education Centre away from the main township, several enjoyable hours spent in the agricultural, fisheries and rocks exhibition displays, and gardeners seen hard at work tending the lovely gardens of vegetables etc. The grounds were so quiet and we admired all the clear signage in Chinese and English.

The most beautiful part of Hong Kong. When returning to my 'motherland', I always make a point of trekking out to Sai Kung. Sai Kung can be accessed via MTR by getting off at Diamond Hill MTR, and taking either the 94 or 96 bus up to Sai Kung Town. A great place to have fresh seafood at one of the restaurants on the pier, great desserts (HK style mango sago!) at the original location of Honeymoon dessert and unparalleled hiking and beautiful, unspoiled beaches (the hike from Chek Keng to Tai Long Wan is awesome) are worth the time commitment to make it out here. Locals generally come out here on weekends, so to make your experience even more special, come on an off day like a Monday.

A nice place to go just to chill and enjoy. I always love to visit this place when I want to enjoy a friendly town feel in hong kong.If you love fresh sea food then you can go here! there are fishermen sealing wide variety of things from starfish to elephant clams.They even have dried snacks for you to try. Now they have fresh Italian ice-cream as well, a nice treat to walk and cool off with. Getting there is easy and quick. Get yourself an mtr octopus-card with stored value on it of at least 200$ (HK) because you can use it in 7-11 to buy drinks with and use it on all modes of transport (excluding taxi) . I took the mtr from causeway bay and switched at northpoint (just walk across to the other side) then ride the train up to Hang Hau station get off and catch a minibus from the bus depot. THe minibus # is 101M and it will get you there is 20 minutes. It will stop at the bus terminus in Sai Kung. YOu can take the 101M back when you leave as well.

Great place to visit!. We love walking along the boardwalk, looking at the huge selection of fresh seafood, seeing dogs run around, and eating good food. If you want excellent pizza, try Paisano's pizza. If you want FANTASTIC gelato, go to "Nice Cream" (it faces the bus terminus and is just one or two doors down from 7-11).

Jubilee Squid Fishing Night. DO NOT book any boat trip or squid fishing tours with a company called JUBILEE (Cruise)! They are terrible!!! I've just come back from a squid fishing trip with 40 other friends. We booked a month ago, and the staff who received our booking seemed great, all until we paid the full payment! The activity was supposed to be from 7pm - 11pm for 15 children and 25 adults. The boat arrived at 7:20 something - LATE! The man who drove us out to sea helped himself to our food without being invited! He shouted at the children, and told them to shut up when all they did was cheer coz they caught a squid! Then he drove the boat back to the pier at 10:00pm, and told us to get off the boat!! When I approached the driver of the boat and said it was supposed to finish at 11pm, he complained that we were noisy, and he didn't want us on the boat! He said he didn't want to talk to me, and told me call the company to complain! Damn! It was a really bad experience for the children, because they were so looking forward to it! Everyone got really upset after being dumped on the pier! So whatever you do, don't book with them!

sai kung. Take the mini bus from the end of Mongkok Ladies Market Dundas St. to Sai Kung terminus $15.h.k. Great little village with lots of seafood eateriers even McDonalds go mid-afternoon and stay for dinner on the water .
Seafood heaven!. Beautiful seaside town, with the best seafood restaurants I've ever been to in HK. Hire a boat for the day and enjoy a slightly less busy HongKong

Sai Kung and its Country Parks is just THE place to go on a weekend!. From the hussle and bussle of Sai Kung village (well... smalltown by now) to the serene tranquility of its hidden places in the Country Park - Sai Kung is a MUST SEE for any visitor. There's so much to see that I won't list it here. Just GO GO GO!!!!! (Seafood galore, friendly people, and the most beautiful countryside and beaches.... WOW!)
Not exactly what you'd expect. If you're looking for beautiful water & swimming, think again. Go for the seafood and only the seafood.

Contrast from the city. We spent an afternoon in Sai Kung and highly recommend it! We took a taxi from Mong Kok $160 (return was $130). We enjoyed a walk down the pier and my sons (19&13) bought a hand line and tried a spot of fishing. We wandered through the streets and enjoyed a shoulder massage in a little place in a local alley. Highly recommended. Lunch was in a local noodle shop. Staff were very friendly and one had very good English which was helpful! We appeared to be the only Aussies in the village! Sai Kung is a very nice change of pace from the busy streets of Mong Kok. Well worth a visit!
Here always is relax. You can leave the noisy HK and in half hour be in a quite place where enjoy local fish restaurants and not so many turist during weeks days.
Seafood a must!. Fresh glorious seafood! Served in a mild flavored sauce to bring out the truly fresh delicious taste!

Beautiful Sai Kung. Sai Kung is hailed as the Back garden of Hong Kong. It is very beautiful there. If you like swimming, the beaches there will not fustrate you. If you like hiking,it is a place you may go.
Great Saikung. Great hiking, great beaches and great living - but lousy to mediocre food.

Great little fishing village. We came here with some locals and had an authentic experience. We bought some fresh scallops, crab and shrimp out of a fisherman's boat (the crab was moving around in the bag!) and then took it to a small local restaurant. There are some larger restaurants along the water that you can buy fish out of tanks but our guides told us that this was just for the "tourists." After that we went to a place for dessert and tried local Chinese desserts. Not my favorite but worth trying! All in all, this was one of my favorite things we did in Hong Kong.

A stroll through a different HK. When you are ready for a taste of something in HK decidedly less urban, head for Sai Kung town. The pier is the jumping off point to several small islands and their beaches as well as the final destination for rich seafood from Clearwater Bay. I took a stroll through the narrow streets, and then took a taxi to trek on a bit of the the MacLehose Trail, running through the Sai Kung Penninsula. I was staying in Clearwater Bay, so the trip to Sai Kung was only 20 minutes, but it's still a fascinating place to visit, even from central Hong Kong. A great day in HK!

Seaside town. Sai Kung has a quaint little old town where you can walk throught the smal backstreets and visit little Chinese shops where you can find everything and more.Try out the seafood at one of the Chinese restaurants at the waterfront. There is one right on the beach a little stroll away from town along the seaside.Meet the Sai Kung cows at night, sleeping right outside town besides the sea.Buy your veggies at one of the stalls where you can find the most beautiful ginger, Thai aubergines, mint etc etcDon't forget to hop into the mushroom bakery for scones, rolls and piesEnd the day with an 8hkd icecream from the old-fashioned icecream van at the Sai Kung pier

Beaches and seafood. Sai Kung covers a large area. You can go hiking and you can swim in one of the beaches. Sai Kung town itself is a small town that used to be a fishing village. Today it is a place for seafoods at reasonable prices.

A great nature get-away. I love Sai Kung. The town is a quaint little town with lots of seafood restaurants, a pier where fishermen sell fresh seafood and a waterfront that's perfect for a sunset stroll.And just 20 minutes away, is the Country Park, which is a big playground for the nature lovers. It's so quiet that you can hear all the birds, crickets and insects. Carabaos walk freely in the park roads. Air is fresh and the pace is slow. I stayed with one of the residents inside the park, and I took long walks along the park roads, visit small little ancient villages that are hidden well inside the park, get to the trails that lead to beautiful shorelines. Even if it's quite secluded, it's very much accessible with buses plying the major park roads and is safe as it is monitored closely by rangers. The park in general is very clean and well maintained.There are a lot of things to do and places to see in Sai Kung, outside of the usual town centre visit. The country park alone has a lot of places to see, and the Geopark is not too miss. Stay at least one night to enjoy the place. Walk or travel by land, instead of the usual island hopping by boat.

Love! Love! LOVE!!. Echo pretty much what everyone else has said. Perfect little paradise away from the hustle and bustle of Kong Kong city life, be it Hong Kong island or Kowloon. Only 30-40 mins mini bus ride from Kowloon, but it feels like a millions miles away from the city life. Fantastic seafood and a huge selection of restaurants, ranging from Dim Sum, Congee, Noodle bars, Indian curry, Italian and many, many more! Air is clean, pristine beaches, stunning mountain scenery, perfect for hikers, and because many ex-pats currently residing there, plenty to offer for those that fancy western food and drinks.I love this place so much and miss it dearly. Hope to go back real soon

Harmonise with the beauty of nature. My family and I took a boat trip out to a section of the Sai Kung coastal treasures, and it was absolutely beautiful! Nothing like going back to nature, listening to the sound of wind rushing past your ears, and seeing the distant mountains shrouded in mist and the faraway sea. We had a very reasonably priced seafood lunch thereafter - the perfect experience!

Fabulous escape to the seaside for fresh seafood - straight from the boats!. Whenever I am in Hong Kong for leisure I make it a priority to escape to Sai Kung for an afternoon by the seaside. Buy local seafood live and fresh from the boats and have it cooked in a nearby seafood outlet. A great location for couples looking for an escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.

The Place for Seafood. This is just like an old town with low rise houses but is definitely one of the best places for seafood. Many restaurants offer open sitting areas for visitors to enjoy fresh seafood made by the top-notch chefs there. You can bring your own seafood (so they can cook for you), or you can choose and buy the seafood right from the shops or restaurants there.

Quiet town with great seafood restaurants. Only 30 min by taxi from Mongkok, Sai Kung is a great place to escape from noisy and busy HK. Wander around the old city streets and find a nice restaurant to enjoy lunch. The port promenade is filled with many restaurants specializing in fish and seafood with lovely views of the boats in the harbour.It is also possible to do many small treks that you can find around Sai Kung that lead you to the jungle and as you climb up the hill, the views of the bay become spectacular!

Best during the week, more than just seafood. Sai Kung used to be a small fishing village but has now changed into a vibrant town, but still manages to maintain a village feel. It can be crowded at the weekends due to visitors, from other parts of Hong Kong, coming for the 'famous' seafood, and so this can affect the traffic and crowds. The weekdays are much better and mainly serves the local population (local and expat).There is more to see and do than just seafood... Walk around the old Sai Kung Village and see an old man who still practices the art of 'metal bashing', take a junk to the many adjacent islands (do bargain on price), go to 'Harrods" (as the locals call it) which is an everything shop for all kinds of goods (especially plastic ones from China) or the everything stationary shop (around the central square), eat at the al fresco dining places around the square (e.g. Ali Oli Bakery), and of course the seafood restaurants along the waterfront (Tung Kee for a well-priced set menu, or Loaf On- the 1 star Michelin for a la carte). There are newer shops opening up which serve a more expat population e.g Babushka for children's organic clothes, organic furniture shop Tree next door to an organic vegetable shop, and good steak at Anthony's Ranch or huge pizzas at Paisanos Pizza.A great place to walk around and feel the local Hong Kong.

Get away from the city for seafood. Minibus, if you ask how first or are brave, is the cheapest way to get there and back. Taxi about $130 HK each way from Kowloon. Well worth the trip for the sights en route and strolling the fishing dock, then dining on the wharf. Gelato or other treats can be found in the village after eating. Prices vary, but most are less $$ than Hong Kong or Kowloon and much more fun.

Go back to the real Hong Kong. Sai Kung Village is about an hour and a half (max) out of Central Hong Kong. A MTR and light bus ride but it is a lifetime away from the crunching traffic, neon lights and "copy watch Mr" pressure of Hong Kong.Great seafood at reasonable (for HK) prices, good atomsphere and something for everyone to do.Allow a day and explore the outer islands if possible.

A must go for seafood lover. This is one of the best place to eat seafood with reasonable price. U can even buy your seafood alive from the fisherman and get the restaurant to cook it for small fees. Also, from sai kung pier u can take kaido to several amazing beach. A bus ride away will bring u to maritime park where u can hv little hike and amazing view. Weekends in sai Kung tend to b very busy though...u might wanna go there during wkdays for less crowd...
Quiet. Naturaleasy transportationbeach with sea breeze!
my hometown. you dont feel like you in hong kong, its my hometown, friendly, easy to get around and so much to do...dont go on a sunday though!!
Underrated. You totally should go!. Love the vibe. Love to see the locals hanging out with no tourists around!

not the greatest experience. this is more of a cultural experience than a culinary one. The food is below the average band according to my standards, it will be overpriced if not accompanied by a cantonese speaking guide. It's far, it's generally overrated.

Great seafood. Went there with friends and family. Hired a little boat to go out for some fishing. Came back and had seafood dinner. Delicious and and adventure that was fun. Many small shops and would go back again!

Wonderful place for SEAFOOD and lounging at the Wharf. Sai Kung is a special village - great people live there, good food and a great place to people watch on a lazy afternoon. Take the ferry over to Kau Sai Chau to the public golf course for a meal in Sai Kung as well.
Buy seafood. Buy seafood from the fisherman and bring it to the local restaurants for preparation. Awesome!

More than Fish n Chips. If you can spare the time during a stay in Hong Kong, consider a day in Sai Kung, it’s an authentic little fishing town (too big to call it a village) in the North East of the New Territories. We did, and found the change of scene and pace almost exciting. We (old folk!) enjoyed the adventure, and swiping our Octopus Passes with aplomb on both the MRT and the Mini Bus.We researched this little side trip on the web before we went to Hong Kong, and to summarize how we get there; we took the MTR to Choi Hung Station, and from outside exit C of that station we took the Green Mini Bus right to Sai Kung town centre. The 30 minute bus ride through suburban and rural New Territories was almost reason enough for the trip on its own. The colourful harbour in Sai Kung was a hive of activity and sampans lined the promenade selling catches of seafood direct to the public and to the local seafood restaurants. I’ve never seen such a variety of exotic sea creatures caught at one time by one little boat!Across from the harbour, are the restaurants with their own array of tanks with their menu swimming or crawling about on display. Some of these are high class places and are a bit expensive, but cheaper places can be found in streets further back from the harbour. The seafood is obviously fresh, but it was difficult for us (westerners) to know what everything was, and what to order, so we took a stab at it so to speak! It was all very tasty, but it was a struggle for me at least to deal with heads, bones, fins, and claws etc., that’s the way it’s done here. My wife managed a lot better than I.You can also take Sampan trips to the nearby islands out in the bay, lots of boat owners touting trips. We didn’t look into that, but I think you can cherry-pick just where you want to go, for reasonable prices I am told. A memorable day out we would recommend.
.. Excellent village for fish restaurants with also beautiful scenery.
The other side of Hongkong. Fresh seafood ,a bit expensive but it's all worth it. Don't go on weekends as it tends to be crowded because of locals.

A fascinating visit from central Hong Kong. Sai Kung is an must see side trip from the modern HK Central/Kowloon if you have time; a very different side of Hong Kong. Fantastic seafood restaurants (almost no English spoken), interesting dockside fish market, tours of the bay (you will be approached by lots of boat owners, but fear not, they are not too expensive).

must go on sunday. on sunday is when they have the fish market and its not just an ordinary fish market. you actually purchase directly from the fisherman's boat and they have so many different types of underwater creatures i've ever seen. the seafood restaurant is tasty and fresh there.

Fantastic!. Definitely some of the best walks and hikes in Hong Kong. the beaches (Tai Long wan, and Long Ke wan) are two of the best beaches HK has to offer (almost Thailand type, and great for surfing during winters as the waves pound the gorgeous mile long, serene and lonely beach). A bit hard to get to but thats the whole point because definitely worth it and just out of reach of the throngs of people who would just plomp their bottoms on a nice place without much struggle anywhere else in HK. So worth the trek and definitely worth spending the night over at Long Ke Wan if the weather is nice (meaning not too hot) as you can rent tents for a minimal charge at the beach cafe run by the local village folk (equiped with showers and the works).

Bustling, harbour village. Foodies and shoppers delight. This little village has many quirky shops to suit all tastes. Restaurants, cafes of all cuisines. The harbour is a great place to take time out and watch the locals. Get to the pier at around 17 00h and watch the fisherman sell their catch to buyers on the pier above. Go for a ride to the islands close by and enjoy the lovely scenery. Plenty of ex Pats here to ask for help should you need it.

Interesting Fishing village. Friends in Hong Kong took us to see this village which boasts a row of restaurants supplied with fish by a fleet of ships moored in the picturesque harbour. I have never seen such a variety of fish all kept in deep tanks. The village is situated in a beautiful bay surrounded by wooded hills. This is a popular weekend venue for residents of metropolitan Hong Kong. I think you can get there by public transport. You may also hire a boat to visit the surrounding islands. Lovely trip.

Best seafood, too bad it's not cheap.. It's not so expensive, but not cheap either. Eat seafood there, ask for the price. Remember fishes there counter /600gr. not /1Kg. The rest just ask before order, and apparently they don't really play around with the pricing. Tough competition I guess. Bring someone who can speak Cantonese, as most of them unable to speak English except the restaurant manager.I will be back definitely.

I can't believe this is only 1 hr from downtown Central!. This is an archipelago of islands - you can hike through the hills (maybe I should refer to them as untouched mountains), to get to your own private beach at the other side. Alternately you can hire a local Sampa to give you a ride! Riding in one of those through the waves is an experience in itself (have a strong stomach!)
Fish heaven. Yes one of the best for fish eatingGreat boat trips to the islands also

Seafood paradise!. If you love seafood you will love Sai Kung - all the restaurants along the sea serve the freshest seafood, also a quieter side of Hong Kong as well.... People can chill along the sea side, fishing or simply have some food or a drink in the restaurant or sit outside the restaurant! There is a nice dessert place around the area as well - my favourite is mango sago dessert!
quaint old hong kong. very different! fishing village worth a trip. some distance from the city centre, but a bus ride is around 40minutes. if u are saving time, use a taxi!
great fishing pier.. CANT not miss this pier, can see fisherman fishing and sale seafood in the boats/

some nice spots for snorkeling. There is no other place than Sai Kung here in Hong Kong for snorkeling, though it is not as good as other diving places outside Hong Kong. This area is quite far from where most local residents live, I often get motion sickless after taking a long bus ride to this place.

Great hiking. Haven't been here for a long time. Yes, it is full of rich people but there are plenty of places to dine and things to do for everyone else! Fantastic array of hiking trails, real wild areas (including wild boar and snakes that have attacked people), and great seafood. The last time I went here with friends, the village we were hiking to had been abandoned! Felt a bit silly.
a different Hong Kong. More like Hong Kong used to be, some lovely little shops and restaurants too.
White beaches best Thai food. This is a great place to visit. The BEST Thai food in Hk is here. During the week this is an amazing way spend a day on the beach and each great food.

Worth a day trip. Nice quiet fishing town to explore if you want to get away from the noise. Make sure to visit some of the surrounding islands - they are beautiful. Seafood is good but the best is pricey.
Sai kung, perfect place to start a hike. I recommend Sai Kung as the starting point of many fabulous hikes.

Sai Kung Pier. Loved the Pier where fishermen sold live sea creatures on sampan-like boats. Prices from some restaurants can be a rip-off though there are some that charge reasonable rates. So it is best that you go there (if eating seafood) with a local who knows the area. Loved the 'Honey Desserts' shop at the end of the food street where HK traditional desserts are sold. A walk at this pier is a must!
Worth the bus ride.. Everything. Go with a local or else you might pay more than you should.

Yummy but overpriced. It is worth the long trip up, and remember to take part in the choosing of your dinner - literally. The Bamboo clams and mini slipper lobsters are a Must Try! Slightly overpriced due to the touristy area. It was a memorable experience as we were caught in a Typhoon on our way back in a speeding minibus!
Attractive Hong Kong countryside. Some beautiful beaches and country parks for hiking with great trails.
Great Seafood. Lots of fresh seafood to choose and the restaurant will cook them for you however you like.

A great day out in HK. This is a small town in NT of HK.on the water. many fishing boats. You can buy fresh fish directly from the boats at pier and take to near-by rests to be cooked as you wish fo a small fee.
Walk the old town with original buildings,streets and shops....old China About HKD200 in a taxi from TST.

Relaxing Place but avoid weekends like the plague. Sai Kung is a fisherman's village. Most people goto Sai Kung to eat Seafood. Beware you can get ripped off as you choose the seafood at the front of the restaurant then it is taken into the kitchen to cook for you, but you cannot challenge whether they have used the seafood you have bought to cook it for you. Prices are usually quite high.On weekdays Sai Kung is heaven, so if you are holiday then I would recommend only going on weekdays as on weekends there are lots of people who come in to either take boats to the seaside or go on walking trips. Restaurants are really busy on Friday evening, Saturdays and Sundays so please avoid.Overall it's a lovely place and no high rise blocks to block views....

Visit this place before it becomes too commercial.. I have been visiting Sai Kung since the early 80's and little has changed here but like the rest of HK, it won't be long until the mega malls and MTR stations arrive. Take a little boat out into the bay and enjoy the scenery and stroll along the promenade to gaze at all the fish tanks outside the restaurants. A relaxing afternoon out.
Kingdom of Seafood. You are now surrounding by the sea, the monster creature of mother nature of god. Try out the authentic recipe, you will never get better seafood out of Sai Kung.

The Pearl of the Pearl of the Orient. Part of Hong Kong that few visitors know exists. It's where the Hong Kongese go to get their wedding photos taken and have a BBQ at the weekend. Lush green scenery, rocky beaches, fishing villages and emerald isles dotting the choppy waters. Gets a bit chokka at the weekends though, so recommend visiting in the week if you have that luxury.
nicest seafood. this is one place i will never skip whenever i am in HK. this is the place to get the best seafood in HK. not too expensive as well.

A seaside town in transition. This is a seaside place on the east side of Hong Kong and away from the main public transport routes. We went there on a Saturday when it was very crowded with lots of people (often showing off their dogs) were walking up and down the promenade. There are seafood restaurants along the front and fishermen at the quayside sell their wares directly from their boats to locals. A wide spectrum of fruits of the sea is available including crayfish, crabs and other kinds of fish with gills. You can walk a mile or more on the promenade and look out at the nearby islands and, if you want, take a boat trip to a golf course on one or simply have a ride to another. During the week, however, the place is much quieter and in squares away from the sea front there are ex-patriots eating western food, reading newspapers and gossiping. There is an English-language bookshop and there are Italian restaurants and bakeries as well. The place is in transition because, as the border with mainland China opens ever wider, it seems likely that the ex-patriot enclaves will be swallowed up by incomers bringing traditional Chinese culture.You can tell that I am a European and value the relaxed cafe culture and hope it survives.

Nothing special. Sai Kung isn't awful, but there are many better destinations in Hong Kong.On the positive side, it's fairly quiet (compared to central Hong Kong) but there's still usually large crowds of tourists. It takes a long time to get to (you could get to Lantau from Central in less time) and because there's no MTR, you're somewhat at the mercy of traffic.In Sai Kung there are a lot of seafood restaurants, but not really much else. It's a popular place to get a junk boat ride from, but again, you could do so in Victoria Harbour, so that in itself isn't a very good reason to visit.It's probably quite a nice place to live, and it does have its passionate defenders, but as a tourist destination, it's not anything special.

Nice place to leave the hustle and bustle of HK. Just a short taxi ride or metro and bus ride away is this nice ocean side town with a nice promenade and good seafood restaurants on the waterfront. It's quite a pleasant change of pace after the crowds and traffic of Hong Kong. It has nice views of the ocean, boats and islands. The drive up through the steep hills on the winding road is interesting as well.

Great place for Sea food and doggie lovers. Nice place to experience the sea food culture of Hong Kong where fresh sea food is displayed in tanks and also one can buy them from the numerous boats near the pier. Went on a Sunday and found the place filled with doggies of different sizes, shaptes and fashion accessories too. Anyone wanting a different type of food and fancies something spicy can try the only restaurant with Sri Lankan food in Hong Kong too.
Best place to have Seafood. wonderful place to lay back for weekend's afternoon , plenty seafood restaurants, prices acceptable

Sai Kung in Hong Kong is an amazing fun place to spend a day AND evening in for fresh seafood, a boat ride to the famous geopark. - Be sure to first visit the Tourist's Center by the pier for useful info!LONG VERSION1. Kau Sai Chou Public Golf Club House Our Favorite!- My wife and I were pleasantly surprised that one does not have to play golf to enjoy a nice snack and drink at their spectacular Club House overlooking the gorgeous golf course by the sea!- The 15min boat ride in the scenic and calm harbor is a treat itself!- We had a relaxing brunch and drinks on the 2nd story terrace watching people happily playing on the vast, magnificent course by the water! Life is beautiful indeed! - They have good foods on both Chinese and western menu. The price is reasonable, starting HK$38 [US$5] for a simple dish upwards to various combos and buffet; beer and wine at HK$30.  The cost of the boat ride is HK$35-45pp Round Trip.  NOTES:- At the Club's own pier, just ask the Club's pier staff about the ride, since there is NO PROMINENT sign about the trip to the club house, even though the bulletin board at the pier does post menus and the boat fare. One can simply get on the boat to the Club, where one must buy a ticket for the round trip fare to return.- Although I normally use 2 walking canes to get around, with the help of their friendly crew, I had no problem getting on/off their good size boat. Since there are steps at the loading area leading to the boat, it is not wheelchair friendly, however, unfortunately. Well, I am not sure, if they could provide a portable ramp for that, though.2. BOAT RIDEs to GEOPARK- There are a number of different boat rides to various part of the famous Geopark islands complex, which is reportedly fun and highly educational.  Unfortunately, we did NOT have enough time that day to explore the Geopark. Well, maybe next time.3. SEAFOOD BOATS and RESTAURANTS- It's a pleasure to walk along the pier to check out the restaurants, one after the other, all of which have huge tanks in front, full of live fishes, clams, geoducks, shrimps, even horseshoe crabs...! A sight to behold! It's also fun to check out the small boats below the pier, full of live seafoods! Incredibly, most of them are IMPORTS and NOT local fresh catches! A seafood diner at one of those restaurants is highly recommended! In town, near the pier, there are a couple of western restaurants, too, as well as some bars, which offer happy hours (5-9).Peterskis, Feb 2012

Chill out place, very relaxing. I go to Sai Kung many times for relaxing, seafood and to be less stressful when it is too much for being in the city. Its busy at the weekends and not so busy in the weekdays but I like it there always.
Great Seafood Place. If you like Seafood, you will found the best and fresh seafood here.

Very relaxing. This is just the thing after fighting crowds in central, Tsim Sha Tsui or Causeway Bay. Chill out while sitting by the water having a couple of beers and a nice seafood meal as you look at at the water, the surrounding hills, or watch the fishermen bring in their fresh catches directly to the restaurants on the pier. You can buy a ride on one of the many boats to one of the smaller, uninhabited islands too if you like.
Different attractions!. You can have a great view of the sea in the afternoon and enjoy seafood at night. Seafood picking from all different shops is an experience.
Sai Kung. The westerners' centre of HK (I used to live there myself). OK for seafood & boat trips are good
lobsters not crummy crayfish. it was delicious /clean /fresh /everything/ 5 course meal for less than $50 aus each couldnt buy the same in sydney for under $200 each

Hong Kong's garden. I'm not just referring to the town of Sai Kung but also the whole area including Wong Shek Pier. Seafood at Sai Kung but the surrounds should be visited as well. Well serviced by buses.

fish market and dog park. it was a bit far to travel..our lovely Hong Kong friends took us there by mini bus from Po Lam bus station, but the trip for us is worth coz u will see some islands there and boat fishing people that sells freshly catch fish, shells crabs on the boats..then dried seafoods..then the famous fish restaurant where u can ask them to cook it for u, then u will see many dog owners with their dogs walking them thru the pathways in the afternoon..and thry r all nice dogs..

Get away from the city.. Most people don't get to see this side of Hong Kong if they are just visiting. The country park has some excellent walks and beaches and the town has some good seafood reataurants and bars.

Overpriced and over rated. There was nothing to see - it seems all the historical sites have been cemented over. Tourist destinations seem to be crowded with local young people. The sea food is grossly over priced and the service is poor

One Last Rural Place Left in Hong Kong. If you want to get away from the fast paced Hong Kong living, pay a visit to Sai Kung on the east coast of Kowloon. My wife and I were there on our last day in Hong Kong before heading back to Canada. Sai Kung is a fishing town, you will see people buying fresh fish etc from local fishermen and boats along the pier. One special history about Sai Kung is the "Ding Houses." The "Dings" are male descendents of aboringinal Hong Kong people who live on the island before the British took over as a colony. The Hong Kong government gave "the Dings" (not the daughters) free land to build houses, only three storey tall, 700 sq ft per floor to preserve the rural scenery of Sai Kung. Many Hong Kong residents and westerners bought or rent "ding houses." Look for the "ding houses" when you visit Sai Kung to relive this surprisngly untold histroy of Hong Kong.

Great way to spend your day and enjoy Seafood. Take the MTR to Choi Hung (green line), get out at Exit C1 and get on a public light bus (green mini bus, HK$7) to Sai Kung pier.It takes only about 20 mins. What a great view. You can see the nearby picturesque small islands, boats and mountains and you will see many people at the pier gather around buying seafood from the floating markets. There are plenty of seafood restaurants nearby with fresh seafood. I have never seen so much seafood in one place. Giant live Lobsters, crabs, scallops, crayfish and many more are displayed in tanks in most of the seafood restaurants. Although the menu prices are not that cheap the food is value for money. The place I had lunch was great and the food was delicious! There are many boats which will take you to nearby small Islands and it cost you around HKD20 return. If you like hiking, there are plenty of tracks for you. In my opinion one day is not enough to spend time in Sai Kung considering there are so many things you can to do and to see..

A great place to "relax" your day and enjoy Seafood. Take the MTR to Choi Hung (green line), get out at Exit C1 and get on a public light bus (green mini bus, HK$7) to Sai Kung pier.It takes only about 20 mins. What a great view. You can see the nearby picturesque small islands, boats and mountains and you will see many people at the pier gather around buying seafood from the floating markets. There are plenty of seafood restaurants nearby with fresh seafood. I have never seen so much seafood in one place. Giant live Lobsters, crabs, scallops, crayfish and many more are displayed in tanks in most of the seafood restaurants. Although the menu prices are not that cheap the food is value for money. The place I had lunch was great and the food was delicious! There are many boats which will take you to nearby small Islands and it cost you around HKD20 return. If you like hiking, there are plenty of tracks for you. In my opinion one day is not enough to spend time in Sai Kung considering there are so many things you can to do and to see..

An amazing seafood experience. Sai Kung is a beautiful, little known escape from the city. This quaint fishing village looks like it has miraculously withstood the modernization of the gargantuan metropolis of Hong Kong, just 40 minutes away by car. If you love fresh seafood you must make a pilgrimage out there. In Sai Kung you will find tanks and tanks of huge fish and shellfish that you've probably never seen elsewhere before. You can get the restaurants along the waterfront to cook it for you immediately and it will be so delicious! Before or after your meal walk along the pier and watch the locals sell fresh catch from the sea right out of their boats. (Makes you wish you had a kitchen in HK so you can bring something home.)

Nice place for Dim Sum and Supper. It is possible to visit this part of town anytime of the day. The tour guide showed us Sai Kung in early morning and we had a hearty Dim Sum in a local restaurant. We spent the day visiting a family and joined them for Chinese lunch, very happy. There are many shops to see and buy but almost all of them are written in Chinese. When night came, the streets are full of food vendors and colorful restaurant signs started to sparkle. The place is beautiful and the dinner was AWESOME!

Interesting place - go earlier in the day. We went to Sai Kung as an afterthoughtWe took the subway to Diamond Head and the bus (i think it was 92) to Sai KungIt took atleast an hour to get there and(being november) it was dark when we got there - but the bus station is right on the waterfront so its very convenient.After we arrived we discovered that there are other things to do there - like go to the marine park and see the coastline and rocks - but as we were there for only a short time we just ate dinner.We saw a few people selling fresh seafood right off their boats then we walked down the waterfront past all the restaurants. We were there around 5 so it wasn't very busy yet but it gets pretty packed.We were handed a number of leaflets and picked one where we could choose 4 out of 10 dishes. Other patrons were actually picked their dinner from the numerous tanks, of course not speaking the language that might have been difficult.We paid about $380 for a fish, lobster and pasta, clams and vermicelli, bok choi and some crab with onions and a beer.The next door table paid about $1900, there were two people and they ordered one of the king crabs. I didn't see anything else so i'm not sure if they got other dishes with that. From another restaurant I saw that might be the going rate for crabs that size - they were enormous.I would recommend going to see other things in the area and then eating dinner at the waterfront and taking the bus back after dinner.Apparently you can get off at another subway stop(the stop after diamond head) but it was easier for us just to ride the full route.

Great place to visit. We visited Sai Kung on two separate occasions during our trip to Hong Kong in August 2011. We had two small children (aged 6 and 7) with us. Sai Kung can be reached by using the 92 bus from Diamond Hill MTR Station. Alternatively there are many green public mini-buses which go there from Choi Hung.Sai Kung is a fishing village located in the New Territories. It is surrounded by beautiful unspoilt countryside and has some lovely country walks available nearby. Visitors can hire a small boat to take them out to one of the islands. We went out to a lovely small island with an amazing beach. The kids loved riding in the boat as well as playing on the beach. Prices for these boats are negotiable and depend quite a lot on your bargaining skills but they are generally quite reasonable and cheap.Sai Kung village itself has many shops and restaurants. Visitors should bear in mind that Sai Kung is not really a touristy place: it is somewhere that locals and ex-pats visit and so a lot of the shops are geared towards them and their needs. However, many of the restaurants serve fresh seafood and have an incredible range of seafood swimming in tanks outside. There is a very nice public swimming pool in Sai Kung town centre that is reasonably priced and is clean and well maintained.Overall, Sai Kung is somewhere I would recommend to visitors. There are boat trips, country walks, interesting shops, and restaurants serving delicious locally-caught seafood. We went twice with two small children and they both loved it so families with small kids should not feel put off.

A hidden germ - Sai Kung has it all!!!!. Sai Kung is a lovely part of Hong Kong that most tourists miss out on. It has beautiful beaches e.g. Hap Mun bay which are easily reached by a small sampan from the public pier at around 20-25HK$- it is quite full on Sundays. Trio beach is my favorite and you can walk here or take a sampan from Pak Sha Wan pier, 5 min before you get to Sai Kung and it costs 10 HK$.Sai Kung Country park is an amazing day out with the best beaches in Hong Kong - but you have to hike there and you need to get a bus into the country park or take a taxi (Sai wan) to the start of the hike. Tai Long Wan is fantastic (also for surfers) and the scenic hike takes about 2 hours with kids - lots of little restaurants along the way. If you get tired just stay at Sai Wan beach which you reach in about 45 min. On weekends it is possible to book a speedboat back at the last restaurant before you get to Tai Long Wan beach - usually 100 HK$ per person but book as soon as you get there if you want this option as the boat tend to fill up quickly.Sai Kung has fantastic seafood restaurants situated right on the seafront facing the habour and these restaurants are quite busy on weekends where all the Chinese Hong kong recidents and expats escape to this lovely spot. Sai kung has lots of other types of restaurants as well so it caters for everybody. A stroll through the old town (near the temple) is a special experience and the narrow streets are cosy and has lots of little interesting shops. Lions park is situated right before you enter Sai Kung and this is a lovely botanic garden where the kids can run around and play and if you are up for a beautiful scenic walk to a great beach it is only 45 min walk. Furthermore, Saturday morning you can buy organic vegetables here and a fair price.Sai Kung has one of the best walks along the seafront and on weekends (and sometimes during the week) you can buy seafood straight from the fishing boats along here. At the end of the pier (500 meters) you can rent kayaks, windsurfing equipment etc quite cheap. Sunday is dog-lovers day in Sai Kung and the seafront is full of dogs running around (or in strollers and dressed up!).Most people choose not to go to Sai Kung because it seems to be far away but it is actually quite easy. Get the red minibus from Dundas street in Mongkok (right at the end of ladies market) and you are in Sai Kung within 20-25 min. To go back jump on the same bus from the stadium in Sai Kung about every 20 min :) If you go via Choi Hung (green line on MTR) take exit C2 and the green minibus to Sai Kung is right there, bus 1a. Go to the last stop on route and you are dropped of at the pier in Sai Kung. From Hang Hau (purple line on MTR) take exit B and the green minibus to Sai Kung is 101 situated in the center lane of the bus station :) Last stop is Sai Kung pier.Sai kung square has 4-5 great restaurants and there is a small playground where the kids can play while the parents enjoy the dinner - there is also a basket ball court right there.

A perfect break from the crowds, noise and chaos of the city. Not many tourists come here but ex-pats and locals love this relaxing fishing village with the long seaside promenade, seafood restaurants and wine bars. This is an excellent place to visit to get away from the chaos and business of greater Hong Kong and Kowloon. Its a bit like Stanley but not at all touristy and with much less tourist crowd, this is a get-away for locals and ex-pats. The promenade bars (Sai Sai is my favorite) are nice and the local fishermen selling their live fish, shellfish and other exotic things from the sea to local buyers are very interesting to watch and photograph. Sampan boats can be rented, cheaper than in Aberdeen, to take you to Sharp island or other nearby places. There is good seafood on the promenade. Inside the town area, 2-3 minutes walk, you can find good Thai Food, European Bistro restaurants as well as local restaurants. Of course there is a McDonalds and Starbucks as well if you're keen on comfort foods. Also, for hikers, Sai Kung has some nice opportunities for spending a day out in nature.Lastly, Sai Kung is well connected to much of HK, particularly Kowloon area by local bus transportation. We highly rate Sai Kung and recommend it to visitors when they have had a enough of the city and need a break from the crowds, noise and chaos. Its a paradise in this regard.
